title: â€˜A lot of fearâ€™: the families bearing brunt of Swedenâ€™s immigration crackdown | Sweden | The Guardian
description: Many of those moved into an asylum return centre have held jobs for years and can speak the language
Author: Miranda Bryant
Headline: Many of those moved into an asylum return centre have held jobs for years and can speak the language
Content: Thamer and Faten, originally from Iraq, are facing deportation despite their third child being born in Sweden.Photograph: Josefine Stenersen/The GuardianView image in fullscreenThamer and Faten, originally from Iraq, are facing deportation despite their third child being born in Sweden.Photograph: Josefine Stenersen/The GuardianSwedenâ€˜A lot of fearâ€™: the families bearing brunt of Swedenâ€™s immigration crackdownMany of those moved into an asylum return centre have held jobs for years and can speak the languageMiranda Bryantin StockholmSat 24 Jan 2026 09.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 10.44 ESTShareâ€œSweden didthisfor us,â€ said Sofiye*, making a supportive scooping up gesture with her hands. â€œAnd then, bam.â€ She dropped them to the ground.Sofiye, who has three children, arrived in Sweden from Uzbekistan as an asylum seeker in 2008, and for much of that time she was able to build a life in the Scandinavian country. The family lived in a flat in a Stockholm suburb and Sofiye worked for the municipality in the home help department. She learned Swedish and her children went through the Swedish school system. Her youngest son was born in Sweden and her 18-year-old son, Hamza, who is studying in college to be a technician, doesnâ€™t know life anywhere else.Three years ago, however, after unsuccessfully seeking refugee status four times, Sofiye lost her right to work and is now living under the threat of a deportation order. For the last two years she and two of her children have been living in limbo in an asylum return centre in an industrial area near Stockholmâ€™s Arlanda airportThe situation is causing her so much anxiety that for the last two months she has lost her appetite and been vomiting with stress. As she spoke to the Guardian she held a plastic bag into which she regularly retched.View image in fullscreenThe asylum return centre near Stockholmâ€™s Arlanda airport. The Swedish migration agency said it had made efforts to ensure the centres were appropriate for children.Photograph: Josefine Stenersen/The Guardianâ€œI cannot sleep. I sleep just one or two hours. I throw up. I am so stressed. I donâ€™t want to speak to the children because here,â€ she said, pointing to her head, â€œis occupied. I donâ€™t know physically, mentally what I should do.â€The centre, one of a growing number of reception and return facilities aimed at housing an estimated 11,000 asylum seekers in the coming years, is part of Swedenâ€™s increasingly hostileasylum and immigration policy. The centre-right government, which depends on the support of the far-right Sweden Democrats, says it wants to â€œredirect focusâ€ away from receiving asylum seekers to instead becoming a â€œcountry for labour immigrationâ€.The government recently celebrated data showing that Sweden had its lowest level of asylum seekers since 1985, claiming that lower numbers â€œcreate better conditions for successful integrationâ€. Thousands of people like Sofiye â€“ who have lived in Sweden for years and are well-established in society and the job market, with children who were born in Sweden â€“ face deportation.Among the recent policy changes include asylum seekers being placed in reception centres instead of being provided with individual accommodation who are then offered â€œrepatriation grantsâ€ to leave the country voluntarily.The government has also introduced stricter conditions for gaining citizenship and tightened family reunification rules. Applicants must prove their identity through an in-person visit and provide more documentation than was previously the case.Committing a crime can now result in losing the right to live in Sweden for anyone who is not a Swedish citizen. In 2025 a total of 440 people were subjected to criminal deportations, according to government figures.â€œIf you do not want to become part of this community, you should not come to Sweden,â€ the government has stated.View image in fullscreenA â€˜refugees welcomeâ€™ demonstration in Gothenburg in 2015. The attitude towards immigration in Sweden has hardened in the years since.Photograph: Scanpix Sweden/ReutersThe hostile environment is a far cry from Swedenâ€™s immigration policies of the past. In 2014, at the start of a period when the number of people arriving to Europe from countries in the Middle East rose sharply, the then prime minister, Fredrik Reinfeldt, made a speech urging Swedes toâ€œopen your heartsâ€to newcomers.The direction of travel is unlikely to change even with a general election next year, say observers, as the main political parties, including the opposition centre-left Social Democrats, have embraced similar hardline policies.â€œMany people that we meet say to us: â€˜We came to Sweden believing this was a country that respected human rights: where are they?â€™â€ said Nannie SkÃ¶ld, a counsellor at Stockholm Stadsmissionâ€™s Who Am I Tomorrow? project, which provides legal and psychosocial support to individuals and families with deportation orders.The latest government figures show that 8,312 people returned to their home countries in 2025, the highest number in a decade, while the number of asylum seekers decreased by 30% on the previous year.â€œWe meet people who came to Sweden for work or to study, and people who donâ€™t have grounds for asylum,â€ said SkÃ¶ld. â€œWe also meet people who are fleeing from the Taliban or they are LGBTQ from Uganda, and who then see that their request for international protection is denied.â€One of the changes that was having a particularly damaging impact is the decision to abolish â€œtrack changesâ€, she said. The new rule, which came into force at short notice last April, prevents people who have had their asylum applications rejected from applying for a residence permit, even if they have worked in Sweden. It also prevents those who had already obtained a work permit from extending it.The decision is estimated to have put 4,700 people who were established in Swedish society at risk of deportation.SkÃ¶ld added: â€œPeople [who] are well integrated and established in Sweden â€¦ are asking: â€˜What else could I have done? â€¦ How could I possibly prove my worth if even doing everything that is supposedly correct isnâ€™t enough and will never be enough?â€™â€Life in the return centres is tough. The facility near Arlanda, which also houses new arrivals, is an â€œopenâ€ centre, meaning people can come and go. But getting around from there is logistically difficult and many people are getting by on a few kronor a day. It was a difficult place to be in for children, said SkÃ¶ld, who said her team heard from LGBTQ asylum seekers that the shared spaces could feel unsafe. Many there suffer from poor mental health as a result of their precarious circumstances.â€œThere is a lot of fear, a lot of anxiety,â€ she said. â€œPeople who have received a deportation order fear being deported any day.â€View image in fullscreenThamer says his sons are willing and able to work.Photograph: Josefine Stenersen/The GuardianThamer and Faten are a married couple who came to Sweden from Iraq on work visas with their two sons, who are now 20 and 16. Their third son was born in Sweden in 2021. But they now face deportation after their asylum applications were denied and work visas expired. Thamer said that a criminal organisation has threatened to harm their children if they return to Iraq.â€œThere are people who have lived in Sweden for 30 years but they donâ€™t talk Swedish like me,â€ said Thamer, 52. â€œI write as well, not just speak. What do they want more than that? I am not a criminal.â€Thamer said he was offered a job as a car mechanic but was unable to take it because his work visa had expired. â€œSweden wants men and I have three. Can they not make use of them?â€The Swedish migration agency said it was unable to comment on individual cases. It was â€œworking to ensure that the [reception and return centres] are safe for everyone staying there, with particular consideration given to children and other vulnerable groups, such as LGBTQ personsâ€, a spokesperson said.*Those interviewed requested their surnames not be published as their cases arein processExplore more on these topicsSwedenEuropeMigrationnewsShareReuse this content

title: Hereâ€™s how Europe can file for divorce from Donald Trump | Phillip Inman | The Guardian
description: Amid the tumult of the WEF in Davos this week, some investors are leading the way by ditching US government bonds
Author: Phillip Inman
Headline: Amid the tumult of the WEF in Davos this week, some investors are leading the way by ditching US government bonds
Content: Waving goodbye to Donald Trump wonâ€™t be easy or quick for Europe.Photograph: Markus Schreiber/APView image in fullscreenWaving goodbye to Donald Trump wonâ€™t be easy or quick for Europe.Photograph: Markus Schreiber/APViewpoint columnEconomicsHereâ€™s how Europe can file for divorce from Donald TrumpPhillip InmanAmid the tumult of the WEF in Davos this week, some investors are leading the way by ditching US government bondsSat 24 Jan 2026 11.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 13.22 ESTShareThere is a way to file for divorce fromDonald Trumpand Europe needs to grab the opportunity.To the public it will look as if nothing has changed. But behind the scenes the EU and the UK could close the joint bank account and cut up the credit cards, or at least set in motion a form of financial separation that limits the power of a controlling former partner.It wonâ€™t be easy to walk away and it wonâ€™t be quick. But a degree of separation is necessary and, crucially, achievable.â€˜At the table or on the menuâ€™: a turbulent Davos week with Trumpâ€™s circus in townRead moreAs a tumultuous week in the Swiss Alps ends with a reprieve for Greenland and there is talk of a post-Davos peace deal for Ukraine, maybe some believe a mix of distraction and appeasement can placate the US president. Or that midterm elections in the US will lasso Trump and tame him permanently.If only that were likely. What we know is that the breakdown of a post-second world war order is set in train â€“ letâ€™s face it, the signs have been flashing red since the 2008 financial crisis â€“ and Washingtonâ€™s next incumbent is likely to be just as belligerent when international rules constrain them.There is some recognition in the shifting tectonic plates of international financeThere is some recognition in the shifting tectonic plates of international finance, which show a separation from the White House wrecking ball is on almost everyoneâ€™s mind.The S&P 500 might say the opposite, sucking in, as it does, so much international money that its rise seems unstoppable. In other financial markets, the reverse is true.For instance, China has spent the past year reducing its US government bond holdings. In other words, it has cut the amount it lends to the US government via the bond markets. Japanese pension funds have done the same.In part their policy is driven by the fear of a stock market crash now that US share prices are at highs not seen since the dotcom bubble at the turn of the century. What is fantastic today could bring tears tomorrow, so those who lend must take a more cautious view and hedge against disaster.China and Japan are also selling up because they have trouble at home, encouraging them to repatriate or redirect their foreign investments, but that is a different, if connected, story.The ongoing leaching away of bond investors means the cost of US government borrowing has begun to rise, little by little. IfEuropewere to begin instituting a financial divorce, it too would start selling the US bonds it holds.This week a fearless and spirited pension scheme â€“ the main retirement fund for Danish academics â€“ provided a glimpse of what could be the norm.The AkademikerPension said it would sell all remaining US government bonds in its multibillion-pound fund by the end of the month. The investment director Anders Schelde made the announcement as Trump was still threatening to invade Greenland.â€œThe decision is rooted in the poor US government finances,â€ he said. â€œThus, it is not â directly related â to â€‹the ongoing rift between the US and Europe, but of course that didnâ€™t make it more â€difficult to take the decision.â€The holding is small, at $100m (Â£73m). Nevertheless, its impact as a beacon to others could be huge.European regulators could help by making it easier for other pension funds to sell their US bond holdingsEuropean regulators could help by making it easier for other pension funds to sell their US bond holdings. Some experts believe pension funds slavishly followed credit rating agency verdicts. And while most agencies downgraded the US last year, they still say it is a safe bet.It should be remembered that credit ratings agencies were at the heart of the 2008 crash. They said the financial products containing US sub-prime mortgages were safe. They werenâ€™t.If pension funds can consider US debt to be more at risk, they can reduce their holdings. There is a cost, there always is, to a reduction rather than a Danish-style clear-out, which is that the bonds remaining in any portfolio are worth less. And the more pension funds sell, the lower the value goes.But there is a gain, just as there is to the Danish, of a less risky portfolio once the number and value of US bonds is reduced.Europeans could also lend to themselves, if Brussels created a market for bonds denominated in euros. This would create a rival market to US Treasury bonds, offering an alternative safe haven that would drain the US market even further.As a proposal it dates back to a 2010 document from the Bruegel thinktank,which it recently updated. Since then the EU has corralled its disparate members to agree one-off eurobonds, most recently the borrowing that underpinned its post-Covid â‚¬385bn (Â£334bn) NextGenerationEU recovery scheme.Like previous schemes it was a one-off. As Bruegel andmore recently the Peterson Institutehave argued, there needs to be a permanent market that could begin to rival the US and others. The opportunity is ripe. Funds across the world are looking for safe havens and Europe could be one of those places.Brussels could start with a coalition of the willing rather than all 28 countries. It could reluctantly admit that much of the money would be generated by banks in London, which hosts bond markets that run deeper and wider than anything on the continent.And why would that be a problem? Politicians in Berlin, Amsterdam, Dublin and maybe even Paris want the UK to be pulled closer to the EU. If there is more money to be made, then resistance on both sides of the Channel could ebb away.And if there is a degree of insulation from Trumpâ€™s threats of financial punishment from Europeans creating their own debt market, in their own currency, then all the better.Explore more on these topicsEconomicsViewpoint columnGlobal economyDavos 2026TariffsDonald TrumpTrump tariffsEuropean UnioncommentShareReuse this content

title: Ryan Weddingâ€™s journey from Olympic snowboarder to alleged cocaine kingpin  | Drugs trade | The Guardian
description: The native of Thunder Bay, Canada, has been compared to Pablo Escobar and El Chapo â€“ but is he really as big a figure as US prosecutors have claimed?
Author: Leyland Cecco
Headline: The native of Thunder Bay, Canada, has been compared to Pablo Escobar and El Chapo â€“ but is he really as big a figure as US prosecutors have claimed?
Content: Ryan James competes at the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City.Photograph: PA Images/AlamyView image in fullscreenRyan James competes at the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City.Photograph: PA Images/AlamyDrugs tradeRyan Weddingâ€™s journey from Olympic snowboarder to alleged cocaine kingpinThe native of Thunder Bay, Canada, has been compared to Pablo Escobar and El Chapo â€“ but is he really as big a figure as US prosecutors have claimed?Leyland Ceccoin Toronto,Harriet Barberin MedellÃ­n andThomas Grahamin TijuanaSat 24 Jan 2026 05.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 09.06 ESTShareTo compete at the highest levels of snowboarding, racers must master carving, edging and balance at speeds stretching the limits of imagination. They can fluently read the nuances of snow and fine-tune their bodies to cross the finish line faster than anyone else.The Canadian snowboarder Ryan Wedding had these skills â€“ but also the quality that catapults amateurs to an elite level: a highly competitive instinct to succeed that can at times manifest in a desire to crush fellow competitors.Those traits were perhaps not as useful as he would have hoped when he competed in the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City. The course was icy, he misjudged turns and in the end, he failed to reach the podium.But the latter quality â€“ the fierce and relentless desire for success â€“ apparently served him in his rapid rise to leader of a notorious drug trafficking ring which, according to US authorities, raked in $1bn in cocaine sales each year. Wedding allegedly ordered the deaths of those standing in his way.View image in fullscreenThe FBI shows a poster with one of the FBI ten most wanted fugitives, Ryan James Wedding.Photograph: Federal Bureau of Investigation/APOn Friday,top US law enforcement officials announced Wedding had been taken into custody, capping the Canadianâ€™s arc, from prodigious young athlete to a drug boss allegedly nicknamed â€œEl Jefeâ€, â€œGiantâ€ and â€œPublic Enemyâ€. His story has unfolded like the plot of an airport bookstore thriller, with allegations of a witness murder, a corrupt lawyer and shipments of cocaine moving undetected over national borders.But while the core of the story is true, analysts suggest US authorities may have exaggerated the scale of Weddingâ€™s enterprise, creating a kingpin who has now been seized with fanfare just as the Trump administration demands the Mexican government do more against drug trafficking.By all accounts, Weddingâ€™s early years in the northern Ontario city of Thunder Bay, could not have been further from a life of flashy cars, drug cartel alliances and an international manhunt. His grandparents owned the Mount Baldy ski resort, a modest hill that laid the groundwork for the skills needed to compete as a snowboarder at world-class venues.After the disappointing result at the 2002 Olympics, the trajectory of Weddingâ€™s life shifted dramatically. A profile in Toronto Life said he worked as a bouncer at a club, and aggressively worked out at the gym to build his physique.He dabbled in flipping properties, acquired a small collection of expensive vehicles and began dressing in fashions popularized by gang members who frequented the clubs where Wedding worked.In 2006, he was named in a search warrant investigating a marijuana-growing operation in British Columbia, but was never charged. Four years later, however, Wedding was convicted of conspiracy to distribute cocaine after attempting to buy the drug from a US government agent and was sentenced to four years in prison.Incarceration meant that he missed the chance to compete for a hometown crowd when Vancouver hosted the 2010 Winter Olympics.Canadian Olympic snowboarder turned alleged cocaine kingpin in custodyRead moreBut prosecutors say he used the time to forge key relationships with drug dealers, expanding his network and developing trusted contacts that would, in years to come, give him immense reach.The scope of his alleged network was laid bare in January when Jonathan Acebedo-GarcÃ­a, a Canadian citizen, was killed at a popular restaurant in MedellÃ­n, Colombiaâ€™s second-largest city.According to CBC News, Acebedo-GarcÃ­a met Wedding in a Texas prison, and began working with him after both were released. He became a trusted ally â€“ until he began working as an FBI informant. Wedding would later call him â€œthe ratâ€ and a â€œsnitchâ€.Prosecutors say that Wedding displayed his capacity for revenge when he used a Canadian blog calledThe Dirty Newzto track down Acebedo-GarcÃ­a and his wife.Authorities allege the websiteâ€™s owner agreed to not post about Wedding. Instead, he allegedly accepted money to post a photograph of Acebedo-GarcÃ­a, which he did on 5 November 2024 with the caption: â€œThis guy single handedly ğŸ€ out one of the strongest underworld networks that this ğŸŒ has seen Good chance heâ€™ll never be found again.â€ The site Dirty Newzhas since been seizedby US authorities.Nearly three months after that post, gunmen located Acebedo-GarcÃ­a, who had been living in MedellÃ­n for a year. They followed him to the upscale neighbourhood of El Poblado.1:04Olympic snowboarder Ryan Wedding arrives in US on drug charges â€“ videoThere, at 2.30pm on 31 January, he ordered food at Mi Arepa, a popular restaurant chain specializing inthe traditional cornbreads.While he was eating, a gunman entered the establishment and shot Acebedo-GarcÃ­afivetimes in the back of the head, killing him instantly, before fleeing on a motorcycle.Wedding is believed to have sent a â€œbejewelled necklaceâ€ to one man involved in the killing, and circulated a photo of Acebedo-GarcÃ­aâ€™s body to his associates to serve as a warning for disloyalty.The brazen, daylight murder in MedellÃ­n is the latest in a string of contract killings which prosecutors have linked to Wedding. In 2023, gunmen attacked a rental home in Caledon, Ontario, believing they were targeting rival criminals who had stolen a drug shipment. Instead, they killed Jagtar Singh Sidhu, 57, and Harbhajan Kaur Sidhu, 55, who had arrived in Canada four months earlier. Their daughter Jaspreet Kaur Sidhu,was shot 13 timesand left critically injured. The next year, 39-year-old Mohammed Zafar was shot dead while sitting in his car in the driveway of his Brampton, Ontario, home over what police say were drug debts.On 5 December, Ontarioâ€™s law society suspended the licence of a lawyer who the FBI says advised Wedding to have a key witness murdered.View image in fullscreenCocaine from one of three seizures this year in the Los Angeles area from a group allegedly led by Ryan Wedding sits on a table at the FBI office in Los Angeles on 17 October 2024.Photograph: Christina House/Los Angeles Times/Getty ImagesDeepak Balwant Paradkar, a lawyer based in the Toronto suburbs, used the social media name @Cocaine_lawyer and cultivated a reputation for helping high-profile drug dealers evade charges.â€œ[Paradkar] told [Wedding], â€˜If you kill this witness, the case would be dismissed,â€™â€ said Bill Essayli, the first assistant US attorney for the central district of California. â€œThat lawyer is now in custody, and heâ€™ll be extradited and brought to justice here in the United States.â€Paradkar has been released on bail pending extradition proceedings and has said that he intends to fight the charges.For years, Wedding evaded capture by hiding inMexico, allegedly under the protection of the Sinaloa cartel. In November, the reward for information leading to his arrest was upped to $15m â€“ a bounty that put him on a level with the most powerful cartel bosses in Mexico.View image in fullscreenThe FBI director, Kash Patel, speaks about the arrest of former Ryan Wedding on multinational drug trafficking charges in Ontario, California, on Friday.Photograph: Amy Taxin/APâ€œMake no mistake about it, Ryan Wedding is the modern-day iteration of Pablo Escobar,â€ said the FBI director, Kash Patel. â€œHe is the modern-day iteration of El Chapo GuzmÃ¡n.â€But security experts in Mexico were sceptical about the comparisons of Wedding to figures like El Chapo, who co-founded and led the Sinaloa cartel, one of the worldâ€™s most powerful criminal organisations, until he was extradited to the US in 2017.â€œThereâ€™s no indication [Wedding] controls territory, nor that heâ€™s at the head of an armed militia, nor that heâ€™s a major player politically,â€ said Stephen Woodman, a security analyst in Guadalajara, Mexico.And though US authorities claim Weddingâ€™s enterprise was trafficking 60 tonnes of cocaine a year, this figure does not appear in the indictment, which only mentions specific cases of a few hundred kilos being moved at a time.â€œIâ€™d say this is a very performative [US] administration that likes to put faces on the issue of international drug trafficking,â€ said Woodman. â€œAnd you can expect films and documentaries to be made about this guy.â€Explore more on these topicsDrugs tradeUS crimeCanadaMexicoAmericasfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: â€˜Wonderfully thick, creamy and clean-tastingâ€™: the best supermarket natural yoghurts, tasted and rated | Breakfast | The Guardian
description: Which supermarket live yoghurts leave a sour note and which are naturally divine?
Author: Tom Hunt
Headline: Which supermarket live yoghurts leave a sour note and which are naturally divine?
Content: Culture club: live yoghurt contains gut-friendly bacteria.Photograph: Robert Billington/The Guardian. Food styling: Robert Billington.View image in fullscreenCulture club: live yoghurt contains gut-friendly bacteria.Photograph: Robert Billington/The Guardian. Food styling: Robert Billington.The FilterBreakfastReviewâ€˜Wonderfully thick, creamy and clean-tastingâ€™: the best supermarket natural yoghurts, tasted and ratedWhich supermarket live yoghurts leave a sour note and which are naturally divine?The best supermarket frozen fruit smoothie mixesTom HuntSat 24 Jan 2026 08.00 ESTShareThe Guardianâ€™s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.Learn more.Live natural yoghurt is the bedrock of my familyâ€™s diet. My six-year-old, for instance, gets through well over a kilo a week: for breakfast, sheâ€™ll have it with porridge, sometimes with blackstrap molasses, while most evenings sheâ€™ll have a generous bowl of yoghurt topped with frozen blueberries or mango before bed (ideally before teeth-brushing negotiations begin). To avoid excessive sugar and more processed ingredients, we never buy sweetened or flavoured yoghurt: just the plain, full-fat stuff thatâ€™s packed with beneficial bacteria.The Guardianâ€™s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.Learn more.So what is live yoghurt, and why does it matter? Live yoghurt contains active bacterial cultures, most commonly strains ofLactobacillus,BifidobacteriumandStreptococcus thermophilus. These cultures help ferment the milk, which is what gives live yoghurt its tang, texture and digestibility, and theyâ€™re one of the reasons itâ€™s linked to gut health.Clear provenance is sadly lacking in this test group, and while most of them are made from British milk, that counts little towards transparency. When I can, I choose organic as a mark of quality and because it tells a clearer story about farming, welfare and standards.The best supermarket live yoghurtBest overall:Yeo Valley Organic whole milk natural yoghurtView image in fullscreenÂ£2 for 450g at Morrisons (44p/100g)Â£2 for 450g at Sainsburyâ€™s (44p/100g)â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†Creamy yet loose-textured and beautifully pourable. Sweet-forward with a balanced acidity. Made with organic British milk and live cultures. Silky on the tongue and, for an organic option, excellent value too.Best bargain:Morrisons natural yoghurtView image in fullscreenÂ£1.10 for 500g at Morrisons (22p/100g)â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†Thick, creamy and with a well-balanced, sweet-forward flavour and gentle underlying acidity. Made with British milk and live cultures. A good-value and dependable everyday option.And the rest â€¦Duchy Organic natural Greek-style yoghurtView image in fullscreenÂ£2 for 450g at Waitrose (44p/100g)â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†Very rich, thick and creamy, with an indulgent mouthfeel. Sweet on the tongue with a fresh, lively acidity. Made with organic British milk and well worth the price.Onken set natural yoghurtView image in fullscreenÂ£1.50 for 450g at Waitrose (33p/100g)â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†Set in the pot and reminiscent of fromage frais, this is thick, creamy and clean-tasting, with less sharp acidity than many of the others here. Particularly versatile, too. Fortified with vitamin D and contains live bacterial cultures.St Helenâ€™s Farm goatâ€™s milk natural yoghurtView image in fullscreenÂ£2.40 for 450g at Sainsburyâ€™s (53p/100g)Â£2.65 for 450g at Waitrose (59p/100g)â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†Goatâ€™s milk can be easier to digest than cowâ€™s milk for some, making this very thick, extra-creamy yoghurt with a pronounced sour twang a useful alternative. Deeply satisfying, indulgent and genuinely delicious. Three-star Great Taste Award winner, too.Pakeeza live set natural yoghurtView image in fullscreenÂ£1.99 for 900g at Iceland (22p/100g)Â£2.30 for 900g at Sainsburyâ€™s (26p/100g)â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†A very thick, clean set yoghurt with proper body and structure, and complex sour notes balanced by a subtle sweetness. Made with British milk and set in the pot with live cultures.Asda natural yoghurtView image in fullscreenÂ£1.08 for 500g at Asda (22p/100g)â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†â˜†Light and clean, with a smooth, thick consistency, a classic sour edge and an underlying sweetness. The country of origin is the UK, and it contains live bacterial cultures. Simple, reliable and undeniably good value.Tesco natural yoghurtView image in fullscreenÂ£1.15 for 500g at Tesco (23p/100g)â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†â˜†Smooth and mild with a relatively neutral flavour and a looser consistency than most. Made with British milk. Very good value.Explore more on these topicsBreakfastThe FilterFoodfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Bear Grylls: â€˜Iâ€™ve bought an apocalypse-proof boat, with an array of weaponryâ€™ | Life and style | The Guardian
description: The adventurer on his familyâ€™s escape vessel, his crush on the Princess of Wales, and a disgusting toenail habit
Author: Rosanna Greenstreet
Headline: The adventurer on his familyâ€™s escape vessel, his crush on the Princess of Wales, and a disgusting toenail habit
Content: Bear Grylls: â€˜My most treasured possession? My old SAS beret.â€™Photograph: Slaven Vlasic /Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenBear Grylls: â€˜My most treasured possession? My old SAS beret.â€™Photograph: Slaven Vlasic /Getty ImagesThe Q&ALife and styleInterviewBear Grylls: â€˜Iâ€™ve bought an apocalypse-proof boat, with an array of weaponryâ€™Rosanna GreenstreetThe adventurer on his familyâ€™s escape vessel, his crush on the Princess of Wales, and a disgusting toenail habitSat 24 Jan 2026 05.00 ESTShareBorn in Northern Ireland, BearÂ Grylls, 51, served as aÂ soldier in the 21 SAS regiment and went on to star in adventure series, including seven seasons of Discovery Channelâ€™s Man vs Wild. Other shows are Running Wild WithBear Grylls, the Emmy award-winning You vs Wild, and Bafta-winning The Island With Bear Grylls. His new series, Wild Reckoning, starts on BBC One next month. He is married with three sons and lives in London, north Wales and Switzerland.What is your greatest fear?Small things make me anxious â€“ like social things â€“ but I have no big fears because I have faith in my heart.Which living person do you mostÂ admire and why?I love and admire Julia Roberts, one ofÂ our Running Wild guests, for the way she has a few close friends, is loyal to her family, doesnâ€™t believe in all the fame stuff and can laugh at herself.What is the trait you most deploreÂ inÂ yourself?Too controlling about silly things likeÂ timings or not having toxic cleaning products in the house.What is the trait you most deploreÂ inÂ others?Caring too much about whatÂ othersÂ think.What was your most embarrassingÂ moment?Holding the hand of some random ladyÂ at an airport who I mistook forÂ myÂ wife, Shara.Aside froma property, whatâ€™s the most expensive thing youâ€™vebought?An apocalypse escape vessel â€“ a steel hull ice-capable sailing boat for all the family that has almost zero electronics and is manual operation throughout â€“ armed with an array of weaponry.What is your most treasured possession?My old SAS beret that I keep on my shelf for when I need some of that â€œWho Dares Winsâ€ spirit.Clare Bailey Mosley: â€˜What single thing would improve the quality of my life? Michaelâ€™Read moreDescribe yourself in three wordsFaith-filled, never-give-up man.What would your superpower be?Recognising good and courageous hearts in unsung people.If you could bring something extinct back to life, what would you choose?My late dad.Who would play you in theÂ filmÂ ofÂ yourÂ life?Tarzan.What is your most unappealing habit?Picking my toenails and occasionally eating them.Who is your celebrity crush?Princess of Wales.What did you want to be when youÂ were growing up?A soldier and adventure guy.What is the worst thing anyoneâ€™sÂ saidÂ to you?Why is your nose so wonky?Would you choose fame or anonymity?A mix maybe.What is your guiltiest pleasure?Early night and TV in bed with Shara.What does love feel like?Light of the Almighty in my heart.Which words or phrases doÂ youÂ mostÂ overuse?Never give up.What would you like to leaveÂ yourÂ children?Resilience, courage and kindness, asÂ compassionate points to follow.What is the closest youâ€™vecomeÂ toÂ death?Where do I begin? There have beenÂ aÂ lot.What has been your closest brushÂ with the law?Police caution from the Civil Aviation Authority for illegal Base jumping.How would you like toÂ beÂ remembered?He knew where life was to be found.What is the most important lessonÂ lifeÂ has taught you?Itâ€™s all a gift. So be grateful for every day.What happens when we die?We finally get to be with Jesus,Â faceÂ toÂ face.Explore more on these topicsLife and styleThe Q&ABear GryllsfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: â€˜The invisible manâ€™: Joe Biden has disappeared in almost every way â€“ except in Trumpâ€™s daily commentary | Joe Biden | The Guardian
description: The 46th president largely exists as Trumpâ€™s foil, with his successor blaming him for the countryâ€™s woes
Author: David Smith
Headline: The 46th president largely exists as Trumpâ€™s foil, with his successor blaming him for the countryâ€™s woes
Content: Joe Biden speaks in Chicago on 31 July 2025.Photograph: Scott Olson/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenJoe Biden speaks in Chicago on 31 July 2025.Photograph: Scott Olson/Getty ImagesThe first year of Trump 2.0Joe Bidenâ€˜The invisible manâ€™: Joe Biden has disappeared in almost every way â€“ except in Trumpâ€™s daily commentaryThe 46th president largely exists as Trumpâ€™s foil, with his successor blaming him for the countryâ€™s woesDavid Smithin WashingtonSat 24 Jan 2026 08.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 08.02 ESTShareIn bitter cold beneath the US Capitol dome, he walked to a marine helicopter and shared parting words withDonald Trump. Then, arriving at Joint Base Andrews,Joe Bidenoffered farewell remarks to his loyal staff. â€œWeâ€™re leaving office,â€ he said, â€œWeâ€™re not leaving the fight.â€But, one year later, Washington, and the world, have mostly moved on from the 46th president. Biden, 83, has been writing a lucrative memoir, planning a presidential library andfighting prostate cancer. He was once the most powerful man on the planet, but now Bidenâ€™s public appearances have been scarce and his influence has palpably diminished.Chris Whipple, an author of books including The Fight of His Life: Inside Joe Bidenâ€™s White House, said: â€œHeâ€™s been the invisible man. Heâ€™s been very smart to stay under the radar because the last thing the Democratic party needs is any reminders of his final year in office, his ill-starred 11th-hour abdication and the resulting defeat of Kamala Harris.â€Former presidents have by tradition tended to keep a low profile out of respect for the office, giving their successors time and space to find their feet and make the Oval Office their own. Trump, as ever, was an outlier as he continued to lambast Biden and falsely claim the 2020 election had been stolen during his political exile.American democracy on the brink a year after Trumpâ€™s inauguration, experts sayRead moreBiden, who surprised many with the scale and ambition of his legislative agenda during the first two years of his presidency, saw his opinion poll numbers sag as he neared the end of his term. Adisastrous debate performanceagainst Trump fuelled concerns about his age and forced him to abandon his bid for re-election.A year ago this week he cut a forlorn figure sitting beside his wife, Jill, in the US Capitol Rotunda in Washington as Trumpdelivered an inaugural addressthat spelled out his determination to erase the Biden legacy.Whereas Biden had cast 6 January 2021 as a dark day for US democracy, Trump used his first day to issuesweeping pardons to more than 1,500 rioters, installed 2020 election deniers in senior posts and used state machinery to reframe the assault as an episode of patriotic protest.While Biden signed the biggest climate spending bill in history, Trump has mounted an unrestrainedassault on clean-energy initiativesand championed fossil fuels as the engine of cheaper energy and the burgeoning AI sector.Trump has rejected Bidenâ€™s faith in professionalism and expertise, dismissing thousands of career officials, imposing loyalty tests and hollowing out agencies previously insulated from political interference. He elevatedRobert F Kennedy Jrand other fringe voices to influential positions in healthcare.The president has purgeddiversity, equity and inclusion frameworksfrom government and mounted a broad offensive on universities and public bodies he blames for the Biden-era â€œwokeâ€ agenda. It comes alongside an aggressive hardening of immigration policy, both illegal and legal.And on the global stage, Trump issketching a new world orderbased on power, strength and self-interest, straining relations with allies through threats of seizing land and imposing tariffs and economic coercion. It is a far cry from Bidenâ€™s commitment to postwar structures such as Nato and support for Ukraine.In the face of such an onslaught it is Barack Obama, 64, who has been more politically active, taking part in dozens of public engagementsincluding campaign ralliesduring last Novemberâ€™s elections.Bidenâ€™s forays into public life, by contrast, have been few and far between. In May his post-presidential office announced that he had been diagnosed with prostate cancer, which had spread to his bones.In July he spoke at the Society for Human Resource Managementâ€™s convention in San Diego, California, andsaid he was receiving callsâ€œfrom a number of European leaders asking me to get engagedâ€. Biden also revealed he was â€œworking like hellâ€ to write a 500-page memoir, which hereportedly soldfor $10m to Little, Brown & Co, an imprint within Hachette.However,NBC News reportedthat Biden was struggling to raise money for a presidential library from donors who feel fatigued and let down. Obamaâ€™s presidential library is due to open in Chicago this spring.In October, Biden addressed an audience in Boston afterreceiving a lifetime achievement awardfrom the Edward M Kennedy Institute. â€œFriends, I canâ€™t sugar-coat any of this. These are dark days,â€ Biden said. He then predicted the country would â€œfind our true compass againâ€ and â€œemerge as we always have â€“ stronger, wiser and more resilient, more just, so long as we keep the faithâ€.But Democrats have shown little appetite for such interventions. Many still blame Biden for stubbornly clinging on to the 2024 presidential nomination until it was too late, giving Harris only 107 days to forge a campaign of her own. His failure to prevent Trumpâ€™s return to the Oval Office is seen asan indelible stain on his legacy.â€˜Who will stand up and oppose it?â€™: Trumpâ€™s relentless campaign of retribution in his second termRead moreFrank Luntz, a political consultant and pollster, said: â€œHe left office on a low and even Democrats feel like they were misled, so itâ€™s gonna take a while for his reputation to return. He had a good one for the first couple of years but thatâ€™s not what people remember of his presidency. They remember how he went out, not how he came in.â€Now regarded as yesterdayâ€™s news, Biden is fading more quickly from the collective consciousness than most ex-presidents. But if anyone is keeping his memory alive, it is Trump and his fellow Republicans. The 79-year-old incumbent constantly references his predecessor in speeches and at press conferences, often with insults such as â€œCrooked Joeâ€ and â€œSleepy Joeâ€.Trump installed a â€œpresidential walk of fameâ€ along the White Houseâ€™s west colonnade, featuring portraits of past presidents, replacing Bidenâ€™s portrait with an autopen image to mock his age and legitimacy. An accompanying plaque calls him â€œby far, the worst President in American Historyâ€.Luntz added: â€œIt feels like the election isnâ€™t over. It feels like itâ€™s being rerun. Itâ€™s Groundhog Day. The electionâ€™s being run again and again and again.â€The White House hasopened an investigationinto the Biden administrationâ€™s use of thepresidential autopen, which Trump has called â€œone of the biggest scandals in the history of our countryâ€. Republicans in the House of Representatives launchedinvestigationsasserting that Bidenâ€™s closest advisers covered up aphysical and mental declineduring his presidency. The Senate starteda series of hearingsfocused on his mental fitness.But political commentators are sceptical that, more than a year into Trumpâ€™s presidency, efforts to make the electorate look back in anger at the 46th president will have much purchase.Bill Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution thinktank in Washington, said:â€œBased on survey evidence, Trumpâ€™s effort to blame Biden for the current state of the economy is falling flat with the American people. By a margin of better than two to one, they say itâ€™s Trumpâ€™s economy, not Bidenâ€™s, so from that standpoint rattling on about Biden on the most important issue facing the country is manifestly not helping him.â€Explore more on these topicsJoe BidenThe first year of Trump 2.0Donald TrumpDemocratsUS politicsfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Starmer allies urge him to block Andy Burnham from running in byelection | Andy Burnham | The Guardian
description: Greater Manchester mayor has applied to stand for Labour in Gorton and Denton, setting up potential fight for PMâ€™s political future
Author: Harry Taylor
Headline: Greater Manchester mayor has applied to stand for Labour in Gorton and Denton, setting up potential fight for PMâ€™s political future
Content: Andy Burnham is considered one of the favourites to replace Keir Starmer were the prime minister to be toppled.Photograph: Phil Noble/ReutersView image in fullscreenAndy Burnham is considered one of the favourites to replace Keir Starmer were the prime minister to be toppled.Photograph: Phil Noble/ReutersAndy BurnhamStarmer allies urge him to block Andy Burnham from running in byelectionGreater Manchester mayor has applied to stand for Labour in Gorton and Denton, setting up potential fight for PMâ€™s political futureKiran Stacey,Geraldine McKelvieandHarry TaylorSat 24 Jan 2026 16.33 ESTFirst published on Sat 24 Jan 2026 12.03 ESTShareKeir Starmerâ€™s allies are urging him to block Andy Burnham from running in the Gorton and Denton byelection, after theGreater Manchestermayor declared his intention to stand, setting up a potential fight for the prime ministerâ€™s political future.Burnham said on Saturday he wanted to contest the seat after the sitting MP, Andrew Gwynne, said he intended to stand down.Burnhamâ€™s allies â€“ including ministers, MPs and trade union chiefs â€“ say that as one of the countryâ€™s most high-profile and popularLabourpoliticians, he must be allowed to fight the seat and attempt a return to parliament.But with theManchestermayor having made no secret about his leadership ambitions, those close to the prime minister were on Friday night urging him to take steps to prevent Burnham standing.â€œIf Keir doesnâ€™t make the call [to block Burnham], itâ€™s game over,â€ said one.Another added: â€œAndyâ€™s candidacy is not going anywhere. It will cost too much to fight the Manchester mayoralty and there is no guarantee we would win it.â€The fight over Labourâ€™s future crystallised on Saturday evening, when Burnham submitted his application to run in the seat alongside a letter to the partyâ€™s ruling national executive committee (NEC).He wrote in the letter: â€œI see this byelection as the frontline of that fight for the Manchester Way and I feel I owe it to a city which has given me so much to lead it from the front, despite the risks involved.â€He said he wanted to run a â€œhopeful and unifyingâ€ campaign. If selected, he would face strong challenges from Reform UK and the Green party.The NEC could meet as soon as Sunday morning to decide whether to let Burnham resign from the mayoralty and to put himself forward to the local party for selection as their candidate.While NEC members are free to cast their votes however they wish, the prime ministerâ€™s allies have a majority on the committee and are expected to vote against Burnham should those around Downing Street make it clear thatâ€™s what they want.One person with knowledge of the committeeâ€™s processes said: â€œThere are significant cost implications to having a mayoral selection and byelection, itâ€™s reasonable to expect mayors to serve their term.â€Starmer faces pressure not to block Andy Burnhamâ€™s return to parliamentRead moreThe byelection was called this week afterthe resignation of the former minister Gwynne, who announced he was standing down because of ill health. Gwynne sat as an independent after being suspended from Labour over offensive WhatsApp messages.It has long been rumoured that Burnham would mount a bid to replace Gwynne. Days before the partyâ€™s conference in Liverpool last year, Burnham told the Telegraph that Labour MPshad contacted him over the summer, asking him to stand, after becoming concerned at Starmerâ€™s growing unpopularity.Polling suggests Starmer is one of the least popular Labour prime ministers ever and Labour MPs are increasingly concerned about how his leadership will impact Mayâ€™s local elections.View image in fullscreenBurnhamâ€™s application could still be blocked by Labourâ€™s national executive committee, the partyâ€™s ruling body which is dominated by Starmer allies.Photograph: Bloomberg/Getty ImagesIn his letter, Burnham said Greater Manchester faced a â€œdirect threatâ€ to â€œeverything [it] has always been about from a brand of politics which seeks to pit people against each otherâ€, perceived as a reference to the growth of the populist right.Some polling has suggested Burnham is the only Labour candidate who could see off a challenge from Nigel Farageâ€™s party.Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, and Labourâ€™s deputy leader, Lucy Powell, both told the Fabian Societyâ€™s conference on Saturday that Burnham should be allowed to stand.Khan told the event in central London: â€œIâ€™m a firm believer in the best team having all the talent playing for them, and if Andy wants to return to parliament, I will try and make some time between now and the byelection to knock on some doors for him.â€Meanwhile Powell, who represents the neighbouring Manchester Central constituency, said the NEC should be wary of blocking Burnham from standing.She said it should be up to Burnham and party members in the constituency whether he is allowed to be the Labour candidate. She praised Burnham as â€œincredibly popularâ€ and as having changed Manchester â€œfor the betterâ€.She said: â€œIt should be up to Andy and the local members who will select their candidate, and our members are very discerning.â€Powell also acknowledged Labour could easily lose to either Reform or the Green party if the wrong candidate was selected.â€œIn that context, I always want to see the very best candidate, the person who can most help Labour win in that very difficult byelection,â€ she said. â€œI want to see the best candidates come forward and be able to come forward and help us win.â€Can Andy Burnham calm the anger in a Manchester seat Labour fears losing?Read moreHealth secretary Wes Streeting, perceived as Burnhamâ€™s biggest rival for the leadership should Starmer be deposed, refused to say whether he would support Burnhamâ€™s candidacy.â€œThis is a decision for the party, not for the cabinet,â€ he said. â€œI have been told in no uncertain terms that is my answer to the question. This is a really critical byelection. We have to work hard to earn peopleâ€™s trust and to earn every vote. We want the best possible candidate for that byelection.â€However, he added: â€œIn the last day or so, without having indicated whether he wants to run, Iâ€™ve seen some pretty unkind things said about Andy, as usual from people who donâ€™t put their names on this sort of briefing.â€œI think that is a disgraceful way to treat someone who is a Labour mayor, part of our team and part of our movement.â€Two members of the government have now said they think Burnham should be allowed to run. Energy secretary Ed Miliband, who led the party between 2010 and 2015, said: â€œI very much hope the local party will have the option of selectingAndy Burnhamas the candidate.â€Miatta Fahnbulleh, parliamentary undersecretary of state in the housing, communities and local government, said: â€œWeâ€™ve got the fight of our lives on our hands to beat Reform, which we have a moral duty to the country to do, and we need our best team on the pitch.â€œSo if he wants to put his hat in the ring and if he can persuade his members and persuade the electorate to bring him in then I think he would be an asset.â€View image in fullscreenMiatta Fahnbulleh MP speaks during the Co-operative party conference last year. She said Burnham â€˜would be an assetâ€™ if he could persuade members and the electorate to vote him in.Photograph: Jeff Moore/PAOther ministers believe it would be a mistake to allow Burnham to run.â€œI know No 10 is inept but surely they are not inept enough to allow a man to enter parliament for the sole purpose of challenging the prime minister,â€ one said.Another said that it would be a â€œbig decisionâ€ for the national executive committee, who will have to consider the prospect of a costly mayoral byelection.â€œIf he stands, it will be to go on the backbenches until the prime minister decides to give him a role,â€ one Starmer ally added.â€œThese are the facts he needs to consider. There is no vacancy for leader if that is where his ambition lies. Very few in the PLP [parliamentary Labour party] would welcome the distraction of any talk of a leadership challenge.â€Another backbench MP added: â€œWe are gearing up for crucial elections across the country. We really donâ€™t need a Burnham circus taking resources away â€“ he needs to put the party before personal ambition for a change.â€œBesides, a mayoral byelection would cost around Â£5m. It simply wouldnâ€™t be right to cut short his term in this way.â€Explore more on these topicsAndy BurnhamLabourKeir StarmerGreater ManchesterManchesterByelectionsLabour party leadershipnewsShareReuse this content

title: Donald Trump walks back comments about UK soldiers in Afghanistan | US news | The Guardian
description: After anger at claim that Nato troops â€˜stayed off frontlinesâ€™, US president says UK forces were â€˜great and very braveâ€™
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: After anger at claim that Nato troops â€˜stayed off frontlinesâ€™, US president says UK forces were â€˜great and very braveâ€™
Content: A day after accusing Nato forces of staying â€˜a little off the frontlinesâ€™ in Afghanistan, the US president said the UK military possessed â€˜tremendous heart and soulâ€™.Photograph: Evan Vucci/APView image in fullscreenA day after accusing Nato forces of staying â€˜a little off the frontlinesâ€™ in Afghanistan, the US president said the UK military possessed â€˜tremendous heart and soulâ€™.Photograph: Evan Vucci/APUS newsDonald Trump walks back comments about UK soldiers in AfghanistanAfter anger at claim that Nato troops â€˜stayed off frontlinesâ€™, US president says UK forces were â€˜great and very braveâ€™PA MediaSat 24 Jan 2026 13.14 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 17.24 ESTShareDonald Trump has said UK soldiers who fought in Afghanistan were â€œamong the greatest of all warriorsâ€ after previously drawing criticism for his claims that Nato troops stayed away from the frontlines during the conflict.In a post on social media on Saturday, the US president said: â€œThe great and very brave soldiers of the United Kingdom will always be with the United States of America.â€œInAfghanistan, 457 died, many were badly injured, and they were among the greatest of all warriors.â€˜Unfathomableâ€™: Australian veterans disgusted by Trumpâ€™s claim allied troops â€˜stayed a little backâ€™ from frontlineRead moreâ€œItâ€™s a bond too strong to ever be broken. The UK military, with tremendous heart and soul, is second to none (except for the USA). We love you all, and always will!â€The post came a day after Trump was criticised for his remarks thatNatoallied troops â€œstayed a little off the frontlinesâ€ in Afghanistan.Keir Starmer raised the comments directly with the US president in a conversation on Saturday, No 10 said.A Downing Street spokesperson said: â€œThe prime minister spoke to the president of the United States, Donald Trump, this afternoon.â€œThe prime minister raised the brave and heroic British and American soldiers who fought side by side in Afghanistan, many of whom never returned home. We must never forget their sacrifice, he said.â€œAs Ukraine approaches the fourth year of war since Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion, the leaders agreed on the need to see progress towards a sustainable ceasefire.â€œWhilst diplomatic efforts continue, the prime minister reiterated that international partners must continue to support Ukraine in its defence against [Vladimir] Putinâ€™s barbaric attacks.â€œThe leaders also discussed the need for bolstered security in the Arctic, and the prime minister said it was an absolute priority for his government.â€œThe leaders discussed the importance of the UK-US relationship, which continues to stand the test of time. They agreed to speak soon.â€Also on Saturday, Italyâ€™s prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, joined criticism of Trumpâ€™s comments on the role of non-US Nato troops in Afghanistan, defending the memory of Italian soldiers killed and wounded there.â€œThe Italian government was astonished to hear President Trumpâ€™s statement claiming that Nato allies â€˜fell behindâ€™ during operations in Afghanistan,â€ Meloni posted on X.During the nearly 20 years of Nato operations in Afghanistan, she said, â€œour nation paid a cost that is beyond dispute: 53 Italian soldiers killed and more than 700 woundedâ€.â€œFor this reason, statements that downplay the contribution of Nato countries in Afghanistan are unacceptable, especially when they come from an allied Nation,â€ she added.Meloni noted that the US had invoked article 5 of the North Atlantic treaty after the 11 September 2001 attacks on the country that killed 3,000 people, in effect launching the Afghanistan campaign.Article 5 requires Nato member states to defend any of their number who come under attack.Meloni acknowledged the strong ties between Italy and the US.â€œBut friendship requires respect, a fundamental condition for continuing to ensure the solidarity at the core of the Atlantic Alliance,â€ she added.Earlier on Saturday, Italyâ€™s foreign minister also paid tribute to Italyâ€™s dead and wounded in Afghanistan in an online post.AFP contributed to this reportExplore more on these topicsUS newsDonald TrumpNatoKeir StarmerAfghanistannewsShareReuse this content

title: Home Office to launch â€˜British FBIâ€™ to deal with serious crime UK-wide  | Police | The Guardian
description: National Police Service will investigate organised crime, terrorism, fraud and online child abuse
Author: Donna Ferguson
Headline: National Police Service will investigate organised crime, terrorism, fraud and online child abuse
Content: The home secretary, Shabana Mahmood, says creating the National Police Service will enable local forces to spend more time fighting crime in their communities.Photograph: James Manning/PAView image in fullscreenThe home secretary, Shabana Mahmood, says creating the National Police Service will enable local forces to spend more time fighting crime in their communities.Photograph: James Manning/PAPoliceHome Office to launch â€˜British FBIâ€™ to deal with serious crime UK-wideNational Police Service will investigate organised crime, terrorism, fraud and online child abuseDonna FergusonandMorgan OforiSat 24 Jan 2026 17.30 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 17.53 ESTShareThe government is setting up a NationalPoliceService â€“ dubbed the â€œBritish FBIâ€ â€“ to deal with organised crime, terrorism, fraud and online child abuse in a major change to policing in England and Wales.The new organisation, which will be announced by the Home Office in a white paper on Monday, means fraud, criminal gang and UK-wide counter terror investigations will no longer be carried out by a combination of existing agencies such as the National Crime Agency and regional organised crime units run by local police forces.The National Police Service (NPS) will instead deploy â€œworld-class talentâ€ and â€œstate-of-the-art technologyâ€ to carry out these investigations nationally, enabling local police officers to use more of their resources to crack down on less serious and complex local crimes, such as shoplifting or antisocial behaviour.Under the plans, the work of the counter-terror policing unit led by the Metropolitan police, the National Police Air Service run by West Yorkshire police and national roads policing operations will all be carried out by the new NPS, which will share technology, intelligence and resources across borders.Police Federation criticises plans for mandatory â€˜licence to practiseâ€™ for officersRead moreâ€œThe current policing model was built for a different century,â€ said the home secretary,Shabana Mahmood.â€œSome local forces lack the skills or resources they need to fight complex modern crime such as fraud, online child abuse or organised criminal gangs,â€ she added.â€œWe will create a new National Police Service â€“ dubbed â€˜the British FBIâ€™ â€“ deploying world-class talent and state-of-the-art technology to track down and catch dangerous criminals.â€œIn doing so, local forces will be able to spend more time fighting crime in their communities.â€The NPS will be run by a national police commissioner who will become the most senior police chief in the country. It will set standards and training for police forces and acquire new technology such as facial recognition cameras â€“ acontroversial movethat has provokedfierce criticismover its impact on privacy and human rights â€“ on behalf of all police forces.A joint statement from the Met, counter-terrorism policing and the National Police Chiefsâ€™ Council said: â€œModern crime requires a modern policing response. We support and have been calling for this ambitious step to bring together some of the most capable policing teams in the country into a single National Police Service.â€œThis builds on the high international regard that already exists among partners for counter-terrorism policing, whose capabilities and professionalism are recognised globally.â€œThis transformation, however, must be delivered with care. Its success depends on maintaining strong connections with local policing and the communities we serve.â€œNeighbourhood officers remain indispensable in disrupting organised crime and countering terrorism. Their relationships, insights and presence on the ground are foundational to public safety.â€œAs we implement this reform programme, protecting those vital local links will be essential to ensuring the new National Police Service strengthens â€“ not separates â€“ the bond between policing and the public.â€The NPS will be created in stages, working alongside existing agencies and regional organised crime units for the transition.Backing the plans, Neil Basu, former head of counter-terrorism policing, said NPS will be â€œfar more capable as one national security system dealing more effectively with major crime, organised crime and terrorism in all its formsâ€.Graeme Biggar, director general of the National Crime Agency, which would be merged into the new organisation, is also supporting the proposals.â€œI am proud of the brilliant work NCA officers do to protect the public from serious and organised crime and new and emerging threats,â€ he said. â€œBut the overall policing system is out of date. Crime has changed, technology has changed, and how we respond needs to change.â€œAs part of reform, we need a single, stronger national law enforcement body, building on the NCA and others, to more coherently tackle organised crime, fraud, terrorism and the new international and online threats we face.â€Biggar added: â€œThese are threats that affect us all locally, but need a national and international response. Such a body would enable us to improve how we protect the public, our communities and the country.â€Sir Mark Rowley, the head of the Metropolitan police, has also previously supported the idea of the national responsibility for counter-terrorism being removed from his force.But the plans were met with concern on the part of Graham Wettone, a policing analyst.Wettone is a former frontline operational officer of 30 yearsâ€™ experience who specialised in public order, policing protests and demonstrations.Poorly performing police forces to be named and shamed under new plansRead moreHe said: â€œHopefully they have consulted with those people actually doing the job: operational frontline officers and frontline detectives, the detectives actually going out investigating crime, police officers in uniform answering calls.â€œI donâ€™t believe they have. From what Iâ€™m hearing, it seems to me itâ€™s largely come from the Home Office, from people that have advised or guided the Home Office as to what policing needs, having never actually done the job at all â€“ possibly from police leaders who havenâ€™t actually done the job for some period of time.â€But, he added: â€œFraud investigations are complex, so probably do need a national overview. Because thereâ€™s now a huge amount of online fraud, it covers many areas of the country, so having one force managing it is very, very difficult when your offenders and your victims can be in Lancashire, Yorkshire and Devon and Cornwall.â€œSo it makes sense. It makes sense to nationalise some aspects as organised crime groups donâ€™t stick to county boundaries. They literally work across the country, and will move people across the country from force to force area.â€Explore more on these topicsPoliceShabana MahmoodPolice and crime commissionersnewsShareReuse this content

title: Storm Ingrid washes away part of Teignmouthâ€™s historic pier | UK weather | The Guardian
description: Yellow warnings for heavy rain remain in place across parts of Northern Ireland, Scotland and south-west England and Wales
Author: Morgan Ofori
Headline: Yellow warnings for heavy rain remain in place across parts of Northern Ireland, Scotland and south-west England and Wales
Content: The force of the waves stirred up by Storm Ingrid caused part of Teignmouthâ€™s Victorian pier to collapse into the sea on SaturdayPhotograph: Teignmouth Town Council/PAView image in fullscreenThe force of the waves stirred up by Storm Ingrid caused part of Teignmouthâ€™s Victorian pier to collapse into the sea on SaturdayPhotograph: Teignmouth Town Council/PAUK weatherStorm Ingrid washes away part of Teignmouthâ€™s historic pierYellow warnings for heavy rain remain in place across parts of Northern Ireland, Scotland and south-west England and WalesMorgan OforiSat 24 Jan 2026 16.13 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 17.57 ESTShareDownpours and high winds are likely to continue after Storm Ingrid wreaked havoc in the south-west and washed away part of a historic pier inDevon, the Met Office said on Saturday.It has been a wet weekend for many, with yellow weather warnings for heavy rain in place across parts of Northern Ireland, Scotland and south-west England and Wales.A yellow warning was in place for an area covering Somerset, Devon and Cornwall and much of south Wales until 10pm on Saturday, while separate warnings in Northern Ireland and Scotland will run until 9am on Sunday.â€˜Cornwall isnâ€™t resilient enoughâ€™: towns struggle with broadband outage after Storm GorettiRead moreApproximately 20-40mm of rainfall is expected across most of the south-west â€“ while some exposed locations could see up to 50mm, the forecaster said, with a risk of flooding to areas battered by rain in recent days.Storm Ingrid, as named by the Portuguese national weather service IPMA, caused chaos with powerful waves in parts of the south-west on Saturday.In the Devon coastal town of Teignmouth, part of its Victorian pier collapsed with the force of the waves.The townâ€™s mayor, Cate Williams, said that Teignmouth had seen unusually high winds and strong waves which damaged benches, flower beds and paving stones near the seafront, as well as the
