Every US citizen, the supporters, dissenters, resisters, are like: what the hellâ€™s going on?â€™Photograph: Scarlet Page/The Guardian10 Chaotic QuestionsMusicBlink-182â€™s Mark Hoppus: â€˜Bass players are just cool. Weâ€™re the one that brings it all togetherâ€™The bass player and singer on naming his chickens, selling his Banksy and surviving cancerRich PelleySat 24 Jan 2026 14.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 19.35 ESTShareYou used to keep chickens named after women fromBlink-182songs. Which was your favourite?There was Wendy, Holly, Josie â€¦ I forget the others. We lived in London, but also had a 25-acre farm out in Somerset with a Georgian farmhouse that was built in 1750. A guy from the British Beekeeping Association, who worked at the local church, would come over and help me open up my hives and harvest the honey. It was crazy how much honey we got â€“ up to 150 jars a season. It was the best honey Iâ€™ve ever tasted.View image in fullscreenMark Hoppus with Banksyâ€™s â€˜Crude Oil (Vettriano)â€™ at Sothebyâ€™s in London in March 2025, where it was auctioned for Â£4.3m.Photograph: Tristan Fewings/Getty Images for Sothebyâ€™sDid you really have to sell your Banksy because you were worried someone might steal it?It was more that we worried it would get damaged. People would come over, lean in way too close with a glass of red wine and say: â€œIs that really a Banksy?â€ The more money it was worth, the more precious we got with it. Eventually, it was so much stress, we sold it and gave some of the money to charity. My charity is haematology oncology research. My wife volunteers at Childrenâ€™s Hospital Los Angeles. It was right after the fires in LA, so we wanted to donate to the Firefighters Association. I also wanted to take some of the money and invest in new up-and-coming artists.Are you surprised youâ€™re not dead?I amverysurprised Iâ€™m not dead.When I was diagnosed, my doctor said the good news was there was only one treatment for the type of cancer, so I didnâ€™t have to agonise over whether to choose radiation or surgery or try an experimental drug. The only treatment was R-CHOP chemotherapy, but it was still the worst chemotherapy you can undergo, and my doctor said: â€œYou only have a 60% chance of living through this and never having to deal with it again.â€ Chemotherapy feels like youâ€™re being crushed. They give you a massive dose of steroids â€“ the same steroids they give me when I lose my voice on tour â€“ but instead of one or two pills, I was on a packet a day, which would send me hyper-crazy. Then, when they give you the actual drugs, you can feel them burning the cancer cells out of your body, like youâ€™re on fire from the inside.â€˜I thought I was going to die â€“ and it was so freeingâ€™: Blink-182â€™s Mark Hoppus on stardom, breakups and surviving cancerRead moreDo you believe in UFOs as much as yourBlink-182 bandmate Tom Delonge?Ever since I met Tom, when weâ€™d be touring in a van and we were taking turns driving, Tom would sit up all night looking at the skies, just hoping to see a UFO. When the internet was invented, it was like it opened his door to all the cons, conspiracies and theories. I donâ€™t presume that the only life in the universe is here on this one little planet out in the middle of nowhere. Iâ€™ve heard that weâ€™ve never gone to the moon and it was a hoax perpetuated at a sound stage in Burbank. Iâ€™ve also heard that the reason that Kennedy was assassinated was because when we went to the moon, the astronauts saw a secret glass structure on the dark side of the moon that Kennedy was going to expose to the world. But both ideas sound a bit crazy.View image in fullscreenMark Hoppus performs during the Blink-182 tour at the Hollywood Palladium on 10 October 2009.Photograph: Christopher Polk/Getty Images for T-MobileWhatâ€™s the weirdest WhatsApp group youâ€™re in?Probably just one with a bunch of other musicians, creators and business owners, where we talk about the world.What were you like at school?I grew up in a military base in the middle of the desert because my dad was a rocket scientist and worked for the navy. There was nothing to do and I felt kind of alone. Then my parents got divorced, and I feltreallyalone. I didnâ€™tfeel myself until I got into skateboarding when I was 13. That was the first time I felt like I found my people and my community. All the outsiders, all the losers and all the unpopular people were welcomed into the skateboarding community. At first, I got into alternative goth music. I was a big fan of the Cure and would dress up as Robert Smith and walk into school in all black, with my hair all up, black eyeliner and red lipstick, which wasnâ€™t really the look for the middle of the desert. But I felt like that was who I wanted to be. I felt like I needed to plant my flag and say: â€œIâ€™m not like the rest of you guys.â€Urthboy AKA Tim Levinson: â€˜My most chaotic gig? Thereâ€™s a lot where itâ€™s pretty good knowing we didnâ€™t dieâ€™Read moreWhen did you last cry?On stage, which was embarrassing, because it was in front of a lot of people.Who are your top three other bass players?Peter Hook from New Order. Simon Gallup from the Cure. And the two bass players from Nedâ€™s Atomic Dustbin, who are the best, because they had two bass players. Bass players are just cool. Bass players are the glue â€“ weâ€™re the one that brings it all together. Weâ€™re the bridge between the rhythm of the drums and the melody of the guitar and the vocal.What do you think about the state of the US right now?I think the whole world feels confused by whatâ€™s going on in the US right now. Every US citizen, the supporters, dissenters, resisters, are like: what the hellâ€™s going on? You try to read to get to the actual facts, but everything is clickbait now. Itâ€™s all headlines that are meant to enrage you. We were sitting next to an English couple at breakfast the other morning and struck up a conversation and the first thing they asked is: â€œWhat do you guys think of Trump?â€ Being here in England, I havenâ€™t really noticed anti-American sentiment or anything with our accents.Is that story about Oasis true?Yes. Blink was kind of just starting out when Oasis were first big. We got a chance to meet them when we were on the same bill. Liam came into our dressing room and said: â€œAre you guys Blink-182? Youâ€™re the best Iâ€™ve seen in America.â€ Tom said: â€œOh, thatâ€™s awesome. You like our band?â€ and Liam said: â€œNo, I didnâ€™t say I like your music. I just think you guys are cool.â€Fahrenheit-182: A Memoir by Mark Hoppus is out now. He is speaking at Melbourne Recital Hall on 19 March and Sydney Opera House on 21 MarchExplore more on these topicsMusic10 Chaotic QuestionsBlink-182Pop and rockfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: â€˜Itâ€™s such a complex little areaâ€™: how to really look after your wrists | Life and style | The Guardian
description: The structure of wrists mean we have the capacity to do both handstands and neurosurgery. A lot can go wrong
Author: Bianca Nogrady
Headline: The structure of wrists mean we have the capacity to do both handstands and neurosurgery. A lot can go wrong
Content: Wrists are a complex area of the body. How to look after them and prevent conditions such as carpal tunnelComposite: Guardian DesignView image in fullscreenWrists are a complex area of the body. How to look after them and prevent conditions such as carpal tunnelComposite: Guardian DesignThe way you moveLife and styleâ€˜Itâ€™s such a complex little areaâ€™: how to really look after your wristsThe structure of wrists mean we have the capacity to do both handstands and neurosurgery. A lot can go wrongRead more summer essentialsBianca NogradySat 24 Jan 2026 14.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 19.21 ESTShareItâ€™s a bad time of year for wrists. Parents â€“ and sometimes grandparents â€“ full of enthusiasm and holiday cheer hop on their childâ€™s new scooter or bike, keen to show said child how great the new toy is, and forget that gravity isnâ€™t as kind to the body when weâ€™re older. Falls happen, and wrists often take the brunt.â€œItâ€™s got its own name: â€˜fall on an outstretched handâ€™,â€ saysBrigette Evans, an occupational therapist at Bathurst Hand Therapy. As we fall, our instinct is to put our arms out in front of us to protect our body, face and head, and the wrist takes a lot of that force.Understand the complexity of wristsâ€œThe wrist is such a complex little area,â€ Evans says, as they have evolved to allow an extraordinary range of movement while also supporting a high level of fine motor control â€“ the wrists mean we have the capacity to do both handstands and neurosurgery.â€˜Do not ignore your bodyâ€™s signalsâ€™: how to really look after your neckRead moreâ€œItâ€™s got eight little carpal bones â€“ theyâ€™re the axis of the wrist â€“ and then youâ€™ve got your radius and your ulna, which are your two forearm bones, and then that joins in with your hand bones, your metacarpals,â€ Evans says. And all those smaller and larger bones are held together by ligaments, and interwoven throughout the whole complex are the tendons that connect the muscles of the hand and arm with the bones of the hand, wrist and arm. There is a lot that can go wrong.Repetitive movements are the enemyOne common wrist condition that therapists see a lot of is calledDe Quervain tenosynovitis, which is sometimes called â€œmotherâ€™s thumbâ€, says physiotherapistNicola Wheelerfrom Bondi Junction Hand Therapy. â€œItâ€™s common in new parents, new grandparents, because of this position in lifting up under the arm, as well as feeding postures,â€ Wheeler says.That new repetitive movement or position-holding is inevitable with a new baby â€“ although itâ€™s also seen with lots of scrolling or computer use â€“ and it can irritate and inflame the two tendons that connect the arm muscles to the bones of the thumb. â€œOnce theyâ€™re inflamed and thick, as theyâ€™re gliding through a tunnel, they get caught, lots of friction, and then that can be a cycle of that friction causing more inflammation,â€ Wheeler says.The solution is to modify your movement to reduce the load on those tendons, using different lifting techniques â€“ which Evans says are now taught by midwives and nurses to new parents and propping the baby up on pillows while feeding so the wrist doesnâ€™t hold the entire weight at an unusual angle.Donâ€™t lift from the wristBecause the wrist is a relatively delicate instrument, keeping it healthy is less about making it stronger and more about using it carefully, Wheeler says. â€œIn a lot of situations, weâ€™re trying to minimise wrist movement and actually train people to keep it very straight and stable, particularly when itâ€™s with load,â€ she says.That means not lifting from the wrist, but rather keep the wrist stable and instead using the larger load-bearing joints and muscles like the arm and shoulder. Wheeler likens it to the advice about lifting safely to avoid back injury: â€œInstead of that quick grab, really you should be setting ourselves using our muscles, and then using all these arm muscles to do the lifting.â€Limber upAnother common wrist complaint that most have heard of iscarpal tunnel syndrome, which presents as tingling, numbness or weakness in the thumb and first two fingers. Itâ€™s caused by the median nerve, which extends from the neck to the hand, getting compressed as it passes through a passage in the wrist called the carpal tunnel. That compression can happen if the wrist is bent forward for a long time, like if we sleep with our hand tucked around against ourselves.â€œIf itâ€™s been like that all night, then itâ€™s common either to wake up through the night or in the morning with numbness and tingling,â€ Wheeler says. But it can also happen with poor position during computer use, or resting the wrist on a desk or hard surface for a long period of time.So itâ€™s also important to keep the wrist limber by breaking up periods of computer work with little stretches and rotations, Evans says. â€œJust getting up and moving your wrists in all the different directions that they that comfortably go in, and not holding them in a prolonged position.â€ For a stiff wrist in the morning, a gentle heat pack can go a long way to easing things up.And stay off the kidâ€™s scooter.Explore more on these topicsLife and styleThe way you moveHealth & wellbeingFitnessAustralian lifestylenewsShareReuse this content

title: â€˜I feel like Iâ€™ll never be cold againâ€™: How tennis stars coped with Melbourne heat | Australian Open 2026 | The Guardian
description: Extreme heat wreaked havoc on Saturdayâ€™s Australian Open schedule but tennis has changed its ways of dealing with the sun
Author: Tumaini Carayol
Headline: Extreme heat wreaked havoc on Saturdayâ€™s Australian Open schedule but tennis has changed its ways of dealing with the sun
Content: Jessica Pegula places a bag of ice around her head during a break in play against Oksana Selekhmeteva.Photograph: Aaron Favila/APView image in fullscreenJessica Pegula places a bag of ice around her head during a break in play against Oksana Selekhmeteva.Photograph: Aaron Favila/APAustralian Open 2026Analysisâ€˜I feel like Iâ€™ll never be cold againâ€™: How tennis stars coped with Melbourne heatTumaini Carayolat Melbourne ParkExtreme heat wreaked havoc on Australian Open schedule but tennis has changed its ways of dealing with the sunSat 24 Jan 2026 13.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 19.23 ESTShareEven before the first set and first hour of his match elapsed, Tomas Machac had asked the umpire for the tournament doctor, trainer and pickle juice, the drink du jour for tackling cramps. Those preventive measures taken in the intense early stages of his third-round tussle with Lorenzo Musetti proved to be sensible, for the pair would spend a brutal four hours, 25 minutes on court.Four hours of that took place inside an open John Cain Arena, a furnace in suffocating heat. â€œWe knew today was going to be really, really hot,â€ Musetti said. â€œI think I managed well to finish the match without cramping.â€Maddison Inglis has it easy as clique of champions struggle in Melbourne heatRead moreThose early stages of Musettiâ€™s five-set win over Machac set the tone for an unusual day at the Australian Open asthe heat arrived in force, inserting itself into the outcome of matches and wreaking havoc on the schedule. A cursory glimpse around the grounds on Saturday underscored what was to come. Anticipation of the heat convinced the organisers to start play half an hour earlier than usual at 10.30am.The first sight was St John Ambulance workers standing around. Stations offering free SPF50+ sunscreen were dotted across the grounds. From the start of play, long lines of spectators waited by the many water dispensers to refill their bottles.TheAustralian Openwas well prepared for 39C, but the most pertinent question was which players would not be so ready. Jessica Pegula, who reported for the morning shift, beat the worst of the heat by reaching the fourth round with an easy 6-3, 6-2 win over Oksana Selekhmeteva.She stressed the importance of using ice towels and hydration. â€œThe fact we havenâ€™t been playing that much in the hot temperatures is what gets people. You have no tolerance to it and then it comes out of nowhere. Weâ€™re used to it happening here, but itâ€™s hard to prepare for that.â€View image in fullscreenKaren Khachanov wraps an ice towel around his neck during a break against Luciano Darderi.Photograph: Dar Yasin/APThat preparation begins overnight with increased hydration and electrolytes. Higher temperatures also mean faster playing conditions since the balls fly more quickly through warmer air. Players also have the option of making changes to their equipment.Madison Keys notes the importance of stringing rackets at a higher tension to counteract the ball flying. â€œI typically go up in my tension a little bit,â€ she said. â€œNot today. Only went up a pound, because I was playing earlier. Depending on what the weather changes would be like, thereâ€™s been times where Iâ€™ve gone up even three, four pounds.â€Heat is a common subject in tennis, a sport that chases the sun around the world. Last month,after numerous heat-related retirementsat the Shanghai Masters, the ATP announced its own heat rules, ending years of debate over whether the tour should prioritise the welfare of its players or continue to enable antiquated attitudes. There are still some who view the sport as a gladiatorial pursuit where athletes should be able to handle all conditions, regardless of how dangerous they are.In the media centre, one of the screens showing the matches, statistics and practice court schedules changed to display the Australian Open Heat Stress Scale, the tournamentâ€™s extreme heat protocol. The chart measures heat stress on a scale of 1 to 5, with 1 signifying â€œtemperate playing conditionsâ€ and 5 leading to the immediate suspension of play on outdoor courts. By 2pm the temperature had reached 34C and the chart had risen to 4, which mandated extended breaks between sets.The scale shifted to 5 at the most significant moment of the day. Jannik Sinner, the defending champion, had been struggling with the conditions on Rod Laver Arena since the early stages of his match against Eliot Spizzirri and by the third set No 2 seed was in deep trouble.Sinner began to suffer from full body cramps, limping badly between points and unable to run properly. At one point, he hobbled to the side of the court and offered his blunt assessment of his chances to his team: â€œI donâ€™t know what to do. Iâ€™m fucked.â€At the exact moment Sinner lost his serve to trail Spizzirri 1-3 in the third set, the Australian Open Heat Stress Scale reached 5. The roof was immediately closed on Rod Laver Arena and Sinner recovered his strength to win.As Margaret Court Arena and John Cain Arena followed suit, play was suspended on the remaining courts. Spizzirri could not help but smile as he was informed of the move: â€œIt was just funny that right when I broke and he was wobbling it happened to happen that way,â€ he said.Sinnerrecognised his good fortune: â€œGot lucky today,â€ he said. â€œAt the point when they closed the roof, it takes a little bit time. Tried to loosen up a little bit. It helped.â€View image in fullscreenCasper Ruud pours water over his head during his third round match against Marin Cilic.Photograph: Aaron Favila/APSinnerâ€™s lack of durability in the heat remains one of his few weaknesses. Others, however, almost enjoy the extreme conditions. Many of the 14 Americans in the third round are used to training in Floridaâ€™s heat and humidity. They respond to heat-related questions with a shrug.Even as Spizzirri competed in one of the biggest matches of his career, he viewed the heat as an opportunity: â€œWhen I saw how hot it was, I was not disappointed or not, like, â€˜this is unlucky I have to play on this day.â€™ I tried to relish that and look at it more as an opportunity to showcase my physicality and see if I could outlast him,â€ he said.The absence of play left the grounds in an interesting state. Thousands of spectators congregated in the air-conditioned hallways inside Rod Laver Arena, while others chose to sit in the shaded areas of Kia Arena, which showed matches from the top courts on its big screen. One of the many weather-related conversations included the comment: â€œI just feel like Iâ€™m never going to be cold again.â€The player balcony, which overlooks the grounds, is usually a popular space for players, coaches, agents and families to relax. For once, it was empty, with players escaping to the air-conditioned surrounds of the their lounge underneath the stadium.Around 7pm, 90 minutes later than initially anticipated, the heat stress reading fell to 4.7. Play swiftly restarted on the outside courts and normal service resumed. The three roofs meant there was minimal disruption to the singles.On Tuesday, when the temperature here is forecast to be 41C, similar scenes will unfold. Those in the other half of the draws will be charged with enduring the full force of the Melbourne summer.Explore more on these topicsAustralian Open 2026Australian OpenAustralia sportTennisanalysisShareReuse this content

title: I Want Your Sex review â€“ vampy Olivia Wilde almost saves Gregg Arakiâ€™s tame dom-sub romp | Sundance 2026 | The Guardian
description: As a provocative artist using sex to wield power, the actor is electric but the writer-directorâ€™s return to his campy, dayglo roots is largely underwhelming
Author: Benjamin Lee
Headline: As a provocative artist using sex to wield power, the actor is electric but the writer-directorâ€™s return to his campy, dayglo roots is largely underwhelming
Content: Cooper Hoffman and Olivia Wilde in I Want Your Sex.Photograph: Lacey TerrellView image in fullscreenCooper Hoffman and Olivia Wilde in I Want Your Sex.Photograph: Lacey TerrellFirst look reviewSundance 2026ReviewI Want Your Sex review â€“ vampy Olivia Wilde almost saves Gregg Arakiâ€™s tame dom-sub rompSundance film festival:As a provocative artist using sex to wield power, the actor is electric but the writer-directorâ€™s return to his campy, dayglo roots is largely underwhelmingBenjamin Leein Park CitySat 24 Jan 2026 11.15 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 19.05 ESTShareWhile Sundance is traditionally focused on the importance of looking to the future of American film, a lineup filled with more first-timers than any other major festival, this year has been all about looking back. There are misty eyes over the loss of founder Robert Redford along with host state Utah and also for the many films that have premiered here over the years. Alongside more retrospective screenings than one usually expects, even the new films have a touch of old Sundance to them.Extra Geography review â€“ a sweet and spiky coming-of-age debutRead moreOn opening day, Rachel Lambertâ€™s small-town dramaCarouselconjured up memories of quiet character-driven indies of the late 90s and early 00s and then, on a Friday full of packed-out premieres, I Want Your Sex took us back to the eraâ€™s more in-your-face acts of provocation, made by renegade outsiders who would have otherwise struggled to find a place in the industry. Itâ€™s the new film from Gregg Araki, a film-maker who was at the forefront of this particular wave, one of Sundanceâ€™s most loved enfants terribles. Heâ€™s premiered most of his films here, from â€œheterosexual movieâ€ The Doom Generation to magnum opus Mysterious Skin to all-time stoner comedy Smiley Face to 2014â€™s misbegotten drama White Bird in a Blizzard, his last film until now.Introducing his much-anticipated return to the audience, and briefly detailing the decade itâ€™s taken to make it, Araki was as excitable as one would hope the director of a film called I Want Your Sex to be, a film dubbed a â€œreturn to formâ€ by the pre-introduction introduction. Itâ€™s certainly a return to what many know him for â€“ vibrant colours, unfettered sex, madcap plotting â€“ but itâ€™s also missing that same sense of infectiously boisterous energy. The parts are here but thereâ€™s nothing to truly animate them, just the vague hope that maybe nostalgia might be enough.For a while it almost is. Araki hasnâ€™t taken us to this fun, kitschy territory since 2010â€™s scrappy college cult caper Kaboom, and as we watch Cooper Hoffman and a mincing Mason Gooding help create a vagina made of chewed up gum, itâ€™s hard not to feel excited for what someone like Araki might have to say about this current moment. Before we realise that the answer is â€œnot that muchâ€, our hopes are lifted by the electric presence ofOlivia Wilde, an often misused or misunderstood actor whom Araki has compared to an â€œold-time starâ€ like Ingrid Bergman or Greta Garbo. While it might be hard to imagine either woman lubing a dildo to place up her assistantâ€™s ass, there is a magnetically old school femme fatale pull to how she plays provocative artist Erika Tracy, every eye immediately drawn to her whenever she enters a room.One of her many admirers is new assistant Elliot (Hoffman), a sexually inexperienced rube she can easily sniff out and one she quickly takes under her wing, a student to be taught. He becomes her sub, a toy to be blindfolded, pegged and spanked whenever she pleases, a thrilling new world for him, stuck with a bored, sexless girlfriend (Charli xcx, a little flat). Araki, who wisely gender-swapped the pair after #MeToo, uses their different ages and sexual histories to comment on an ongoing tussle based on widely believed stereotypes about horny millennials and prudish gen Z-ers, laid out quite obviously in an early discussion between the pair (Erika bemoans the â€œretro sex negativityâ€ of Elliottâ€™s generation). Erika is also exhausted by political correctness, rolling her eyes at the â€œwoke policeâ€ and gets a kick out of degrading a younger man to remind him of his base impulses.But even though Araki delivers his didactic thesis upfront, he doesnâ€™t really have much more to add or really expand upon. The sexual relationship between the pair is surprisingly tame even if they both bare almost everything, played-for-laughs scenes involving dildos, handcuffs and ball gags doing very little to raise an eyebrow (maybe Araki is once again poking fun at a straight idea of perversion). It goes from kinky to conventional too soon and while Wilde is more than game and acutely aware of exactly the right tone for an Araki romp (Gooding, playing gay and slutty ever so believably, is also on the same page), Hoffman is seriously miscast, acting as if he were in a different, far less heightened movie (it plays more like heâ€™s auditioning for a Woody Allen comedy). The pair have no form of chemistry, sexual or comedic, and while we might see them in many, many semi-naked situations, it remains hard to actually believe that any sex is being had and that anyone is getting any enjoyment out of it.Itâ€™s a film thatâ€™s ultimately more suggestively cheeky than actually raunchy and while Araki choosing to position sex as harmless and silly at a time when it might be demonised by some is certainly admirable, shouldnâ€™t we be having a little bit more fun with it? Itâ€™s a 90-minute romp that feels longer than that, with increasingly unexciting hijinks (a threesome that fizzles, a murder plot that flames out, more dildos) that are never as amusing or as propulsive as they should be. I Want Your Sex wants our shock, our arousal and our debate but it barely gets our attention.I Want Your Sex is screening at theSundance film festivaland is seeking distributionExplore more on these topicsSundance 2026First look reviewGregg ArakiOlivia WildeComedy filmsSundance film festivalComedyFestivalsreviewsShareReuse this content

title: Six great reads: spuds in vogue, Finlandâ€™s biggest crime and a month living in analogue | Life and style | The Guardian
description: Need something brilliant to read this weekend? Here are six of our favourite pieces from the last seven days
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Need something brilliant to read this weekend? Here are six of our favourite pieces from the last seven days
Content: Composite: Guardian Design / Cathy Britcliffe/Getty Images / Gianna DorseyView image in fullscreenComposite: Guardian Design / Cathy Britcliffe/Getty Images / Gianna DorseySix great readsLife and styleSix great reads: spuds in vogue, Finlandâ€™s biggest crime and a month living in analogueNeed something brilliant to read this weekend? Here are six of our favourite pieces from the last seven daysSat 24 Jan 2026 01.00 ESTShare1.â€˜We want to make jacket potatoes sexy again!â€™: how the humble spud became a fast food sensationView image in fullscreenThe fad for jacket potatoes.Composite: Guardian Design;  Cathy Britcliffe/Getty ImagesOne of the UKâ€™s most unlikely fast food trends of the past few years has been an influencer-led rise in appetite for baked potatoes, one of Britainâ€™s original street foods. Sammy Gecsoyler met the spudfluencers spreading the starchy gospel.Read more2.Out of the ruins: will Aleppo ever be rebuilt?View image in fullscreenBombed-out buildings in the Old City of Aleppo.Photograph: Ghaith Abdul Ahad/The Guardianâ€œFor 5,000 years,â€ wrote Ghaith Abdul-Ahad, â€œAleppo has been a great metropolis at the heart of a region that stretches from the shores of the Mediterranean, across the fertile lands of what is now southern Turkey, and all the way to Mosul in modern-day Iraq. Throughout the centuries, Aleppo prospered as a trade hub and manufacturing centre. It endured its share of invasions, plagues, civil strife and natural disasters, yet somehow managed to preserve a distinctive character evident.â€After the Syrian civil war, nearly two-thirds of the city is in ruins. The destruction is so vast that it will take years just to clear the rubble, let alone start rebuilding. Can Aleppo return to the city it was before the war?Read more3.â€˜Iâ€™d come back to the UK â€“ but Iâ€™m not playing a copâ€™: Oscar nominee Wunmi Mosaku on sensational vampire smash SinnersView image in fullscreenMosaku.Photograph: Gianna DorseyThe actor grew up on a Manchester council estate. Now sheâ€™s gone stratospheric for her pivotal role in Sinners â€“ and this week she was nominated for an Oscar. Before that, the star talked to Lanre Bakare about leaving Britain for LA â€“ and the Â£30 bus trip that changed her life.Read more4.He called himself an â€˜untouchable hacker godâ€™. But who was behind the biggest crime Finland has ever known?View image in fullscreenAleksanteri KivimÃ¤ki.Photograph: Juuso Westerlundâ€œAt 2am on 23 October 2020 â€“ the day before the emails began to arrive in tens of thousands of inboxes â€“ ransom_man had uploaded a much larger file. It contained every record of every single patient on the database. Everyoneâ€™s therapy notes had already been published, for free, for everyone in the world to see.â€Who was behind the biggest crime Finland had ever known? And might they have been motivated by something other than money? Jenny Kleeman spent 18 months trying to find out. The story culminated in one of the most chilling conversations she had ever had.Read more5.â€˜Exclusively for the eliteâ€™: why Mumbaiâ€™s new motorway is a symbol of the divide between rich and poorView image in fullscreenThe coastal road project.Photograph: Nirmal G/The GuardianThe Indian city is known for its graphic inequality â€“ it is home to 90 of Indiaâ€™s billionaires, but also to more than six million slum dwellers. Now a city where most people squeeze on to buses and trains has a new symbol of the gulf between rich and poor: a high-speed, eight-lane motorway on its western coast, which critics say serves only the wealthy despite being built with taxpayersâ€™ money. Amrit Dhillon examined a road that â€œrepresents a massive transfer of wealth to the rich and imposes costs on the restâ€.Read more6.My analogue month: would ditching my smartphone make me healthier, happier â€“ or more stressed?View image in fullscreenEmma Russell.Photograph: David Levene/The Guardianâ€œIs it possible, asked Emma Russell, â€œto live lo-fi in a hi-tech world?â€ For a month, she tried: swapping her iPhone for a Nokia, picking up physical copies of books, newspapers and magazines; and using a London A-Z for directions.Read moreExplore more on these topicsLife and styleSix great readsnewsShareReuse this content

Content: Team talk â€¦ Steve Coogan (centre) as Mick McCarthy in Saipan.Photograph: Aidan Monaghan Photographer/Aidan MonaghanView image in fullscreenTeam talk â€¦ Steve Coogan (centre) as Mick McCarthy in Saipan.Photograph: Aidan Monaghan Photographer/Aidan MonaghanGoing out, staying inCultureFrom Saipan to Take That: your complete entertainment guide to the week aheadSteve Coogan stars in a loose retelling of an infamous football falling-out, while a new Netflix doc gets nostalgic about the heyday of Gary Barlow and coSat 24 Jan 2026 01.00 ESTShareContents1Going out: Cinema2Going out: Gigs3Going out: Art4Going out: Stage5Staying in: Streaming6Staying in: Games7Staying in: Albums8Staying in: Brain foodView image in fullscreenGoing out:CinemaSaipanOut nowAs the Irish national team descend on a small island in the Pacific to prepare for the 2002 World Cup, an epic falling out between manager Mick McCarthy (Steve Coogan) and top player Roy Keane (Ã‰anna Hardwicke) is looming, in this sports drama loosely based on the infamous real-life spat.No Other ChoiceOut nowKorean auteur Park Chan-wook (Oldboy) enlists Squid Gameâ€™s Lee Byung-hun to lead this dark comedy about a man who has recently been made redundant but is so committed to reclaiming his role that he feels he has â€œno other choiceâ€ but to resort to murder.H Is for HawkOut nowBased on the novel by Helen Macdonald, this drama sees Claire FoyÂ play a woman mourning the loss of her father become on the idea of training a hawk. This project isnâ€™t necessarily a natural fitÂ with her life asÂ a graduate fellow atÂ Cambridge. Directed by Philippa Lowthorpe and also starring Brendan Gleeson and Lindsay Duncan.The History of SoundOut nowPaul Mescal (Hamnet) plays a talentedÂ singer and Josh Oâ€™Connor (The Mastermind) a committed musicologist who become lovers in thisÂ early 20th century-set romantic drama from Oliver Hermanus (Living). Prone to futuristic world-building, andÂ with the promise of various special guests, itâ€™s likely to be a visual and sonic onslaught anchored by Diamondâ€™s experimental pop nous.MCEarth and Other Planets: Britten Sinfonia with Stevens & Pound andÂ Robert MacfarlaneMilton Court,London,28 January;Norfolk Events Centre,Norwich,29 January;West Road Concert Hall,Cambridge,30 JanuaryFolk duo Delia Stevens and Will Pound collaborate with the Britten Sinfonia and Macfarlane to reimagine Holstâ€™s The Planets in a version of the orchestral suite that includes their newly written Earth. The folk-themed concert will also feature Brittenâ€™s rarely heard Suite on English Folk Tunes: A Time There Was, which he dedicated to the memory of Percy Grainger, alongside Graingerâ€™s own Lincolnshire Posy, based on songs he collected more than a century ago.Imogen TildenMarsalis Trumpet Concerto/Brighton Philharmonic OrchestraBrighton Dome Concert Hall,24 JanuaryThe Brighton Philharmonic Orchestra under Joanna MacGregorâ€™s baton performs the blues, swing, Latin and contemporary-classical kaleidoscope of Wynton Marsalisâ€™s panoramic 2023 Trumpet Concerto with exciting young Nigerian-Scottish trumpet virtuoso Aaron Azunda Akugbo, on an eclectic programme also featuring music from Michael Nymanâ€™s The Draughtmanâ€™s Contract, jazzy variations on Henry Purcell.John FordhamGoing out:ArtView image in fullscreenNo Title, Andy Warhol, 1967. Tate.Photograph: Seraphina Neville & Jai Monaghan/The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts/DACS/TateAndy WarholLakeside Arts, Nottingham,24 JanuarytoÂ 19 AprilAs the US changes, does our understanding of this most American artist also change? Arguably we are still catching up with Andy. His cold analysis of a future dominated by cheap celebrity that disguises a monotonous sameness has never looked more plausible. He never saidÂ itÂ would be a utopia.Julia PhillipsBarbican Centre: The Curve, London,30 Januaryto 19 AprilThis Germany-born artist is a sculptor of acutely modern unease. Casts of her own body, strangely rendered in shiny ceramic, are juxtaposed with steel frames, sharp tools and other pieces ofÂ technology. Her jarring collisions ofÂ flesh and metal suggest the new machine age, in the spirit of Berlin dada.Georg BaselitzCristea Roberts Gallery, London, toÂ 28Â FebruaryThe veteran painter and sculptor â€“ who has spent a life expressing the human condition, from scabrous â€œdegenerateâ€ early works to upside-down pictures and historical provocations â€“ is having a brilliant, honest old age. He marks his 88th birthday in typically defiant and dangerous style with depictions ofÂ the German eagle.Caroline WalkerPallant House Gallery, Chichester, toÂ 26 AprilRealist, on the surface almost placid, paintings that explore the experience of motherhood. A mother sits with herÂ children in one scene, and we wonder what her thoughts and feelings are in this stilled moment ofÂ everyday life. Another painting looks from the outside, at a child in aÂ room.Jonathan JonesGoing out:StageView image in fullscreenLee Duveneck, Kenny Corrigan, Alex Clayton and Shawn Lesniak of Paul Taylor Dance Company.Photograph: Whitney BrownePaul Taylor Dance CompanyRoyal Ballet & Opera: LinburyTheatre, London,27to 31 JanuaryPaul Taylor was one of the most important, and popular, figures in American modern dance, from the 1950s onwards. The company hasnâ€™t been to the UK for two decades (Taylor died in 2018) so this is a long-overdue visit, with two programmes featuring Taylor classics and new works.Lyndsey WinshipRosalie Minnitt: ClementineTheatr Clwyd, Mold,24 January; touringto 7 JuneSince debuting in 2022, Minnittâ€™s one-woman Regency heroine spoof has gradually blossomed into a word-of-mouth hit. Combining period drama parody with knowing anachronism, Clementine draws clever parallels between its protagonistâ€™s eye-wateringly desperate search for a husband and the nightmare of modern dating.Rachel AroestiArcadiaOld Vic theatre, London,24 Januaryto 21 MarchThe late Tom Stoppardâ€™s dazzling classic â€“ a century-hopping swirl of intellect and romance â€“ is staged at the Old Vic for the first time. Directed by Carrie Cracknell and starring Seamus Dillane, Leila Farzad, Angus Cooper and Prasanna Puwanarajah.Miriam GillinsonOur TownSwansea Grand theatre, to 31 January; touring to 28 MarchThe inaugural production for Michael Sheenâ€™s Welsh National Theatre tours Wales and then transfers to Londonâ€™s Rose theatre in February. Sheen leads an all-Welsh cast in Thornton Wilderâ€™s achingly moving play, which quietly tracks the passing of time in aÂ small town.MGView image in fullscreenStaying in:StreamingView image in fullscreenComic capers â€¦ Yahya Adbul-Mateen II and Ben Kingsley in Marvelâ€™s Wonder Man.Photograph: Marvel TelevisionWonder ManDisney+,28 JanuaryMarvel has its cake and eats it with this mind-bendingly meta drama set in a world plagued by superhero fatigue. Wannabe actor Simon Williams (Yahya Abdul-Mateen II) and past-it thesp Trevor Slattery (Ben Kingsley) are both desperate for roles in a Wonder Man reboot â€“ but could the former be a far better fit for the lead than he first appears?Under Salt MarshSky Atlantic & Now,30 January, 9pmThis brooding Wales-set thriller from rising film-maker Claire Oakley is more bone-chiller than winter warmer. Starring Rafe Spall and Yellowstoneâ€™s Kelly Reilly, it kicks offÂ with a detective turned teacher discovering the body of a pupil; the ensuing investigation unites police dysfunction, small-town suspicion and climate crisis-abetted natural disaster.Take ThatNetflix,27 JanuaryBetween the BBCâ€™s the BBCâ€™s Boybands and Girlbands Forever strand and Skyâ€™s Boyzone doc, sensitive yet rollickingly entertaining programmes about our favourite 90s pop stars are everywhere. title: Arne Slot says Liverpool â€˜ran out of energyâ€™ in defeat at Bournemouth | Liverpool | The Guardian
description: Arne Slot conceded his Liverpool side ran out of steam in defeat at Bournemouth, after Amine Adliâ€™s 95th-minute winner condemned his side to a first loss since November
Author: Ben Fisher
Headline: Arne Slot conceded his Liverpool side ran out of steam in defeat at Bournemouth, after Amine Adliâ€™s 95th-minute winner condemned his side to a first loss since November
Content: Arne Slot said he could not criticise his players for lacking energy due to the rigours of the fixture list.Photograph: Robin Jones/AFC Bournemouth/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenArne Slot said he could not criticise his players for lacking energy due to the rigours of the fixture list.Photograph: Robin Jones/AFC Bournemouth/Getty ImagesLiverpoolArne Slot says Liverpool â€˜ran out of energyâ€™ in defeat at BournemouthHead coach highlights away game in Champions LeagueSlot questions fixture list after difficult away tripBen Fisherat the Vitality StadiumSat 24 Jan 2026 16.42 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 19.28 ESTShareArne Slot conceded his side ran out of steamin defeat at Bournemouth, after Amine Adliâ€™s 95th-minute winner condemned Liverpool to a first loss since November. Liverpool pulled level from 2-0 down late on courtesy of Dominik Szoboszlaiâ€™s sensational free-kick, but Bournemouth responded impressively and Adli struck a winner from a long throw with almost the last kick.The Liverpool head coach felt the referee, Michael Salisbury, should have played more second-half stoppage time taking in substitutions and video assistant referee checks but admitted he feared aBournemouthwinner. â€œI think it is safe to say they could have scored 3-2 a little bit earlier,â€ Slot said, alluding to chances for the Bournemouth pair Evanilson and Ryan Christie. â€œA few of our players ran out of energy and I cannot even criticise them for that because two days ago [three] we had to play an away game. Weâ€™re the only team that played in the Champions League that has two games in between.Adli scrambles last-gasp winner as Bournemouth take down LiverpoolRead moreâ€œThis time after an away game [a3-0 win in Marseille], another away game against one of the most intense teams in the league and I mainly played the same players because of the players we have available. Conceding a goal is always frustrating, but especially if there is no time left to come back into the game.â€At full time Slot told the officials he was unhappy that only four minutes of stoppage time were allocated. â€œFor me, four minutes of added time was not enough but in the end that didnâ€™t matter because they scored,â€ he said. â€œAlthough then we couldâ€™ve maybe had two or three [more] minutes but this game shouldnâ€™t have had four minutes of extra time. There was a free-kick that took two or three minutes, there were VAR moments, there were substitutions. Thatâ€™s what I said to them.â€Slot refused to criticise his captain, Virgil van Dijk, for his defensive error in the buildup to Evanilsonâ€™s opener and would not be drawn when asked whether Andy Robertson would remain at the club. Tottenhamare pursuing a dealto sign the Scotland captain, who replaced Milos Kerkez at half-time. The left-back, a Â£40m buy from Bournemouth last summer, was at fault for the hostsâ€™ second goal, scored while Liverpool had only 10 men on the pitch after Joe Gomez was forced off injured.Bournemouthâ€™s head coach, Andoni Iraola, expressed his delight that his side were rewarded for shifting their mentality and gameplan. â€œNormally we go full gas from the beginning, we keep our energy until the end,â€ he said. â€œBut now, probably because we donâ€™t have the numbers and need to adapt a little bit, we are choosing our moments a little bit more and knowing we might need to save a little bit of energy.â€Explore more on these topicsLiverpoolBournemouthArne SlotnewsShareReuse this content

title: Thomas Frank calls for â€˜calm headsâ€™ as Tottenham fans renew calls for his exit | Tottenham Hotspur | The Guardian
description: Thomas Frank has called for â€˜calm headsâ€™ after Tottenhamâ€™s draw at relegation-threatened Burnley despite fans again urging the club to dismiss him
Author: Will Unwin
Headline: Thomas Frank has called for â€˜calm headsâ€™ after Tottenhamâ€™s draw at relegation-threatened Burnley despite fans again urging the club to dismiss him
Content: Thomas Frank (left) talks to Micky van de Ven after the draw at Burnley.Photograph: Richard Sellers/PAView image in fullscreenThomas Frank (left) talks to Micky van de Ven after the draw at Burnley.Photograph: Richard Sellers/PATottenham HotspurThomas Frank calls for â€˜calm headsâ€™ as Tottenham fans renew calls for his exitHead coach targeted in draw at BurnleyFrank: â€˜You canâ€™t say we didnâ€™t do everything to winâ€™Will Unwinat Turf MoorSat 24 Jan 2026 13.32 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 13.58 ESTShareThomas Frank has called for â€œcalm headsâ€ after Tottenham fans urged the club to dismiss him during their draw at relegation-threatened Burnley. The away end sang â€œYouâ€™re getting sacked in the morningâ€ at full time, making their views clear to the hierarchy and head coach.Cristian Romero salvaged a late point for Tottenhamafter Axel Tuanzebe and Lyle Foster had turned things around to counter Micky van de Venâ€™s opening goal. The draw leaves Tottenham with two wins in 14 and mired in mid-table.Romeroâ€™s late strike rescues point for troubled Tottenham at BurnleyRead moreâ€œYou canâ€™t say we didnâ€™t do everything to win,â€ Frank said. â€œWe just need to keep improving. The only way it can be is calm heads, carry on and keep doing what we think is the right thing.â€œWe do more than enough to win the game, we just need to defend better in two situations. And, of course, score another goal that could make the difference at 1-0.â€Poor defending assisted Burnleyâ€™s comeback. â€œWe can never, ever, ever concede that goal, because it just changes the momentum going into half-time,â€ Frank said of Tuanzebeâ€™s header.â€œIn the second half we are coming out, we are not as dominant, but I still think we are OK on top. We got a big chance to Dominic Solanke, 2-1 up. And then we concede another goal that we can never, ever, ever concede.â€The Tottenham supporters chanted regularly for Frankâ€™s exit during the match. Talks were held last weekend over the head coachâ€™s position, but no definitive action was taken.View image in fullscreenMicky van de Ven put Tottenham in front at Turf Moor but the visitors fell behind before Cristian Romeroâ€™s late leveller.Photograph: Peter Powell/Reutersâ€œThe message to the fans, as I said the whole time, is that weâ€™re working very hard on making sure everything is going in the right direction and that weâ€™ll keep doing that,â€ Frank said.â€œFirst and foremost, I want to thank them for travelling and supporting the team throughout the game. We could, should have been out of sight. But also they acknowledge the willpower and character of the team that keep running, keep fighting to the end. We just need to keep going.â€A point away to Eintracht Frankfurt on Wednesday should guarantee a top-eight spot in the Champions League and progression to the round of 16, which would help Frankâ€™s cause. The club are also in negotiations with Liverpool overthe signing of the defender Andy Robertson, who would become the second new arrival this month afterConor Gallagher.There were more points dropped late on by Burnley, which has become a regular occurrence this season. â€œIt was only four or five weeks ago I was hugely critical of this team in terms of usat Brighton away, weâ€™ve reacted in an incredible way,â€ Scott Parker said.â€œThereâ€™s no denying that we need to now turn draws into wins and today, for being so close, youâ€™d hope that would have been the case. We just fell a little bit short.â€Explore more on these topicsTottenham HotspurThomas FrankBurnleyScott ParkernewsShareReuse this content
