The orange tan that doesnâ€™t extend beyond the neckline or wrists; the pale bald patches showing through his yellow comb-over. Itâ€™s a way to undermine his ego, like plucking the feathers off. I think the best caricatures capture not just a politicianâ€™s face but their whole body and its movement. I hoped that the finger motion of plucking feathers would evoke Trumpâ€™s pincer-like hand gestures.When Iâ€™m drawing a political cartoon Iâ€™m always slightly in awe of the fact Iâ€™m working from and into a tradition. Iâ€™ve admired Martinâ€™s work all my life and his caricatures have deeply shaped how I see politicians and inspired how Iâ€™ve gone on to draw them. I now have the more complicated task of working out how my cartoons could and should be different. At the beginning it felt necessary to prove that I could do the job of the (almost exclusively) men who came before me, even when it wasnâ€™t International Womenâ€™s Day, by rinsing most of the femininity out of my cartoons; both in concept and in style. Gradually, with a bit more confidence and experience, Iâ€™ve been trying to bring it back.View image in fullscreenIllustration: Ella Baron/The Guardian

title: Three arrested after two incidents of disorder outside asylum seeker camp | East Sussex | The Guardian
description: Police say two men and a woman shouted abuse and struck vehicle outside Crowborough military site in East Sussex
Author: Morgan Ofori
Headline: Police say two men and a woman shouted abuse and struck vehicle outside Crowborough military site in East Sussex
Content: Police officers outside the Crowborough training camp, East Sussex, where the first 27 illegal migrants have now moved in as part of the government's mission to end the use of expensive hotels.Photograph: Maja Smiejkowska/PAView image in fullscreenPolice officers outside the Crowborough training camp, East Sussex, where the first 27 illegal migrants have now moved in as part of the government's mission to end the use of expensive hotels.Photograph: Maja Smiejkowska/PAEast SussexThree arrested after two incidents of disorder outside asylum seeker campPolice say two men and a woman shouted abuse and struck vehicle outside Crowborough military site in East SussexMorgan OforiSat 24 Jan 2026 13.09 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 13.21 ESTShareThree people have been arrested after two occurrences of disorder outside Crowborough training camp, which is being used to house asylum seekers.A 36-year-old man and a 62-year-old woman from Crowborough, and a 54-year-old man from Newhaven were arrested on Saturday on suspicion of an offence under the Public Order Act and are now in police custody.Sussex police said the arrests came after two incidents at the entrance to theEast Sussexcamp on Friday.About 27 men have been housed at the camp, where the Home Office plans to accommodate up to 500 men as it bids to end the use of asylum hotels.Crowborough is one of two military sites the government announced last year it would use to house asylum seekers, along withCameron Barracks in Invernessin the Highlands.View image in fullscreenPolice officers speak to a man near the Crowborough training campPhotograph: Maja Smiejkowska/PAThe move has triggered opposition from neighbours of the camp, and the local authority, Wealden district council, has said it is considering legal action.A Sussex police spokesperson said: â€œThe gathering was initially peaceful. However, when a vehicle was leaving the site, three individuals were threatening and intimidatory.â€œThe individuals caused an obstruction, shouted abuse and struck the vehicle, alarming the driver and passengers.â€Ch Supt James Collis said: â€œThe Home Office retains responsibility for the site, its security and its occupants, and we encourage anyone with concerns relating to the site to contact the Home Office in the first instance.â€On a visit to Crowborough on Thursday, the home secretary, Shabana Mahmood,vowed to defendany legal challenge â€œvigorouslyâ€.She told broadcasters: â€œI understand the strength of feeling but I do also believe that getting out of asylum hotels is absolutely crucial for the country.â€œWe should never have used asylum hotels to house illegal migrants into this country.â€Explore more on these topicsEast SussexnewsShareReuse this content

title: Snow, sleet and power outages: 140m Americans under warnings for major winter storm | US weather | The Guardian
description: Dangerous weather engulfing large area of country as 16 states plus DC declare states of emergency
Author: Anna Betts
Headline: Dangerous weather engulfing large area of country as 16 states plus DC declare states of emergency
Content: A plow truck clears snow on I-40 during Winter Storm Fern in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.Photograph: Nick Oxford/ReutersView image in fullscreenA plow truck clears snow on I-40 during Winter Storm Fern in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.Photograph: Nick Oxford/ReutersUS weatherSnow, sleet and power outages: 140m Americans under warnings for major winter stormDangerous weather engulfing large area of country as 16 states plus DC declare states of emergencyAnna Bettsin New YorkSat 24 Jan 2026 17.31 ESTFirst published on Sat 24 Jan 2026 11.02 ESTShareA powerfulwinter stormwith more than 140 million Americans in its crosshairs started sweeping across much of the US on Saturday, packing heavy snow and sleet as well as freezing rain and causing widespread power outages.Snowfall wasalreadybeing reported on Saturday morning acrosspartsof the plains, the south and the midwest, including in areas ofOklahoma,Iowa,Tennessee,Kansas,TexasandMissouri.The severe cold weather created unsafe driving conditions on many roads throughout the midwest and southern US as ice coated streets and highways and electric grid operators stepped up precautions to avoid rotating blackouts.Three people were found dead on New York City streets amid freezing temperatures on Saturday afternoon. A 67-year-old man was found on a sidewalk at about 7.45am on Third Avenue in Manhattan, according to police. An additional two bodies â€“ a man in his 30s and a woman in her 60s â€“ were found separately in Brooklyn about two hours after the first discovery. All three died as a result of â€œweather-related circumstancesâ€, according to sources who spoke withNBC NewsNew York.Ice and sleet hit northern Texas overnight and moved toward the central part of the state on Saturday. Ice formed on roads and bridges in a third of Mississippiâ€™s counties. Dominion Energy said it is preparing for widespread power outages in Virginia andNorth Carolinacaused by the storm.View image in fullscreenA de-icing crew works during Winter Storm Fern on a Southwest Airlines flight at Nashville international airport in Nashville, Tennessee.Photograph: Andrew Nelles/ReutersAs of Saturday afternoon, nearly 14,000 flights through Monday into, within or out of the US had been canceled as the storm began its track, according to FlightAware.com. The storm brought severe cold and ice to regions unaccustomed to such severe conditions. About 140 million people, or more than 40% of the US population, were under winter storm warnings from New Mexico to New England.By midday Saturday, a quarter of an inch of ice was reported in parts of south-easternOklahoma, eastern Texas and portions of Louisiana.The X account of Chicago & Midwest Storm Chasersreportedâ€œmany cars are off the road or stuck along the [south-west] side of [interstate] 30 near Little Rockâ€ amid significant ice and snow.And Arkansas meteorologist Zachary HallwroteSaturday on X that interstate 40 was â€œat a standstill â€¦ due to accidentsâ€.â€œThese conditions will *NOT* improve with more snow, sleet and freezing rain likely tonight and tomorrow too,â€ Hall wrote.View image in fullscreenAn unhoused woman uses a blanket to try to stay warm in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.Photograph: Nick Oxford/Reutersâ€œWhat really makes this storm unique is, just following this storm, itâ€™s just going to get so cold,â€ said Allison Santorelli, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service. â€œThe snow and the ice will be very, very slow to melt and wonâ€™t be going away anytime soon, and thatâ€™s going to hinder any recovery efforts.â€The weather agencywarnedon Saturday morning that the powerful winter storm was â€œunderwayâ€ with â€œprecipitation already impactingâ€ south-central regions of the country.Forecasters have said that more than160 million Americansare expected to be affected by the winter storm. Weather officials warn that widespread, extended power outages were possible â€“ along with major travel disruptions, extensive tree damage and dangerous conditions.Heavy snow is expected across a large area from the southern Rockies and plains through the mid-Atlantic and into the north-east through the weekend, the NWS said. The NWS added that snowfall totals were likely to exceed 12in across the Ohio valley, mid-Atlantic and north-east.View image in fullscreenA shopper walks through a snow-covered parking lot in Brentwood, Tennessee.Photograph: Camden Hall/NurPhoto/ShutterstockWidespread freezing rain and sleet are forecast for the southern plains, the lower Mississippi valley, theTennesseevalley and the south-east.The NWS warned of â€œcatastrophic ice accumulationâ€ from the southern plains to the mid-Atlantic and the south-east. It added that the catastrophic impacts are expected where freezing rain amounts exceed a half inch, with totals of more than 1in possible in parts of northern Louisiana, central and northern Mississippi, southern Tennessee and the southern Appalachians.In the wake of the storm, the agency said, communities from the southern plains to the north-east can expect to contend with â€œbitterly cold temperatures and dangerously cold wind chillsâ€.On Friday, the agencysaidthat power outages â€œare certain for some, especially in areas where the heaviest ice will accumulate on trees and powerlinesâ€.The service urged Americans on Friday to â€œtake this storm seriouslyâ€.As of Saturday afternoon, more than 130,000 customers, including about 61,600 inTexas, were without power nationwide, according to PowerOutage.us.Donald Trump on Friday nightsaidon his Truth Social platform that he had been â€œbriefed on the Record Cold Wave and Historic Winter Storm that will be hitting much of the United States this weekendâ€.View image in fullscreenA snow-covered street in St Louis, Missouri.Photograph: Jeff Roberson/APâ€œThe Trump Administration is coordinating with State and Local Officials,â€ the president said. He declared the Federal Emergency Management Agency (Fema) â€œfully prepared to respondâ€ less than a month after reports that his administration had drafted plans toeliminate thousandsof the entityâ€™s staff.â€œStay Safe and Stay Warm!â€ Trump wrote on Truth Social.Before the storm,at least 16 stateshad declared states of emergency, along with Washington DC.Kentuckyâ€™s governor, Andy Beshear,warnedon Saturday morning that the winter storm was â€œmoving throughâ€ the state â€œwith areas expecting up to 15 inches of snow, ice accumulation and dangerously cold temperaturesâ€.He urged residents to avoid travel and to prepare.New York Cityâ€™s mayor, Zohran Mamdani, meanwhile,saidthat the city was forecast to get from 3in to 16in of snow this weekend.Explore more on these topicsUS weatherExtreme weatherDonald TrumpNew YorkOklahomaIowaTennesseenewsShareReuse this content

title: Red meat, no lettuce: Nigel Farage and Liz Truss attend private lunch after week of Tory defections | Politics | The Guardian
description: Meal at Mayfair club took place on day Reform UKâ€™s Robert Jenrick criticised former PMâ€™s mini-budget
Author: Ben Quinn
Headline: Meal at Mayfair club took place on day Reform UKâ€™s Robert Jenrick criticised former PMâ€™s mini-budget
Content: Liz Truss and Nigel Farage, seen here at the 2024 Conservative Political Action Conference in the US, enjoyed a lunch of steak and chips at a club in Mayfair, London.Photograph: JosÃ© Luis MagaÃ±a/APView image in fullscreenLiz Truss and Nigel Farage, seen here at the 2024 Conservative Political Action Conference in the US, enjoyed a lunch of steak and chips at a club in Mayfair, London.Photograph: JosÃ© Luis MagaÃ±a/APPoliticsRed meat, no lettuce: Nigel Farage and Liz Truss attend private lunch after week of Tory defectionsMeal at Mayfair club took place on day Reform UKâ€™s Robert Jenrick criticised former PMâ€™s mini-budgetBen QuinnandHelena HortonSat 24 Jan 2026 02.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 02.29 ESTShareIf it was on the menu, a side helping of lettuce never made it to the table. Over blood-red steak and chips,Nigel Farageand Liz Truss came together on Monday for a discreet lunch at a swish Mayfair club, organised by a climate-denying US thinktank.Lois Perry, a former leader of the far-right Ukip party who is now Europe director of the Heartland Institute, posted photographs, now deleted, on X of Farage addressing others, including Truss, at the meal.WhileReform UKappears to be keeping the former prime minster at armâ€™s length publicly, despite welcoming other former Tories, the gathering at Markâ€™s Club organised by the Heartland Institute raises potentially fresh awkward questions for the party.â€œLiz Truss would not be welcome in Reform UK,â€ the partyâ€™s press team replied within seven minutes of being asked by the Guardian if the party would ever allow the UKâ€™s shortest-serving prime minister into its ranks.View image in fullscreenThe former Conservative housing secretary Robert Jenrick, centre, defected to Reform UK on 15 January.Photograph: Jacob King/PAYet speculation has persisted about the next moves of Truss, whose mini-budget was described by Farage as â€œthe best Conservative budget since 1986â€.â€œShe is very comfortable in that group, a lot whom hang out together, and both she and Nigel are clearly close to a lot of the same people, including some of Reformâ€™s biggest backers,â€ said one of the other 20 or so people who attended.The thinktank they were lunching in aid of has made some extreme and incorrect comments on the climate. In the past, it has compared people who believe in global heating to the Unabomber, the US terrorist jailed for killing three people and injuring many others.Those present included David Starkey,the historian dropped by his university and publisher in 2020 over racist remarks, who has become a favoured guest at Reformâ€™s annual conference, and Mike Graham, the broadcastersacked from Rupert Murdochâ€™s TalkTVafter it said he had failed to cooperate with an investigation into a racist post that appeared on one of his social media accounts.Others included Alan Mendoza, a founder and executive director of the right-leaning Henry Jackson Society thinktank, and Lance Forman, the smoked salmon mogul and former Brexit party MEP who gave financial backing to Trussâ€™s Tory leadership campaign.View image in fullscreenLance Forman, seen here in 2016, said he spoke to Liz Truss at the lunch about Robert Jenrickâ€™s criticism of her mini-budget and she was â€˜not upset at allâ€™.Photograph: Graeme Robertson/The Guardianâ€œIt was basically about climate change,â€ Forman told the Guardian when asked about the lunch, which happened to take place on the same day that one of Reformâ€™s newest recruits,Robert Jenrick, had claimed he toldKemi Badenoch to kick Truss out of the Conservative party because of her â€œcackhandedâ€ mini-budget.Areport in the New Statesmanhas suggested Truss spent the lunch visibly annoyed about Jenrickâ€™s attack on her and her record in a piece for the Times and, after Farageâ€™s departure, she complained to other guests that â€œdark forcesâ€ were behind the article.However, Forman said: â€œThe timing of it was quite funny because of what Robert Jenrick had said that very morning. I was talking to Liz Truss and we mentioned it â€“ she was not upset at all. She is very cheerful and robust.â€œIt was a ridiculous thing for Jenrick to have said, actually. He said it on the back of her budget and Nigel Farage was one of those who congratulated her on her budget.â€ He said the food on offer was an â€œunmemorableâ€ set menu featuring a chocolate mousse for dessert.Labour seized on the presence of both Truss and Farage, with a spokesperson claiming that Farage is â€œhellbent on reassembling Boris Johnsonâ€™s cabinet of failed Tories who broke our public services and hammered family financesâ€.They added: â€œOn the same day Robert Jenrick said his old boss Liz Truss should be thrown out of the Tory party because of the damage she did to families, his new boss Nigel Farage was quaffing champagne and enjoying a lavish lunch with her.â€Hard copies outlining the views of the Heartland Institute were also passed around at the lunch, where one diner said Farage gave a short speech that endorsed the instituteâ€™s ideas.â€œI think itâ€™s likely that some of the things they are calling for will end up in a Reform programme for government,â€ they added.Once owned by the entrepreneur Mark Birley, Markâ€™s Club was sold in 2007 to Richard Caring, who also owns The Ivy and Sexy Fish restaurant chains, and is seen by the rightwing elite as a new money establishment with a less exclusive membership list than in its storied past.The Liz Truss Show review â€“ hapless ravings from a cupboardRead moreThe club recently had a migraine-inducing makeover, stuffed with chintzy furnishings, gigantic oil paintings of dogs and brightly patterned wallpaper. Membership of Markâ€™s is Â£2,750 each year plus a Â£1,250 joining fee.The home of the Tory right is now unanimously understood to be 5 Hertford Street, which is owned by the late Mark Birleyâ€™s son, Robin. Truss may have struggled to secure a booking at this club; she is understood to haveirritated its ownersby wandering the premises in search of members to poach for her own rival club just one street away, which asks â€œfounding membersâ€ for an eye-watering Â£500,000.While a much more fringe figure, Perry too has increasingly been working to establish herself as a major player on Britainâ€™s new right. She spentmuch of this weekin Zurich at a â€œDavos alternativeâ€, run by the Heartland Institute, where Truss was billed as a keynote speaker, opining on â€œa vision for the UK and the democratic westâ€.The lunch was not the first time Perry has brought Truss and Farage together. Both graced the launch of the Heartlandâ€™s UK chapter at a glitzy party last year, held at Brooksâ€™s private members club â€“ one of the few remaining London gentlemenâ€™s clubs that does not admit women.Explore more on these topicsPoliticsNigel FarageLiz TrussReform UKConservativesKemi BadenochRobert JenricknewsShareReuse this content

title: From scorpions to peacocks: the species thriving in Londonâ€™s hidden microclimates | London | The Guardian
description: An extraordinary mosaic of wildlife has made Britainâ€™s urban jungle its home
Author: Isaaq Tomkins
Headline: An extraordinary mosaic of wildlife has made Britainâ€™s urban jungle its home
Content: A peacock basks in the sunshine in Holland Park, west London.Photograph: Johnny Armstead/AlamyView image in fullscreenA peacock basks in the sunshine in Holland Park, west London.Photograph: Johnny Armstead/AlamyLondonFrom scorpions to peacocks: the species thriving in Londonâ€™s hidden microclimatesAn extraordinary mosaic of wildlife has made Britainâ€™s urban jungle its homeIsaaq TomkinsSat 24 Jan 2026 01.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 10.20 ESTShareLondon is the only place in the UK where you can find scorpions, snakes, turtles, seals, peacocks, falcons all in one city â€“ and notLondonzoo. Step outside and you will encounter a patchwork of writhing, buzzing, bubbling urban microclimates.Sam Davenport, the director of nature recovery at the LondonWildlifeTrust, emphasises the sheer variation in habitats that you find in UK cities, which creates an amazing â€œmosaicâ€ of wildlife.â€œIf you think of going out into the countryside where you have arable fields, itâ€™s really homogeneous. But if you walk a mile in each direction of a city youâ€™re going to get allotments, gardens, railway lines, bits of ancient woodland.â€Animals also thrive in cities because urban winters are milder than in the countryside. â€œItâ€™s not uncommon in cities to see queen bumblebees foraging over Christmas,â€ Davenport said. â€œWhen itâ€™s cold, the city is warmer. We have a microclimate that invertebrates can make use of.â€Beyond bees, species such as otters and herons benefit from waterways that are less likely to freeze, keeping food supplies more stable through the winter months.Many species also adapt their behaviour to urban life, altering where and how they hunt, the habitats they use, or the ways they move through the landscape. â€œCities show that natureâ€™s really good at being adaptable and finding a niche,â€ Davenport said.Here are some of the species that have found a way to thrive in the big smoke:LandView image in fullscreenA disused London Underground station, home to the eponymous mosquitoes that migrated from the Middle East.Photograph: Dan Kitwood/Getty ImagesAs it turns out, the â€œLondon Underground mosquitoâ€ (Culex pipiens f. molestus) is not aptly named. The insects became notorious during the second world war, when they would dine on Londoners seeking shelter from bombing in tube tunnels. But despite popular belief, they did not evolve underground. Their origins lie in the Middle East several thousand years ago, though they have since happily adapted to the temperate climate of the capitalâ€™s transport network.Mosquitoes are not the only emigres to have found a home in Britainâ€™s urban jungle. More than 10,000 yellow-tailed scorpions (Tetratrichobothrius flavicaudis) are thought to live in the crevices of walls at Sheerness dockyard, Kent, and are believed to have spawned a second colony in the east London docklands. They arrived in the UK in the 1800s, nestled in shipments of Italian masonry.Meanwhile, Regentâ€™s Park provides perfect woodland conditions for the UKâ€™s main population of Aesculapian snakes (Zamenis longissimus). One of Europeâ€™s largest snake species, these olive-coloured constrictors are thought to be escapers from a former research facility, surviving in the wild by preying on rodents and birds.WaterwaysView image in fullscreenOtters can be spotted playing in the water near Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park.Photograph: Kirsty Wigglesworth/PAIn 1957, the Natural History Museum declared the Thames biologically dead. Since then, improvements to sewage systems and industrial waste disposal have transformed the river into a habitable ecosystem. The wildlife now found in the Thames and its network of waterways is a striking environmental success story.Otters, once endangered, can be seen playing in the water near Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park. Downstream in the Thames estuary,hundreds of harbour sealssometimes wander inland to hunt fish that have returned to cleaner urban rivers.Londonâ€™s waterways have also attracted more unexpected residents. These include the demon shrimp (Dikerogammarus haemobaphes),a worrisome speciesof aggressive omnivore from the Black Sea, and short-snouted seahorses (Hippocampus hippocampus), thought to have drifted in on the Gulf Stream â€“ perhaps a more hopeful sign of the Thamesâ€™s biological recovery.Two aquatic creatures vie for the strangest origin story in the Thames. First are red-eared terrapins (Trachemys scripta elegans), imported to the UK from Mississippi and Mexico during the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle craze of the 1980s. Bought as pets and later abandoned, they have since thrived in urban ponds and canals. Some of the terrapins seen today are likely to be the same 1980s pets â€“ just significantly older.Then there is the European eel (Anguilla anguilla), which has one of the strangest life cycles of any animal. After spawning in the Sargasso Sea near the Bahamas, the eels drift on Atlantic currents to rivers such as the Thames, where they can live for decades before making the long journey back to the Bahamas to die.SkyView image in fullscreenPeregrine falcon chicks in a nest atop a London tower block.Photograph: Nature Picture Library/AlamyPeregrine falcons(Falco peregrinus)are the fastest animals in the world â€“ and they thrive in central London. Some of the cityâ€™s roughly 40 breeding pairs roost on the Barbicanâ€™s tower blocks, where residents report watching adults give flying lessons to their young.Swooping from the Barbican, the falcons often spend the day at Tate Modern, just across the river. Although they would not usually hunt at night, they have adapted to city life, preying on nocturnal migratory birds drawn to the glow of streetlights.Peregrine falcons loopBats, too, live comfortably alongside people. They are commonly found along canals, disused industrial buildings, in peopleâ€™s homes â€“ and even flying down Regent Street. Wildlife experts believe they navigate much like human commuters, using linear railway embankments as guides through the city.Other birds are legacies of Britainâ€™s aristocratic past. Peacocks, for example, are known to strut through the Kyoto Garden in Holland Park, feral descendants of birds once kept by the gentry.Meanwhile, the ancestors of the pelicans that live in St Jamesâ€™s Park were a gift presented to King Charles II by the Russian ambassador in 1664.Explore more on these topicsLondonWildlifeAnimalsBirdsInsectsConservationLondon UndergroundnewsShareReuse this content

title: â€˜We cannot say for sure these wolves come from Russiaâ€™: Finns try to fathom cause of record reindeer deaths | Wildlife | The Guardian
description: Wolves killed more than 2,100 reindeer in Finland last year, and herders are blaming the Ukraine war
Author: Patrick Greenfield
Headline: Wolves killed more than 2,100 reindeer in Finland last year, and herders are blaming the Ukraine war
Content: Wolves have had their strictly protected conservation status downgraded in the EU after numbers almost doubled in 10 years.Photograph: Danny Green/naturepl.comView image in fullscreenWolves have had their strictly protected conservation status downgraded in the EU after numbers almost doubled in 10 years.Photograph: Danny Green/naturepl.comThe age of extinctionWildlifeâ€˜We cannot say for sure these wolves come from Russiaâ€™: Finns try to fathom cause of record reindeer deathsWolves killed more than 2,100 reindeer in Finland last year, and herders are blaming the Ukraine warThe age of extinction is supported byAbout this contentPatrick GreenfieldSat 24 Jan 2026 00.00 ESTShareJuha Kujala no longer knows how many reindeer will return to his farm from the forest each December. The 54-year-old herder releases his animals into the wilderness on the 830-mile Finnish-Russian border each spring to grow fat on lichens, grass and mushrooms, just as his ancestors have done for generations.But since 2022, grisly discoveries of reindeer skeletons on the forest floor have disrupted this ancient way of life. The culprits, according to Kujala: wolves from Russia.Oblivious to the tensions between the two countries sparked by Moscowâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, large animals such as wolves and bears move freely across the heavily forested frontier. Most go unnoticed, but on the Finnish side, a record level of wolf attacks on reindeer last year has sparked concern among some herders.View image in fullscreenA Finnish reindeer killed by wolves. â€˜They go for the throat and legs.â€™Photograph: Juha KujalaThey suspect that Russian wolf numbers have exploded after hunters were sent to the frontline in Ukraine, driving the predators to search for new territory inFinland.â€œThe last year has been the worst ever for wolf attacks in this area. The reindeer are an easy catch for them,â€ says Kujala, whose reindeer are spending the winter at his farm near Kuusamo.â€œYou can see the signs that it is wolves: they go for the throat and the legs. When youâ€™ve seen enough dead ones, you can tell.â€œMy home is 38km from the Russian border. When it snows, you can see the tracks coming from their side,â€ he adds.A record 2,124 reindeer were killed by wolves in 2025, according to the Reindeer Herdersâ€™ Association of Finland, which says those found are likely to be a fraction of the true total. Many share photos of the skeletons they find in the forests, which have often been chewed clean to the bone.Despite the herdersâ€™ suspicions about Russian wolves being to blame, the authorities say it is hard to be definitive about the reasons behind the jump in predation.There is almost no contact across the border between Finland and Russia, and it is impossible to get answers to basic questions from the Russians about what might be behind the rise in attacks. Finnish herders say they are no longer able to collect reindeer that have crossed the border, which was commonplace before Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine.View image in fullscreenReindeer roam widely but Finnish herders say they can no longer collect reindeer that have crossed the border, as they did before Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine.Photograph: T Mendoza/AlamyUntil last June, the wolf was a strictly protected species in the EU after it was nearly hunted to extinction in many countries. But itsconservation level was downgradedafter numbers almost doubled across Europe from 11,193 to 20,300 between 2012 and 2023. Roughly 65,500 livestock a year are thought to be killed by the predators, prompting some EU states toincrease culling.In the hills of Italy, wolves returned from the brink. Then the poisonings beganRead moreFinlandlifted its ban on wolf huntingat the start of 2026, instead implementing a hunting quota system to limit population growth.Ilpo Kojola, a wolf specialist with Finlandâ€™s Natural Resources Institute, says: â€œThe wolf is a species that can increase rapidly. They are usually pretty limited by hunting in Russia so thatâ€™s why it is possible that the war in Ukraine has had some role in the change.â€œBut itâ€™s impossible to be conclusive because, of course, there could be some other reason that we do not have solid evidence for.â€The increase in attacks is close timing with the war in UkraineIlpo KojolaThe Finnishwolf population was about 430in spring last year, according to official statistics, and is part of the same subspecies as those in Russia, which is home to an estimated 60,000.Kojola says there is a precedent for the rapid increase in Russiaâ€™s wolf population when, during the second world war, numbers doubled after millions of men were sent to fight against Nazi Germany on the Soviet Unionâ€™s western front. There wasanother spikewhen the USSR collapsed.View image in fullscreenA reindeer killed by wolves near the border.Photograph: J Kujalaâ€œWe donâ€™t know how big a role the soldiers stationed at garrisons on the border played in wolf hunting in the area. But the increase in attacks is close timing with the war in Ukraine,â€ he says.Mia Valtonen, a senior scientist with the Natural Resources Institute, is responsible for the genetic testing of wolves shot to control populations. She says a majority of the wolves shot in Finland in recent years do not appear to be from the country, but researchers cannot be certain as a genetic record of their entire wolf population has not yet been completed.â€œWe cannot say for sure that most of these wolves come from Russia. Itâ€™s likely, but we cannot say it for sure,â€ she says.Kujala and other herders who regularly find dead reindeer in the forest dismiss the scientific caution, calling for greater protection from attacks.â€œWe do not hate the wolves but we need balance,â€ Kujala says. â€œThe reindeer spend most of their time out in nature. Around my farm, there is a big 50km section for them to roam in. Itâ€™s impossible to protect them all the time.â€œWe need them healthy and strong. This is our life, itâ€™s our job, itâ€™s how we live. Itâ€™s been like this for hundreds of years.â€Find moreage of extinction coverage here, and follow the biodiversity reportersPhoebe WestonandPatrick Greenfieldin the Guardian app for more nature coverageExplore more on these topicsWildlifeThe age of extinctionFinlandRussiaBiodiversityMammalsEuropeConservationfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: RHS unveils plans to protect UK gardens from future water shortages | Water | The Guardian
description: Environmental charity to prioritise water capture and storage as it urges gardeners to prepare for â€˜new normalâ€™
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Environmental charity to prioritise water capture and storage as it urges gardeners to prepare for â€˜new normalâ€™
Content: The RHS is reviewing how and where to allocate water across its gardens, including Wisley (pictured).Photograph: Adrian Davies/AlamyView image in fullscreenThe RHS is reviewing how and where to allocate water across its gardens, including Wisley (pictured).Photograph: Adrian Davies/AlamyWaterRHS unveils plans to protect UK gardens from future water shortagesEnvironmental charity to prioritise water capture and storage as it urges gardeners to prepare for â€˜new normalâ€™PA MediaSat 24 Jan 2026 03.00 ESTShareThe Royal Horticultural Society has unveiled emergency plans to protect its gardens frommajor water shortagesin the future.The environmental charity, which owns and operates five renowned public gardens inEngland, said on Saturday it will invest in more water-capture and water-management projects in 2026 after severe droughts last year.In response to increasingly erratic weather patterns, the RHS is also urging gardeners to mirror its measures this winter and spring to prepare for as much rain as possible.This includes preparing the soil with hollow tining,chop and dropand mulching, creating rain gardens, installing rainwater storage facilities and considering whether plants are in the right place.Global heating continues to drive volatility in the water cycle, with the UK experiencing below average rainfall more frequently and a rise in the risk of flooding.Last year was the driest spring in 132 yearsand the hottest summer since records began, plunging several areas of the UK into drought, with some still recovering in January.In preparation for the next drought, the RHS is reviewing how and where to allocate water across its gardens at Wisley in Surrey, Hyde Hall in Essex, Rosemoor in Devon, Harlow Carr in North Yorkshire and Bridgewater in Greater Manchester.Era of â€˜global water bankruptcyâ€™ is here, UN report saysRead moreProjects in 2026 will include increasing the storage of water in tanks and lakes, installing ebb-and-flow benches in retail centres to reduce water use, and investing in rain garden installations.The charity will also carry out research on soil health in its gardens and continue to quantify individual plant and whole landscape water use. In addition, it will explore using more grey-water â€“ cleaner wastewater from baths, showers, sinks and washing machines.The plans mark a wider shift in the RHSâ€™s approach to the climate crisis as it focuses on adapting to the growing impacts of planet-warming emissions in the atmosphere.Tim Upson, the RHSâ€™s director of horticulture, said: â€œWater is the lifeblood of any garden â€“ important not only to human health and wellbeing but the broader environment and wildlife â€“ and we, like the UKâ€™s 34 million gardeners, are having to adapt to the new normal; prioritising collection, storage and management of rainwater as well as relocating and reassessing our collections to future-proof them.â€Upson said the charityâ€™s updated water management plan â€œgets into the nitty-grittyâ€ of where a last bucket of water might be used in each garden. â€œThatâ€™s the reality of the situation we need to prepare for and we would be foolish not to,â€ he said.To understand what grows in its own gardens and advise British gardeners, the RHS is also recording the use of water in different garden landscapes, such as trees, herbaceous perennial borders, turf lawns and vegetable gardens.The RHS said it was using this knowledge to predict water use patterns by these plants and prepare for future planting and water resources management as the climate crisis accelerates.Upson said: â€œThereâ€™s a sweet spot between building plantsâ€™ resilience to withstand drier periods by providing less water, but then thereâ€™s the potential of stressing a plant and leaving them susceptible to plant health issues, not to mention reduced floriferousness, which has a knock-on effect for wildlife and humans.â€Explore more on these topicsWaterClimate crisisGardensDroughtPlantsTrees and forestsEnglandnewsShareReuse this content

title: Police Federation criticises plans for mandatory â€˜licence to practiseâ€™ for officers | Police | The Guardian
description: Crime minister says reforms will improve standards, but Federation says unsafe workloads must be tackled first
Author: Donna Ferguson
Headline: Crime minister says reforms will improve standards, but Federation says unsafe workloads must be tackled first
Content: Licence will create a single standardised framework for officer training, supervision and development, rolled out across all 43 police forces in England and Wales.Photograph: Tolga Akmen/EPAView image in fullscreenLicence will create a single standardised framework for officer training, supervision and development, rolled out across all 43 police forces in England and Wales.Photograph: Tolga Akmen/EPAPolicePolice Federation criticises plans for mandatory â€˜licence to practiseâ€™ for officersCrime minister says reforms will improve standards, but Federation says unsafe workloads must be tackled firstDonna FergusonSat 24 Jan 2026 08.46 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 09.25 ESTShareThe government must stop burdening police officers with unsafe workloads and improve police pay and training if they want â€œprofessionalâ€ policing, the Police Federation has said, in response to sweeping Home Officechanges to improve standardsin the police.Under the new plans, to be unveiled in a white paper on Monday, police officers in England and Wales will be required to hold and renew a â€œlicence to practiseâ€ throughout their career in the future.This will ensure officers â€œstay at the top of their gameâ€ by keeping up to date with the latest â€œproblem solving and technological skills they need to catch more criminalsâ€, theHome Officesaid.Former UK police informer convicted of 38 paedophile offences jailed for lifeRead moreThe licence will create a single standardised framework for officer training, supervision and development, which will be rolled out across all 43 police forces in England and Wales.It would set clear standards in areas including violence against women and girls, neighbourhood policing and leadership expectations for staff, the Home Office said.Officers who repeatedly fail to demonstrate they â€œhave the skills needed to fight crimeâ€ will be sacked.The crime and policing minister Sarah Jones said: â€œEvery police officer needs to remain match-fit to protect their communities. As crime evolves, we expect police to evolve more quickly.View image in fullscreenSarah Jones says the licence reforms will â€˜equip every officer with the skills and capabilitiesâ€™ to do the job.Photograph: Martin Godwin/The Guardianâ€œThe licence to practise will equip every officer with the skills and capabilities to do the job â€“ whether new to the force or a policing veteran.â€But thePolice Federationof England and Wales criticised the plans, saying: â€œEveryone wants professional policing, but that requires pay, training, time and support.â€œOfficers are routinely pulled off mandatory training to plug gaps, work rest days to stay afloat, and carry workloads no one would call safe.â€œWe will await the detail of the white paper but these issues need to be fixed.â€Former Bedfordshire police and crime commissioner Festus Akinbusoye said the plan was unnecessary.Akinbusoye, a former Conservative party candidate, told the Daily Mail: â€œI am genuinely astonished that, of all the crises facing British policing such as collapsing recruitment, appalling retention, failure to get the basics right, deep-rooted cultural problems, and a serious leadership deficit â€“ the Home Office has decided that the answer lies in forcing police officers to hold a licence to practise.â€The changes will form part of what the government has said will be the largest shake-up of the police service since it was founded 200 years ago. Other changes announced include targets for crime fighting, responding to emergency calls and satisfying the victims of crimes, with those performing poorly to be named and shamed.One police chief said national targets, with forces potentially ranked in league tables, could lead to perverse incentives. â€œPeople worry about their position in league tables as opposed to the quality of service,â€ they said. â€œWhat gets measured gets done, and what does not get measured does not get done.â€Another chief said: â€œYou can hit the target and miss the point.â€The government has also announced a graduate recruitment drive, with Â£7m promised to attract students into graduate neighbourhood police officer roles.The home secretary, Shabana Mahmood, will unveil the reforms in the white paper on Monday.Explore more on these topicsPolicePolice FederationHome OfficenewsShareReuse this content

title: Welsh first minister: Senedd election should not be referendum on Starmer | Welsh politics | The Guardian
description: Exclusive: Eluned Morgan says it is not time for protest votes when the economy and public services are at stake
Author: Pippa Crerar
Headline: Exclusive: Eluned Morgan says it is not time for protest votes when the economy and public services are at stake
Content: Eluned Morgan said she would â€˜not retreatâ€™ from fighting for Walesâ€™s priorities â€“ even if they were at odds with the UK governmentâ€™s.Photograph: Zoe Head-Thomas/PAView image in fullscreenEluned Morgan said she would â€˜not retreatâ€™ from fighting for Walesâ€™s priorities â€“ even if they were at odds with the UK governmentâ€™s.Photograph: Zoe Head-Thomas/PAWelsh politicsWelsh first minister: Senedd election should not be referendum on StarmerExclusive: Eluned Morgan says it is not time for protest votes when the economy and public services are at stakePippa CrerarPolitical editorSat 24 Jan 2026 07.00 ESTShareTheLabourfirst minister of Wales has urged voters not to treat the May elections as a referendum on Keir Starmer, calling on them to focus on the countryâ€™s future instead, with the party on course for a fight for third place.Eluned Morgan said it was not the time to send a protest vote to the prime minister when two pro-independence parties â€“ Plaid Cymru and the Greens â€“ could end up in power and so much was at stake for the economy and public services.In an interview with the Guardian, she said she would not retreat from fighting for Walesâ€™s priorities â€“ even if they were at odds with the UK governmentâ€™s. But Labour faces an uphill struggle, withpolls suggestingthe Senedd race could end its decades of dominance in Wales.With Starmer facing renewed leadership pressure from thepotential returnto Westminster of Andy Burnham, she said she was confident the prime minister would â€œget a gripâ€ on running the country after a turbulent first 18 months in power.But she declined to answer whether Starmer should lead the party into the next general election, saying it was in the gift of MPs. â€œThere is no doubt, though, that if Labour performed badly inWalesin May, the heat will be put up on Keir,â€ she said.â€œI do hope that people in this election will recognise that this is not a time to send a protest vote towards Keir Starmer. This is a time where people have to work out what is best for their communities and delivery of services.â€Reform UK and Plaid are on course to win more seats than Labour, reflecting pressure for change among the public after 26 years of Labour control.Morgan, however, argued that 14 of those were under Tory austerity from which Wales was only just emerging. â€œWeâ€™re coming out of it now. Weâ€™ve got decent budgets that allow us to look to the future with hope,â€ she said.â€œWhen youâ€™ve been in power for 26 years, you gain a pretty good idea of how to govern. The UK government are still relatively new in that position, so Iâ€™m confident that they will get a better grip on setting out a clearer strategic vision for the country.â€Morgan welcomed Starmerâ€™stougher tonetowards Donald Trump this week after the US president threatened to impose tariffs. â€œYou have got to stand up to people when they threaten the international legal world order,â€ she said. â€œBut also to recognise that you need to keep a cool head in these circumstances.â€But she would like Starmer to go further with theEU reset, saying it was â€œcriticalâ€ for Wales to have the closest possible trading relationship as 59% of its exports were goods based, compared with 32% for the UK overall.â€œSince weâ€™ve left, proportionately, Wales is impacted more than England, because our economy is one based on goods rather than services. The irony is, of course, that it was those communities that voted for Brexit that have paid the price in terms of jobs because of that reduction in trade.â€On rejoining the EU, she said: â€œNow is not the time to rejoin, but I do think that that should not be off the table in the long term.â€œI want to see the closest possible relationship with the EU. But I donâ€™t think all of that is within our gift. This is about what the EU would be willing to offer us.â€Morgan said she was focusing on the â€œbread and butterâ€ issues in Wales â€“ such as growing the economy and improving public services.Despite criticism of her governmentâ€™s handling of NHS waiting lists, which remain higher than in England, she said they were down 90% since their peak, and that contrasting with England was like â€œcomparing apples with pearsâ€ because the two countries counted differently.Welsh voters should â€œwake upâ€ to the prospect that two pro-independence parties could end up in power in Cardiff, suggesting it would be a â€œmassive distractionâ€ from the day-to-day business of running government.Even though Plaidâ€™s leader, Rhun ap Iorweth, has said a vote for his party would not be taken as an endorsement of independence, Morgan suggested it would be â€œtoo temptingâ€ for him not to pursue it.The implications for prosperity and public services in Wales were â€œdireâ€, she said, because of the Â£14bn funding gap. â€œYou canâ€™t have it both ways. The nationalists are trying to say, â€˜Give us more money Englandâ€™, while we head for the door.â€Turning her sights on Reform UK, which polls suggest is on course to take second place, she warned against the â€œpolitics of anger and divisionâ€, suggesting that Nigel Farage â€œdoesnâ€™t know the first thingâ€ about Wales.She suggested that Reform, in Wales as in the rest of the UK, was on course to be Conservatives 2.0 after so many defections. â€œI hope the people of Wales wonâ€™t be fooled by any suggestion that what youâ€™ve got here is a fresh new party. What youâ€™ve got here is recycled Tories who are on the road to oblivion.â€Explore more on these topicsWelsh politicsEluned MorganLabourDevolutionReform UKPlaid CymruGreen partynewsShareReuse this content

title: Fake weight-loss medication in tablet form could flood Britain, experts warn | Weight-loss drugs | The Guardian
description: Better regulation and enforcement urged before launch of oral treatments, which criminals are likely to try to exploit
Author: Nicola Davis
Headline: Better regulation and enforcement urged before launch of oral treatments, which criminals are likely to try to exploit
Content: Experts say weight-loss medication will be easier for fraudsters to counterfeit than injections.Photograph: Science Photo Library/AlamyView image in fullscreenExperts say weight-loss medication will be easier for fraudsters to counterfeit than injections.Photograph: Science Photo Library/AlamyWeight-loss drugsFake weight-loss medication in tablet form could flood Britain, experts warnBetter regulation and enforcement urged before launch of oral treatments, which criminals are likely to try to exploitNicola DavisScience correspondentSat 24 Jan 2026 05.00 ESTShareExperts are warning that fake weight-loss treatments could become more prevalent as tablet forms of the medications, currently available only via injections in the UK, are launched.They say stronger regulation and enforcement are needed to prevent fraudsters from cashing in on tablets which will be easier to counterfeit.While pill forms of weight-loss medications are expectedto be much cheaper, and hence more accessible than injectable versions, experts have warned they are also an easier target for fraudsters.â€œPills are much easier prey for scammers than injectables as they require relatively accessible equipment to manufacture the pill â€“ something to mix the powders and a pill press â€“ and can provide the scope for vast production,â€ said Bhavik Patel, a professor of clinical and bioanalytical chemistry at the University of Brighton.In the UK, the demand forweight-loss jabs such as Wegovy and Mounjarohas grown, with trials suggesting they can help people lose on averageabout 14% and 20%of their body weight respectively after 72 weeks.However, the jabs are expensive, require an injection pen and needles, and must be refrigerated.Now pharmaceutical companies are working on oral versions of the medications, creating tablets containing drugs that mimic the hormone GLP-1.A pill form of Wegovy, produced by Novo Nordisk, was approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) last month and is under assessment by the UKâ€™s Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA), while Orforglipron from Eli Lillyhas completed phase-three clinical trialsand has beensubmitted to the FDAfor review.How weight-loss wonder drugs are redefining the way our bodies workRead moreDr Bernard Naughton, an associate professor and researcher in pharmaceutical regulation and innovation at Trinity College Dublin, said counterfeit pills could include medications taken out of the legitimate supply chain â€“ and potentially stored incorrectly â€“ while they could also be contaminated, or contain an incorrect dose, incorrect active ingredient or no active ingredient at all.â€œWe can see already that there have been some examples of the injections being falsified,â€ said Naughton. â€œItâ€™s relatively easy to just create a pill and, if youâ€™ve got good packaging, to falsely put it forward as the legitimate product.â€Naughton saidhis own researchof patient behaviour with other medications has suggested people seemed more likely and more willing to take a risk online with tablets than injections.â€œSo even when they think there might be something wrong, I have seen examples of people still going ahead and actually buying it and taking it,â€ he said.Novo Nordisk said its Wegovy pill not only contained the active ingredient semaglutide, but also a substance called SNAC (salcaprozate sodium) that enhances the absorption of the drug.â€œOnly Novo Nordisk manufactures FDA-approved semaglutide medicines with this SNAC technology,â€ a spokesperson said. â€œCompounded semaglutide is not approved by the FDA and may contain impurities, unnecessary additives, and untested doses.â€There is a precedent for fake weight-loss medications, with the MHRA havingrepeatedly issued warningsof the importance of buying jabs only from registered pharmacies or legitimate retailers.Oksana Pyzik, an associate professor at the UCL school of pharmacy, said demand for medications such as Wegovy and Mounjaro had outpaced regulated supply, whileprice rises for some productshave also been linked to people seeking cheaper alternatives online via unlicensed routes.â€œWhile oral weight-loss drugs may improve access, it will also widen opportunity for criminals to falsify GLP-1s,â€ she said.In October last yearthe MHRA revealedit had carried out a raid on a factory in Northampton, seizing more than Â£250,000 worth of counterfeit weight-loss jabs, including injection pens for the experimental drug retatrutide, which is not licensed in the UK.At present it is unclear whether any arrests or prosecutions have been made in connection with the raid, with the MHRA saying it is unable to disclose information regarding ongoing investigations.However, aGuardian investigationrevealed the company whose name featured on the packaging of the jabs, Alluvi, has continued to advertise its branded retatrutide pens on the social media platform Telegram.Patel said the recent raid showed the MHRA was highly proactive in protecting the public from counterfeit medicines. â€œHowever, the use of social media and online marketplaces provides a widespread access to consumers who wish to access the medicines, and this does pose a risk,â€ he said.â€œWith the huge demand there will be [for] the pills, this will really stretch the UK Border Force and MHRA, as the scale is likely to be greater than injectables and we may not be able to completely eradicate these counterfeit products entering our market.â€Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk said they were taking action to combat counterfeits, with the latter noting that for the pill form of Wegovy this included online monitoring and removing, for example, websites or posts; sharing information about the pillâ€™s supply chain flow and characteristics with authorities; and providing sample pills to the FDAâ€™s Forensic Chemistry Center for testing and further investigations if needed.Andy Morling, deputy director of enforcement at the MHRA, said medicines for weight management must meet rigorous standards of safety, quality and effectiveness before they could be authorised for use in the UK.â€œWe are working tirelessly through robust regulatory and enforcement processes to identify and take action against the illegal supply of unauthorised and falsified medicines, ensuring the UK legal supply chain remains strong, responsive and effective as new treatment formats become available,â€ he said.â€œAuthorised medicines are subject to robust regulatory processes and ongoing oversight, including controls on how they are manufactured, supplied and monitored once on the market. Any medicine supplied illegally or without authorisation poses a risk to public health and patent safety, regardless of its format.â€Pyzik, who is academic chair of theFight the Fakes Alliance, said that the UK was beginning to use AI tools to detect falsified online adverts, but stronger regulation and enforcement were neededâ€œPatients need to know that they should only access these products with a prescription, under medical supervision and to avoid purchasing any pharmaceuticals on social media,â€ she said.Pyzik added there had been a shift from falsified medical products being imported into the UK to increasingly sophisticated domestic operations.â€œWhen an illicit counterfeit factory can be raided, shut down, and then reappear online shortly afterwards apparently with no arrests or prosecutions as of yet, that is not a functioning deterrent and exposes real regulatory gaps,â€ she said.â€œNot only does it signal to criminal groups that the risk of prosecution is low and the rewards are high, but emboldens them to break further laws and take even more drastic measures to sell falsified pharmaceuticals.â€Naughton said that, among other actions, the UK should ensure it was easy for patients to verify that they were buying medications from a legitimate online pharmacy â€“ and develop public health campaigns targetting groups with different motivations and attitudes to risk when it comes to buying medications online.â€œI think thatâ€™s really important because there is value in buying medicines online, and it provides access to lots of people who wouldnâ€™t have access otherwise,â€ he said.Explore more on these topicsWeight-loss drugsPharmaceuticals industrynewsShareReuse this content

title: Why it has not been so easy being green for the white van in the UK  | Electric, hybrid and low-emission cars | The Guardian
description: Electric van sales are behind government targets, but those fleets that have switched are seeing a real difference
Author: Jasper Jolly
Headline: Electric van sales are behind government targets, but those fleets that have switched are seeing a real difference
Content: Jordane Roach, an Openreach engineer, says: â€˜This is so much easier to drive. Iâ€™d never go back to diesel.â€™Photograph: Graeme Robertson/The GuardianView image in fullscreenJordane Roach, an Openreach engineer, says: â€˜This is so much easier to drive. Iâ€™d never go back to diesel.â€™Photograph: Graeme Robertson/The GuardianElectric, hybrid and low-emission carsWhy it has not been so easy being green for the white van in the UKElectric van sales are behind government targets, but those fleets that have switched are seeing a real differenceJasper JollySat 24 Jan 2026 09.00 ESTShareSwinging a fully laden electric van around a training centre in Bishopâ€™s Stortford feels easy, with instant acceleration that belies the racks of heavy equipment in the back. Perhaps too easy, as the sudden shriek of its proximity sensor suggests the Guardian was a whisker away from a bill for some new paintwork.The van in question belongs to Openreach, BTâ€™s fibre broadband subsidiary. It is one of 6,000 electric vans out of 23,400 in Britainâ€™s second-largest commercial fleet â€“ and a further 1,000 are expected to be added by March.The shift away from polluting diesel engines to electric will play a crucial role in the UKâ€™s efforts to cut carbon emissions from vans â€“ which werelast recordedat 18m tonnes or 12% of all transport emissions in 2023.Yet while the transition is moving forward for some of the biggest fleets, on a UK-wide level electric van sales have lagged behind expectations. For the white van, it has not been so easy being green.On the face of it, electric van sales are behind government sales targets, known as the zero-emission vehicle (ZEV) mandate â€“echoing the situation for car sales. In 2025, the headline target was for 16% of new vans sold in Great Britain to be electric. Manufacturers only managed 9.5%, while struggling with an overall van market that slumped by 10%, according to figures published this week. That has led to a battle between manufacturers and some of the biggest buyers over how quickly Britain should make the switch.For some fleets it makes sense. Royal Mail has theUKâ€™s biggest commercial fleet, with about 43,000 vehicles. Posties drive pretty much the same route every day, before bringing their vehicles to a depot overnight. This pattern â€“ with predictable mileage and a base to recharge â€“ makes it easy to choose a van with the right size of battery, saving costs.As well as 8,000 mid-sized electric vans, in the last month the company has also started using micro-electric vehicles â€“ essentially rugged golf carts â€“ and heavy electric lorries. Together those could cover the entire parcel journey with zero direct emissions.View image in fullscreenA Paxster micro-electric vehicle in Royal Mail livery. The vehicles will be used for Royal Mail deliveries and collections in some urban areas.Photograph: James Linsell Clark/SWNSCost savings are the driving force for those companies which have switched. European sole traders â€“ the white-vanman, or womanâ€“ would save about â‚¬14,000 (Â£12,200) over three years relative to a diesel equivalent, according to a2024 studyby the Centre for Economics and Business Research (which was commissioned byFord, seller of many more diesel Transitsthan electric models).Upfront costs are still markedly more expensive â€“ an E-Transit Custom starts at Â£43,630, compared with Â£33,750 for the cheapest diesel. Most of the savings from going electric come from charging being more cost-effective than diesel. Large fleets are also in a strong position to negotiate steep discounts â€“ large-scale fleet buyers can get as much as a quarter off the list price when committing to a big order.However, charging is difficult for some drivers, particularly if they have to rely on public chargers. Openreach installs home chargers for employees where it can, and also has deals to use other companiesâ€™ connections when their depots are empty during the day. Bulk charging deals mean it can get cheaper rates at public chargers when engineers are out and about.EV graphicSitting in the converted telephone exchange building in Bishopâ€™s Stortford, Judy Oâ€™Keefe, director of fleet at Openreach, said she valued the reliability of electric vehicles, avoiding roadside rescues which can cost Â£500 a pop.â€œThey are way more reliable,â€ she said. â€œBreakdowns, being left on the side of the road at night, are significantly down. Long term, the EV is the right way to go in terms of maintenance and servicing alone.â€Butrange anxietyis perhaps the main reason people are holding back. Oâ€™Keefe said that some engineers have been concerned about not having enough charge, but looking at fleet data, â€œI can see that engineerâ€™s data and say, it is enoughâ€.Nevertheless, there is still clearly some way to go to persuade the majority of buyers to consider a green van. Yet as with the ZEV mandate for cars, the missed headline targets are not quite what they seem. The mandate has â€œflexibilitiesâ€ â€“ handy loopholes that allow manufacturers to gain â€œcreditsâ€ that allow them to sell more vehicles with petrol and diesel engines. They can earn credits by cutting the emissions of the petrol and diesel vehicles they sell (a strong incentive to sell more plug-in hybrids), and they can sell more electric vehicles in later years to catch up. To complicate matters further, manufacturers can swap credits between their cars and vans.The thinktank New Automotive has estimated that the actual target for last year was not 16%, but closer to 9.35%. If the estimates are correct it would suggest manufacturers are on track to avoid costly fines if they fail to comply. However, Mikes Hawes, chief executive of the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders lobby group, disputes that, saying the numbers are â€œsignificantly adrift of ambitionâ€.Whatever the flexibilities, the headline targets do increase quickly. For 2026, the headline target is 24%, and it will reach 70% in 2030, before sales of petrol and diesel vans are banned in 2035.The big van makers in the UK are Ford, Stellantis (owner of the Peugeot, CitroÃ«n, Fiat and Vauxhall brands, among others) and Volkswagen â€“ although,as in the car market, Chinese rivals are ruffling feathers, with Maxus recording fast growth.View image in fullscreenOpenreach, BTâ€™s fibre broadband subsidiary, has 6,000 electric vans, Britainâ€™s second-largest commercial fleet.Photograph: Graeme Robertson/The GuardianStellantis is the only company that still makes vans in Britain, at a plant in Ellesmere Port, Cheshire. However, Stellantis also exemplifies the difficulties facing European van manufacturers: in April itclosed a factory in Lutonthat previously made Vauxhall Vivaro vans. It partly blamed the mandate, although some industry experts believed that Stellantis had too much capacity across Europe to meet lower demand.Eurig Druce, UK group managing director for Stellantis, said the company is â€œmore than compliantâ€ with the rules once flexibilities are accounted for, but the complexity of the regulatory calculation â€œalmost makes running the business a gameâ€.â€œWe are as an industry considerably short of where the mandate sets out,â€ he said. â€œThe reality for the majority of manufacturers in the UK is theyâ€™re struggling to comply. The take-up has been slower than any of us would have liked.â€Druce argued that the government should remove a cap on the number of electric van grants each buyer can use, but also that it should â€œreview the trajectoryâ€ of targets as soon as possible. Otherwise the UK would â€œput in danger the investment in manufacturing in this countryâ€.â€œThe market is not willing to follow,â€ said Druce. â€œThe consumers do not follow at the rate of the trajectory.â€However, some companies â€“ including energy companies Ovo andSSE,as well as Openreach,have argued the opposite: they want electric vans as soon as possible. Abby Chicken, Openreachâ€™s head of sustainability, said an end to the â€œgovernment oscillations over the last five yearsâ€ would be helpful. However, she added that â€œthe business case looks goodâ€ for switching to electric â€“ alongside the â€œmoral imperativeâ€ to cut carbon emissions.View image in fullscreenAbby Chicken, Openreachâ€™s head of sustainability, said the business case looks good for switching to electric â€“ alongside the â€˜moral imperativeâ€™ to cut carbon emissions.Photograph: Graeme Robertson/The GuardianDominic Phinn, head of transport at the Climate Group, which runs the EV100 campaign to get big fleets to switch, said that its members â€“ which include Tesco, British Gas owner Centrica, Lloyds Banking Group, and Next â€“ â€œcanâ€™t get enoughâ€ of electric vans.â€œIt feels like another attempt by the automotive sector to slow things down,â€ said Phinn. â€œTheyâ€™ll all snap into line. Weâ€™ve seen this time and time again.â€Ben Nelmes, chief executive of New Automotive, said that van makers of all stripes are under pressure because there is too little demand to use all their factory capacity.â€œMost van makers still are making less profit on their electric van sales than they are on their diesel van sales,â€ said Nelmes. â€œThey are doing everything they can to boost their margins.â€The vans used for a few years by the big fleets will eventually hit the secondhand market, giving sole traders electric options. For those who actually drive the vans, there is little appetite to switch back once they have had a go.â€œThis is so much easier to drive,â€ said Jordane Roach, an Openreach engineer demonstrating how to wire up a broadband connection. â€œItâ€™s so much better. Iâ€™d never go back to a diesel.â€Explore more on these topicsElectric, hybrid and low-emission carsAutomotive industryGreenhouse gas emissionsMotoring (Technology)Motoring (Money)featuresShareReuse this content

title: Syrian and Kurdish forces agree to extend ceasefire as threat of war looms | Syria | The Guardian
description: Ceasefire to be extended for one month to allow transfer of suspected Islamic State members from Syria to Iraq
Author: William Christou
Headline: Ceasefire to be extended for one month to allow transfer of suspected Islamic State members from Syria to Iraq
Content: Members of Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) arrive at the Kurdish-held city of Kobane after withdrawing from the Al-Aqtan prison in the Raqa province of Syria.Photograph: AFP/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenMembers of Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) arrive at the Kurdish-held city of Kobane after withdrawing from the Al-Aqtan prison in the Raqa province of Syria.Photograph: AFP/Getty ImagesSyriaSyrian and Kurdish forces agree to extend ceasefire as threat of war loomsCeasefire to be extended for one month to allow transfer of suspected Islamic State members from Syria to IraqWilliam Christouin Deir el-ZourSat 24 Jan 2026 07.47 ESTShareThe Syrian government and Kurdish forces agreed to extend a ceasefire on Saturday, according to Syrian diplomatic sources, temporarily staving off a looming war between the two sides in the north-east of the country.Sources told Agence France-Presse the ceasefire would be extended for â€œa period of up to one month at mostâ€, citing the need to facilitate the transfer of suspected members ofIslamic Statefrom Syria to Iraq.Kurdish forces withdraw from IS detention camp in north-east SyriaRead moreThe two sides had announced a temporary ceasefire earlier in the week, halting an offensive by the Syrian government which brought its army to the door of the Kurdish Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF). The announcement quelled concerns the offensive would restart on Saturday and gave more space for diplomacy, but did not solve the root cause of the conflict between the two sides.Fighting over three contested neighbourhoods inAleppoin early January led to a sweeping government offensive in which the SDF lost the majority of its territory in the country in a matter of days.The ceasefire was meant to give time for the SDF to implement a 14-point plan with the Syrian government under which the Kurdish militia would disband and its soldiers integrate into the Syrian army.If the SDF did not implement the agreement, Damascus would resume its offensive and push toward the last strongholds of the SDF in Hasakeh, and the Kurdish-majority areas of Qamishli and Kobane.The two sides spent the ceasefire preparing for the eventuality of a full-scale war.SDF forces built up in Kurdish-majority areas while its leaders called for a general mobilisation among residents there, distributing weapons to those willing to take up arms.View image in fullscreenA protester at a demonstration in the northern Iraqi Kurdish city of Sulaimaniyah to oppose the deployment of Syrian government forces in formerly Kurdish-led areas in Syria.Photograph: Shwan Mohammed/AFP/Getty ImagesSyrian government soldiers and tanks streamed towards the frontline, hoping to bring the north-east under the control of Damascus. â€œSoon we will be in Hasakeh and then Qamishli, God willing,â€ a soldier said on Thursday while standing guard as logistics convoys moved towards the Hasakeh front.As soldiers waited on the battlefield, Syrian officials and regional powers were engaged in a bout of diplomacy to avoid resuming the war. The SDF leader, Mazloum Abdi, went to Iraqi Kurdistan for the second time, where he met the US envoy for Syria, Tom Barrack, who has been mediating talks between the SDF and Damascus.Abdi also spoke on the phone to the Syrian foreign minister, Asaad al-Shaibani, which was followed by an agreement allowing the safe transfer of SDF fighters from a besieged prison in Syrian government-controlled territory.â€œIdeally, the transfer of Daesh [Islamic State] prisoners from Syria should take place. While this is happening, the existing non-conflict environment needs to be maintained,â€ the Turkish foreign minister, Hakan Fidan, said on Friday, referring to the US-facilitated transfer of more than 7,000 suspected IS members and fighters from Syria to Iraq.Disputes between the two sides remain even with the ceasefire extension. The 14-point plan would bring an end to the autonomous Syrian Kurdish project, and Kurdish leaders seemed to struggle to come to terms with their losses over the last two weeks, which has left them with little leverage.The SDF went from controlling nearly a third of the country, including its oil fields, breadbasket and key infrastructure, to just a few cities. The deal on the table would turn the Kurdish force, which not so long ago boasted of being 100,000 strong, into essentially a municipality overseeing a local police force running a few Kurdish cities in the north-east of the country.Abdi, long known as a pragmatic figure among the SDF, has signalled he would be willing to implement the deal.He is struggling, however, to gain consensus within the SDF.If he is unable to unify the SDF and implement the agreement with the government, then the alternative would be war. Damascus has made it clear it would no longer tolerate non-state armed groups and is determined to unify the country under its flag, either through negotiations or force.The US, which has backed the Kurdish force for the past decade, has made its support for Damascus clear, with Barrack saying the SDFâ€™s role as the anti-IS force in Syria had now been filled by the Syrian government.View image in fullscreenThe president of Iraqi Kurdistan, Nechirvan Barzani (right), meets the head of the SDF), Mazloum Abdi, in Erbil.Photograph: Iraqi Kurdistan Presidency/AFP/Getty ImagesThe US military has already began transferring IS prisoners from Kurdish territories to prevent any escapes ahead of a renewed war with Damascus. Once IS prisoners are secured, there will be little strategic interests left for a US military presence in north-east Syria.Even if Damascus has the military advantage and regional backing, it is still hoping to prevent a war. Its offensive so far has led to relatively few casualties, as the SDF has opted to withdraw from Arab-majority areas such as Raqqa and Deir el-Zour rather than confront the Syrian government.Fighting in Kurdish-majority areas is likely to be more bloody.There is fear among Kurdish civilians of the Syrian government fighters, after government-backedmassacres in Druze-majority Suweida province and in the Alawite-majority Syrian coastlast year.Many residents in Kurdish-majority areas have armed themselves. Kurdish forces have dug in, having prepared for this fight for years, creating a vast subterranean tunnel network to facilitate guerrilla fighting against a better armed force.Damascus is aware that even if it wins the war, it could drive away the Kurds, push the SDF underground and create a insurgency similar to that of the Kurdistan Workersâ€™ Party (PKK) in Turkey for years to come.Explore more on these topicsSyriaMiddle East and north AfricaIslamic StateAlepponewsShareReuse this content

title: â€˜I wish I had the power to ease his sufferingâ€™: Gazaâ€™s cancer patients trapped by war and blockade | Gaza | The Guardian
description: Thousands of Palestinian cancer patients are living without treatment as they await medical evacuation
Author: Sufian Taha
Headline: Thousands of Palestinian cancer patients are living without treatment as they await medical evacuation
Content: Aya Abu Hani with her son Ismail Abu Naji, who has been diagnosed with blood cancer and has been unable to leave Gaza for treatment.Photograph: Amjed Tantesh/The GuardianView image in fullscreenAya Abu Hani with her son Ismail Abu Naji, who has been diagnosed with blood cancer and has been unable to leave Gaza for treatment.Photograph: Amjed Tantesh/The GuardianGazaâ€˜I wish I had the power to ease his sufferingâ€™: Gazaâ€™s cancer patients trapped by war and blockadeThousands of Palestinian cancer patients are living without treatment as they await medical evacuationLorenzo Tondoin Jerusalem,Seham Tanteshin Gaza andSufian Tahain NablusSat 24 Jan 2026 06.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 06.02 ESTShareWhen theGazawar began, Ismail Abu Naji was just 18 months old, his small body covered in swollen, bleeding lesions. Months earlier, doctors had diagnosed him with a rare blood cancer, one that, if untreated, is often a death sentence.In the weeks before the war, Ismailâ€™s family had arranged for him to be transferred to Al-Makassed hospital in Jerusalem, a charitable institution for Palestinians, for specialised care. But the blockade Israel imposed on Gaza after Hamasâ€™s 7 October 2023 attack that triggered the conflict meant Ismail could not leave the territory.He is now one ofthousands of cancer patients in Gazawho the UN says require medical evacuation for urgent treatment.The Guardian has spoken to dozens of Palestinian cancer patients trapped in Gaza, where doctors say cancer-related deaths have tripled since the war began, as Israel continues to hinder patients from leaving and restricts the entry of chemotherapy drugs. While some patients have left, they are far outnumbered by those deemed in medical need who have not. The Israeli NGO Physicians for Human Rights Israel (PHRI) says evacuation routes to third countries have become â€œnear impossibleâ€ to operate, especially since the closure of the Rafah crossing in May 2024, and that Israel is failing to meet its obligation to provide medical care to populations under its control. The crossing between Gaza and Egypt is due to open for traffic next week, the Palestinian technocratic committee leader, Ali Shaath, said on Thursday, although Israel did not immediately confirm that would be the case.View image in fullscreenIsmail Abu Naji is covered in painful swollen, bleeding lesions caused by a rare blood cancer.Photograph: Family handout/The GuardianWith even basic painkillers having become unattainable under the blockade, there is little else Ismailâ€™s mother, Aya Mohammed Abu Hani, who is living in a tent in a school,can do but try to ease his pain, gently dabbing the wounds with a cloth soaked in salt water.â€œIsmailâ€™s life before the war was already difficult, and it has become even harsher since. He cannot sleep due to severe pain, high fever and cries constantly,â€ she told the Guardian. â€œWe were displaced many times from one place to another, which worsened his condition. I could not even provide him with enough clothing. Before the war, hospitals were able to offer antibiotics and painkillers. But now, they canâ€™t even provide a single painkiller.â€Israeli airstrikes on hospitals have reduced the Palestinian healthcare system to ruins. In March 2025,Israel destroyed Gazaâ€™s only specialised cancer treatment hospital, the territoryâ€™s sole provider of oncology care. Since then, doctors have been pushed into makeshift clinics, operating with almost no resources, including the tools needed for diagnosis.â€œAs for cancer diagnosis, we have reached an extremely critical stage,â€ said Dr Saleh Sheikh al-Eid, a specialist physician in haematology and oncology at Nasser medical complex in Khan Younis. â€œBasic diagnostic tools, such as biopsy needles, are unavailable. Patients come to us with obvious cancerous masses, yet we lack the means to take samples and examine them. As a result, we have lost many patients without even being able to properly diagnose or treat them.â€Despite recent ceasefire agreements intended to facilitate the entry of aid, essential medical supplies remain restricted.â€œWe receive repeated warnings from the pharmacy that essential chemotherapy drugs are close to running out,â€ al-Eid says. â€œThe resources available to us do not exceed 5% of those available in hospitals in the West Bank, and in many cases they are almost nonexistent.â€Living with a cancer diagnosis and the uncertainty of survival is, in itself, a traumatic experience. Going through such an ordeal while trapped in a war zone, cut off from essential medication and under constant Israeli bombardment, can be unbearable. While airstrikes have slowed since the US-brokered ceasefire in October,they have not stopped. Israeli forces have killed at least 466 Palestinians in the last three months.All the while, friends and family members of cancer patients have died during the bombardments.The pain of losing her granddaughter, killed in an Israeli bombardment, accompanies Fathiya Abu Frieh, 65, every day.
