title: My cultural awakening: A Queen song helped me break free from communist Cuba | Queen | The Guardian
description: Listening to Brian Mayâ€™s multi-tracked epic on a battered cassette player when I lived in repressive Havana inspired lit a spark of rebellion inside me
Author: Emma Loffhagen
Headline: Listening to Brian Mayâ€™s multi-tracked epic on a battered cassette player when I lived in repressive Havana inspired lit a spark of rebellion inside me
Content: Illustration: Martin O'Neill/The GuardianView image in fullscreenIllustration: Martin O'Neill/The GuardianMy cultural awakeningQueenMy cultural awakening: A Queen song helped me break free from communist CubaListening to Brian Mayâ€™s multi-tracked epic on a battered cassette player when I lived in repressive Havana inspired lit a spark of rebellion inside meMario LÃ³pez-Goicoechea; as told toEmma LoffhagenSat 24 Jan 2026 02.00 ESTShareThroughout my childhood and teenage years growing up in 80s Cuba, Fidel Castroâ€™s presence, and the overt influence of politics, was everywhere â€“ on posters, on walls, in speeches that could last four hours at a stretch. The sense of being hemmed in, politically and personally, was hard to escape.I had been raised to believe in communism, and for a long time I did. I even applied twice to join the Young Communist League, only to be rejected for not being â€œcombativeâ€ enough: code for not informing on others. Friends were expelled from university or jailed for speaking too freely and my family included people in the military and police, so I had to be careful not toÂ endanger them. But amid that stifling conformity, something else had begun to take hold.When I was 13, my first girlfriendâ€™s father, a sailor, brought back LPs fromÂ abroad. Through those records, IÂ discovered rockâ€™nâ€™roll. In Cuba at the time, that was no small thing. Western music arrived years late, passed hand to hand through a black market of cassette tapes copied and recopied.It wasnâ€™t without risk: IÂ know people who went to jail just forÂ listening to the Beatles or the Rolling StonesBy the time I reached my fourth year of secondary school, music had become an obsession. Four or five of us made an unspoken pact to seek it out wherever we could. We held listening sessions in each otherâ€™s homes and gathered at an arts centre every Saturday night, where local bands played or taped rock blared from speakers. It wasnâ€™t without risk: IÂ know people who went to jail just forÂ listening to the Beatles or the Rolling Stones. Long hair, bracelets, necklaces â€“ any hint of â€œwestern proclivitiesâ€ â€“ could land you in the back of a van for the night.I was 15 in 1986, living in a one-bed flat in Havana that I shared with my mother, grandmother, aunt and cousin, when I discovered The Prophetâ€™s Song byQueen. Iâ€™d heard of the band, but IÂ had never listened to them properly. AÂ friend had sourced A Night at the Opera for me, photocopying the inlay with the lyrics included. I listened to itÂ on a battered mono cassette player with a single speaker, hardly ideal for an album so carefully constructed.And yet, from the opening notes, itÂ stopped me cold. The song begins gently, with soft guitar chords, before shifting into something more frenetic. Then Freddie Mercuryâ€™s voice arrives: possessed, prophetic, as if rallying an unseen crowd; his voice had this beautiful urgency, singing about aÂ vision he had.Then came the moment that changed everything. Brian Mayâ€™s delay effect multiplies Mercuryâ€™s voice â€“ â€œNow IÂ know, now I knowâ€ â€“ so it echoes into itself, ghostlike and disembodied. Even through that tinny speaker, it was otherworldly. For eight minutes, the noise of Havana fell away. In that cramped flat, surrounded by family andÂ surveillance, a crack opened.What moved me wasnâ€™t just the sound, but what it represented. AÂ Night at the Opera was Queenâ€™s first album after falling out with their management. They were given creative freedom. Until then, my world had been bound by â€œsocialism or deathâ€, words still painted on Havanaâ€™s walls. Suddenly, IÂ too felt the freedom to imagine something different. The inspiration for the song, written by Brian May, wasÂ a fever dream he had while recovering from an illness. In a way, the track became my own personal convalescence.My cultural awakening: Losing My Religion by REM helped me escape a doomsday cultRead moreI didnâ€™t immediately become aÂ dissident. But I kept that kernel of rebellion inside me. Rock music pulled me through the late 80s, through the fear of conscription, through the brutalÂ 90s when friends drowned trying to leave Cuba on homemade boats. I went on to study English andÂ ran a successful, but risky, black-market translation business (if caught, I would have ended up in jail unless I bribed my way out of it). This business also included city tours, not only in English but in French and German too. Eventually I made my way to the UK in 1997: I met my British (now ex-) wife in Havana and we were married for more than two decades. It was the early years of New Labour, and being in a relationship with a British citizen made moving here easier. I live inÂ London now, a writer, teacher and cycling instructor, with grownup children of my own.I still listen to The Prophetâ€™s Song. ItÂ opened my ears not only to rock, but genres such as jazz. Most importantly, it spurred my curiosity, and the idea that life could be lived in a way that didnâ€™t conform. In the middle of all that noise, it was the one thing that cutÂ through.Share your cultural awakeningsShare your experiencesYou can tell us how a cultural moment has prompted you to make a major life change by filling in the form below or emailing us onÂ cultural.awakening@theguardian.com.Please share your story if you are 18 or over, anonymously if you wish. A cohort of 20 young artists and writers visitedAsean Heritage Parksin their own countries to tell stories of biodiversity, nature and culture.Aung first travelled toInlay Lake Wildlife Sanctuary, known for its floating gardens, in 2022. â€œThe Intha people live around the lake and build floating houses: structures made from bamboo on stilts,â€ Aung says. â€œFishing is a common occupation; they use their feet to paddle their boats. title: Lajuana is 89, with the body and mind of someone decades younger. What are the secrets of the superagers? | Ageing | The Guardian
description: Why do some people age better than others? Five extraordinary individuals â€“ who scientists are studying â€“ share their tips
Author: Isabelle Aron
Headline: Why do some people age better than others? Five extraordinary individuals â€“ who scientists are studying â€“ share their tips
Content: â€˜I concentrate on how good it is to be aliveâ€™: Lajuana Weathers in Illinois.Photograph: Lucy Hewett/The GuardianView image in fullscreenâ€˜I concentrate on how good it is to be aliveâ€™: Lajuana Weathers in Illinois.Photograph: Lucy Hewett/The GuardianAgeingLajuana is 89, with the body and mind of someone decades younger. What are the secrets of the superagers?Why do some people age better than others? Five extraordinary individuals â€“ who scientists are studying â€“ share their tipsIsabelle AronSat 24 Jan 2026 01.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 16.46 ESTShareLajuana Weathers is determined toÂ be the healthiest version of herself. She starts each day with a celery juice, is always trying to increase her step count, and meditates daily. Weathers is also 89Â years old. And she has no plans to slow down. â€œIÂ wake up in the morning and feel blessed that I have another chance at a day of life,â€ says the grandmother of six, and greatâ€‘grandmother of six more, who lives in Illinois in an independent living facility for seniors. â€œI look at my life as a holistic entity, and in that life is my physical, social, emotional and spiritual wellbeing. I have to take care of all of those. Thatâ€™s what I like about the ageing process. All the clutter of raising children is out and IÂ can concentrate on the wellness of me.â€Weathers is a superager. This isnâ€™t a self-proclaimed label, but one backed up by science â€“ she is part of theSuperAging Research Initiativeat the University of Chicago. To qualify for the study, you have to be over 80 years old and have memory performance thatâ€™s at least as good as the average 50- to 60-year-old. There are about 400 superagers enrolled across North America.As life expectancy increases, many of us are keen to know how to stay healthy in our older years. According tofigures from the Office for National Statistics(ONS), the average life expectancy in the UK is 79.1 years for men and 83 for women. Thelatest ONS projectionsshow that those born recently will live even longer â€“ boys born in the UK in 2023 can expect to live, on average, to 86.7 years and girls to 90 years, while 11.5% of boys and 17.9% of girls born in 2023 are expected to live to at least 100. In recent years, there has been an increasing interest in longevity and healthspan â€“ the period of life spent in good health â€“ rather than lifespan, which is the total number of years lived. So what can this growing area of research tell us about why some age better than others? What can we learn from the superagers?Enrolment in the SuperAging Research Initiative takes three to four days. It includes a paperâ€‘and-pencil test that assesses memory, attention, language and different aspects of cognition, as well as sharing a detailed family history. An MRI brain scan and a blood test provide data on genetic factors, bloodâ€‘based biomarkers such as risk level for Alzheimerâ€™s, and the immune system. â€œWe integrate data across brain structure and function, molecular and genetic measures, lifestyle, medical history, psychosocial factors, family history and other factors to understand how these elements interact to support exceptional cognitive ageing,â€ explains Dr Emily Rogalski, director of the initiative.We set the bar high. Weâ€™re looking for people who are truly uniqueThe goal isnâ€™t to study these people for the sake of it, but to use the findings to benefit everyone. â€œIf this rare population has something in common, it could be translated to be beneficial to the general population,â€ says Rogalski. â€œIf you find a protective factor, then you say, â€˜How do we turn this protective factor on in the mainstream population to boost chances of living long and living well?â€™â€There isnâ€™t yet the data to say what percentage of the population are superagers. â€œWhat we can say is that of the people who think that they are superagers, less than 10% end up meeting the criteria. We set the bar high. Weâ€™re looking for people who are truly unique.â€Weathers doesnâ€™t seem like your average 89-year-old. With a short crop of white hair, red lipstick and a beaming smile, she is full of energy and positivity, and seems younger than her years. â€œI concentrate on how good it is to be alive,â€ she says. â€œI have a â€˜count my blessingsâ€™ attitude. I intend to be happy and I have the power to orchestrate that.â€ She loves clothes and has no interest in what society says she â€œshouldâ€ wear at her age. â€œI dress in what satisfies me,â€ she says. To boost her mood, she plays choral music in her apartment and sings along. The eldest of three sisters, she is often mistaken for the youngest (who is 85; the middle sister is 87). She proudly tells me that she takes only one pill â€“ at her doctorâ€™s insistence â€“ for blood pressure and feels so well that she has plans to negotiate with her doctor about phasing that out. She talks passionately about enjoying this â€œseasonâ€ of her life and constantly trying to better herself.After the researchers mentioned that colouringÂ and word searches would be beneficial for her cognitive function, Weathers started doing both every day. â€œIâ€™mÂ trying to do anything I can do to enhance my cognitive ability â€“ well, all abilities,â€ she says. She has been in the study for two years, after hearing about it at an event and reaching out to see if she would qualify. â€œI felt that they were in a good place to research whatâ€™s happening with the older generation so that they can help the younger generations and slow downÂ debilitating diseases. My mother died at 33, my brothers died at 19 and 61, and my father at 62, so I wanted the opportunity to share whatâ€™s happening with me,â€ she says.Colouring is one of the many activities in Weathersâ€™ packed schedule. She walks outside if the weather is nice â€“ if not, she gets her steps in around the corridors of her building, starting with a 40-minute walk each morning and another walk after dinner. She does about 6,000 or 7,000 steps a day, but her goal is to get to 10,000. She does occupational therapy twice a week to work on her physical health, and goes to a weekly wellness class where she has learned about nutrition, preparing food and how to â€œstackâ€ her foods. â€œThe body uses fibre first, then protein, starches and sugar. I stack my food in that order, so my body can process it better,â€ she says. She doesnâ€™t eat refined sugar or gluten, and follows a largely plant-based diet, with some fish and chicken. She is involved in her local church and, as a vocal technician, she loves music and still works with choirs in her area. â€œIf they call me, Iâ€™m there. For my 90th, Iâ€™m going to conduct the choir at church,â€ she says.View image in fullscreenâ€˜I never thought of myself as anything specialâ€™: Ralph Rehbock at his home in Northbrook, Illinois.Photograph: Lucy Hewett/The GuardianLike Weathers, Ralph Rehbock is aÂ superagerÂ with a busy schedule. He keeps track of it on a paper calendar, where he writes down appointments, singing rehearsals and social visits. Aged 91, Rehbock lives in the Chicago suburbs with his wife. Born in Gotha, Germany, he fled the Nazis in 1938 when he was four â€“ his parents found a sponsor so that they could move to the US. Today, Rehbock shares the story of his escape with others. Heâ€™s the first viceâ€‘president at the Illinois Holocaust Museum, for which he does talks, in person and on Zoom.As well as his work with the museum, Rehbock is part of Men Enjoying Leisure (MEL), a social group for male retirees, which was set up 25 years ago by four men who met on a computer course. They gather on the first Friday morning of each month in the basement of a local synagogue. Rehbock also manages MELâ€™s singing group, the Meltones, which rehearses on Friday afternoons. â€œWe sing songs from the 30s and 40s. WeÂ sing at senior residences, and hope that they will sing along, and they do,â€ he says. It was through MEL that Rehbock heard about theNorthwestern University SuperAging Program. He has been part of the study for the last 11 years.View image in fullscreenRehbock with the family tree he started at the age of 15.Photograph: Lucy Hewett/The GuardianWhen heâ€™s at home, Rehbock rarely sits still. â€œIâ€™mÂ always needing things. My wife says, â€˜Youâ€™ve been sitting for only one minuteâ€™ and I jump up to do something, sit back down again, and then I think of something and jump up again.â€ One of his big projects in recent years has been working on his family tree. ItÂ started with a school project he made aged 15. He still has the original and gets up to find it and show it to me. He has digitised it and added the new generations of children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren; the family tree now includes 600 members of his extended family and 400 members of his wifeâ€™s. Itâ€™s on the wall in his basement, where he continues to add details. â€œThat took a lot of time. Some people might call it busywork, but itâ€™s my kind of busywork,â€ he says.He drives himself and his wife to appointments, does Wordle every day, and always has a 1,000-piece jigsaw on the go. â€œI might do an hour a day, and it might take several weeks to complete,â€ he says. When he finishes a puzzle, he adds it to the ever-growing pile in his garage of ones heâ€™s completed. When I ask him about his superager status, heâ€™s modest. â€œI was booksmart in the sense of my grades, but I never thought of myself as anything special,â€ he says.Having discovered that the memory performance of superagers such as Rehbock and Weathers is as good as 50- to 60-year-olds, researchers wanted to look at the structure and functionality of their brains â€“ known as brain integrity â€“ to understand why. â€œWhat does their brain integrity look like? Does it look like a 50-year-oldâ€™s, with whom they share memory performance? Does it look like an 80-plus-year-oldâ€™s, with whom they share chronologic age?â€ says Rogalski. Her team looked at this on MRI scans, which allowed them to measure the thickness of the cortex, the outer layer of the brain. AsÂ weÂ age, the cortex usually shrinks, which has aÂ negative effect on cognition. Rogalskiâ€™s research found that in â€œaverage agersâ€, the outer layer of their brains had thinned, but in superagers there was no thinning. The superagersâ€™ brains looked â€œindistinguishableâ€ from 50- to 60-year-oldsâ€™, except in the anterior cingulate region, which is important for attention and memory. This part of the brain was thicker in superagers than in 50- to 60-year-olds.The research focuses on memory and cognitive function, but is looking at a broader picture by gathering data on physical activity, motor function, sleep and social engagement through wearable sensors. The aimÂ isÂ to understand â€œhow physical, social and biological factors interact to support cognitive resilienceâ€. TheyÂ are still processing the data, but anecdotally. Rogalski says most superagers are active in some way. â€œWe have some people who are doing highâ€‘intensity water aerobics, yoga and hiking in mountains. Other people are skiing or cycling, and then we have people who may need a wheelchair or aÂ walker, who might beÂ doing chair stretching. But there is a consistent report of activity,â€ she says.View image in fullscreenâ€˜I had no idea that my strength was exceptionalâ€™: Ina Koolhaas Revers, 78, at the gym in Amsterdam (above and below). Photographs: Jussi Puikkonen/The GuardianView image in fullscreenBeing active as you age is important, but some of the superagers push this to extremes, performing at a level youâ€™d expect to see in much younger people. This is the case for Ina Koolhaas Revers, a 78-year-old powerlifting champion who lives in Amsterdam. At 64, Koolhaas Revers started doing CrossFit â€“ a type of high-intensity training that combines weightlifting, gymnastic and cardio exercises. â€œBefore that, I went to a regular gym, but I didnâ€™t really know what I was doing. I had always been physically active, but never in an intense or competitive way,â€ she says. Her coach noticed that she was â€œunusually strongâ€ and suggested she try powerlifting, a form of competitive weightlifting focused on three lifts with a barbell â€“ aÂ squat, bench press and deadlift. In 2018, she qualified for the Powerlifting World Championship in Canada and won gold in her age group.After that, experts from Maastricht University in the Netherlands studied her as an older athlete. TheÂ resultsÂ were impressive â€“ compared with the average for healthy women in her age group, Koolhaas Reversâ€™s quadriceps muscles were 37% bigger, whileÂ herÂ muscleÂ cells were 46% bigger, and comparableÂ to women in their 20s. She was also able to bench press 57.5kg, squatÂ 90kg and deadlift 133.5kg, which is better than the average woman aged 25, where the maximumÂ results are 49kg, 76kg and 89kg respectively. â€œI turned out to be extremely strong â€“ much stronger than many young women aged 18 to 35 who went to theÂ gym several times a week. I had no ideaÂ that the weights I lifted were considered so heavy or that my strength was exceptional,â€ she says. â€œToÂ me,Â itÂ was evidence that seniors can achieve far more than they imagine.â€Koolhaas Revers continues to compete in powerlifting events. â€œI train four times a week for two hours per session, I follow a high-level athleteâ€™s diet and I prioritise rest and sleep. Iâ€™m not experiencing any significant decline. I still deadlift 131 kilos.â€ She attributes some of her ability to genetics â€“ her father was in the military and very fit, and both parents â€œremained relatively healthy for a long timeâ€. Koolhaas Revers says exercising is good for her brain, too. â€œI strongly believe that being physically active helps keep the brainÂ healthy.â€View image in fullscreenâ€˜I rarely eat meat and I never eat processed foodâ€™: Hans Smeets, 78, running near Gulpen in the Netherlands.Photograph: Jussi Puikkonen/The GuardianHans Smeets is another septuagenarian who has amazed researchers with his physical capabilities. A 78-year-old who lives in the Netherlands, Smeets ran as a teenager, but didnâ€™t take it up again until he was 50, when he decided to run aÂ marathon and achieved a time of two hours 50Â minutes, placing 10th overall and first in his age group.Since then, he has won gold in his age category in 22Â European championships and 25 world championships. When he was 75, Smeets was approached by sports scientist Bas van Hooren from Maastricht University about studying him in the laboratory. They discovered that he had a VO2max of 50.5, which Van Hooren describes as â€œremarkably highâ€.Â VO2max is the maximum amount of oxygen your body can use during intense exercise. Itâ€™s a â€œcentral indicator of cardiorespiratory fitness and endurance potentialâ€, says Van Hooren. Smeetsâ€™s VO2max of 50.5 at 75 years old would â€œplace him roughly in the 75th percentile of 20â€‘Â to 29-year-old menâ€, he says. â€œToÂ our knowledge, this is the highest value reported for someone at 75Â yearsÂ old.â€According to Van Hooren, the results â€œreinforced the concept that ageing does not impose an absolute ceilingâ€ when it comes to fitness. Through his research he wants to understand â€œwhat it takes to remain healthy and fit in old ageâ€ and how to â€œextend your healthspan as much as possibleâ€.In his training, Smeets focuses on endurance, rather than high intensity. â€œThe study confirmed that my training method of mostly slow endurance runs has a positive effect on the wear and tear process. I have remained virtually injury-free as a result,â€ he says. â€œToÂ stay fit at my age, itâ€™s crucial to train consistently, avoid overestimating yourself and build up stamina. This reduces the risk of injury.â€Currently, Smeets runs four or five times every week. He runs in the picturesque â€“ and unusually hilly for the Netherlands â€“ region of Heuvelland in South Limburg where he lives. He used to work at a rehabilitation centre for disabled children. Since retiring, he goes for a walk every Monday with his 84-year-old brother, and spends lots of time gardening. His parents werenâ€™t endurance runners like he is, but they enjoyed cycling and walking.View image in fullscreenâ€˜Thereâ€™s nothing better than being able to whip the backside of a young whippersnapperâ€™: Neil Hunter, 65, in Lancashire.Photograph: Jack Roe/The GuardianConsistency and a focus on endurance isÂ Neil Hunterâ€™s approach, too. He was 57 when he did his first triathlon. Now 65, he estimates that he has participated in between 100 and 150 events. â€œI have four racks for medals in my garage,â€ says Hunter, who lives in Lancashire. Most recently, he became an Ironman Age-Group world champion, after coming first in the menâ€™s over-65s category at the 2025 event in Nice.Hunter ran marathons in his 30s and 40s, but after his first triathlon, he was hooked. Since 2019, he has been working with a coach, who sets him a monthly training plan. Every three months, they test his fitness on a stationary bike while he wears an oxygen mask. â€œEvery 30Â seconds, the resistance increases on the bike. You pedal to destruction,â€ he explains. His most recent test shows that he has a VO2max of 59.6, which iswell above the 90th centile for his age groupand more in line with the 90th centile of 20- to 29-year-olds, which is 62.2.View image in fullscreenHunter: â€˜My mantra is: get fit, stay healthy, be happy.â€™Photograph: Jack Roe/The GuardianHunter trains for 15 to 20 hours every week, which includes running, cycling and swimming. He also walks his dog every day, and does stretching, yoga and pilates. He particularly enjoys overtaking younger people during triathlons. â€œBeing a mature athlete, thereâ€™s nothing better than being able to whip the backside of a young whippersnapper.â€While not everyone can compete in triathlons, Hunter sees exercise, in any form, as a crucial part of healthy ageing. â€œMy mantra is: get fit, stay healthy, be happy. Iâ€™m convinced that thereâ€™s no prescription medicine that could provide the same wellbeing results, either physically or psychologically, as daily exercise,â€ he says. The importance of exercise is backed up by Van Hooren, who suggests doing strength and cardio training. â€œAgeing affects not only the heart and lungs, but also muscles, balance, coordination and joint integrity. A mix helps preserve functional capacity,â€ he says. Interestingly, many of the older people they have studied at Maastricht University didnâ€™t exercise until later in life. â€œItâ€™s never too late to start,â€ he says.The idea of what makes a superager is something that Eric Topol, professor and cardiologist, explores in his bookSuper Agers: An Evidence-Based Approach to Longevity. He spent seven years researching a group of 1,400 people whom he calls the â€œwellderlyâ€. â€œMost of the people were in their 90s, all the way up to 102. They took good care of themselves. There was a 99-year-old man who still smoked two packs a day, but that was the rare exception,â€ explains Topol. His findings showed that â€œlifestyle is fundamentalâ€ and that genetics played less of a role than they anticipated. â€œIn their genome sequence, we found very little to account for their healthy ageing. A lot of it is related to non-genetic issues, especially the immune system. Lifestyle has aÂ big influence on our immune system,â€ he says.Donâ€™t let me sit on aÂ pedestal and think Iâ€™mÂ holier than thou. Do we have a takeaway on a Saturday night? Of course we doWhen thinking about healthy ageing, Topol says that preventing the major age-related diseases â€“ cardiovascular, cancer and neurodegenerative â€“ isÂ crucial. There are new technological developments in this area, such as organ clocks, which assess individuals and predict which diseases they are likely to develop. â€œThese organ clocks give us a pace of ageing of every organ. People generally donâ€™t develop age-related diseases before 50. So at 50 people will get an organ clock assessment of their arteries, brain, heart and immune system. That way weâ€™ll know if thereâ€™s something that warrants more attention. Itâ€™s exciting. The organ clocks will be out this year.â€While he has advice for people â€“ eat an antiâ€‘inflammatory diet, avoid ultra-processed foods, do aerobic exercise and resistance training, work on your balance and prioritise quality sleep â€“ he says many people donâ€™t do these things. â€œWhen we are able to predict which of the three diseases youâ€™re likely to get, the chances of you doing something are greatly improved,â€ says Topol.When it comes to what superagers eat, thereâ€™s no oneâ€‘size-fits-all approach. â€œWe see a wide range of diets,â€ says Rogalski. â€œDiet is important for health, so Iâ€™m not endorsing having fish and chips every night, but some individuals may be able to tolerate it more, and that might be, in part, an interaction with their genes.â€ That said, the people I speak to are all relatively healthy. â€œIâ€™ve eaten healthy my whole life,â€ says Smeets. â€œI rarely eat meat, I never eat processed food. Iâ€™veÂ been baking my own organic sourdough bread for 40 years and I drink buttermilk every day.â€ For lunch, he eats fruit from his garden with organic yoghurt and organic grains. Koolhaas Revers eats salads, greens, fish, nuts, chicken and legumes. Hunter has porridge with blueberries and honey for breakfast, and follows a reasonably healthy diet. â€œBut donâ€™t let me sit on aÂ pedestal and think Iâ€™mÂ holier than thou. Do we have a takeaway on a Saturday night? Of course we do,â€ he says. Hunter isnâ€™t teetotal but mostly stopped drinking in 2019 when he started training more seriously.Evidence increasingly suggests that lifestyle factors and, critically, their timing matter for brain healthInterestingly, Rogalski says that the superagers in their study are â€œnot uniformly â€˜perfectâ€™ in their lifestyle historiesâ€ and that approximately 40% report a history of smoking. â€œThis variability is valuable â€“ it allows us to ask why some individuals maintain exceptional cognitive health despite known risks.â€ But is it possible to reverse years of unhealthy habits? The superagers could be key to finding out. â€œEvidence increasingly suggests that lifestyle factors and, critically, their timing matter for brain health,â€ says Rogalski. One of the goals of her research is to understand if there are windows of opportunity for reducing cognitive decline.There is one thing that unites most superagers â€“ social connection.Researchers at Northwestern Universityfound that superagers in their study tend to be highly social and have strong interpersonal relationships. They also discovered that superagers have more â€œvonÂ economo neuronsâ€ in their brains, which are thought to be linked to social behaviour.Rogalski is in the process of analysing more data on social activity but says that â€œstrong social engagement does appear to be a common feature among many superagersâ€ and that learning new things and social interactions are great for keeping your brain active. Even having conversations with friends is â€œgood exercise for your brainâ€, she says. She also points toa studyin which they took two groups of people and taught one of them knitting and the other photography, and found that both had the same brain benefits because they were learning new skills. â€œIf youâ€™re in a routine and doing something you know how to do, thatâ€™s fine for enjoyment but youâ€™re probably getting less brain benefit, as opposed to doing something challenging.â€I live in a building of 200 units. I donâ€™t see anybody as active as I am or as positive as I amView image in fullscreenWeathers at her home in Illinois.Photograph: Lucy Hewett/The GuardianThese are things Koolhaas Revers prioritises. â€œInÂ the gym, I socialise with all generations. Donâ€™t limit yourself to the company of older adults. A whole new world has opened up to me through young people,â€ she says. â€œStay curious. Read the newspapers, try new foods, go to the theatre or museums. Live fully and try to remain optimistic, even when you lose people around you. Challenge yourself with new hobbies and interests. Donâ€™t think, â€˜Iâ€™m too old.â€™â€ For Weathers, social interactions are â€œessentialâ€. She offers to drive people in her building to the shops if they need something, and leaves notes on peopleâ€™s apartment doors to lift them up. â€œThey say things like â€˜Be encouraged todayâ€™ and â€˜IfÂ you need anything, Iâ€™m hereâ€™,â€ she says.From speaking to superagers and experts, it seems there is always something you can do to keep your mind and body active. â€œMy motto is: if all you can move is your little finger, then move it,â€ says Koolhaas Revers. This is true even if you have mobility or health issues. â€œHealthy ageing does not require perfection or the absence of illness. For individuals with health or mobility challenges, the focus should be on staying physically active within their abilities, remaining cognitively engaged and maintaining social connections. Even modest, consistent engagement â€“ physical, cognitive or social â€“ can be meaningful,â€ says Rogalski. This could be anything from phone calls with friends and family to doing gentle stretching in a chair.Itâ€™s hard to know what exactly makes a superager â€“ genetics, lifestyle or a bit of both? Rogalski says they donâ€™t have the full picture, but they are hoping to build it up through more research. On the physical side of things, Van Hooren says â€œit will always be a mixâ€ but that you can â€œget far by adopting a healthy lifestyle even when genetics arenâ€™t optimalâ€. The superagers IÂ speak to generally think itâ€™s a combination of genetics and lifestyle. â€œI live in a building of 200 units. I donâ€™t see anybody as active as I am or as positive as I am,â€ says Weathers. â€œIt must be something genetic, along with the influences of my environment, that got me to this place. My tip is to be grateful for what you have and use it for a purpose.â€Explore more on these topicsAgeingNeuroscienceMedical researchOlder peopleMental healthHealthFitnessfeaturesShareReuse this content

to us, answering a set of questions. This runs, with a photograph we

 UK) and online attheguardian.comevery Saturday. Itâ€™s been running since 2009 â€“ you canread all about how we put it together here.What questions will I be asked?We

 but respectfully. Be mindful of how it will read to your date, and that

title: Meera Sodhaâ€™s vegan recipe for leek and tempeh manis | Indonesian food and drink | The Guardian
description: Soft leeks and crisped tempeh drizzled in a sticky, spicy sweet soy sauce and liberally sprinkled with salted peanuts
Author: Meera Sodha
Headline: Soft leeks and crisped tempeh drizzled in a sticky, spicy sweet soy sauce and liberally sprinkled with salted peanuts
Content: Meera Sodha's leek and tempeh manis.Photograph: Louise Hagger/The Guardian. Food styling: Emily Kydd. Prop styling: Jennifer Kay. Food styling assistant: Eden Owen-Jones.View image in fullscreenMeera Sodha's leek and tempeh manis.Photograph: Louise Hagger/The Guardian. Food styling: Emily Kydd. Prop styling: Jennifer Kay. Food styling assistant: Eden Owen-Jones.The new veganIndonesian food and drinkMeera Sodhaâ€™s vegan recipe for leek and tempeh manisSoft leeks and crisped tempeh drizzled in a sticky, spicy sweet soy sauce and liberally sprinkled with salted peanutsMeera SodhaSat 24 Jan 2026 01.00 ESTShareTempeh is a gift to all home cooks from Indonesia. Made from fermented compressed soy beans, itâ€™s an intelligent ingredient equivalent to meat in terms of protein, subtle and nutty in flavour and chewy in texture. Happily, it is also now widely available in most large UK supermarkets. Here, the tempeh is cooked in a typical Indonesian way â€“ that is, fried until crisp, then coated in a sticky, spicy sweet soy sauce and liberally sprinkled with salted peanuts. In fact, the only anomaly is the leeks, making this dish mostly Indonesian but via a field in Lincolnshire.Leek and tempeh manisYouâ€™ll probably need a trip to an online or local Asian supermarket to pick up the kecap manis, a sweet soy sauce; and sambal oelek, a zingy and magical Indonesian chilli sauce. While youâ€™re there, you could also buy the makrut lime leaves, palm sugar and tempeh, but those are also available in most big supermarkets these days.Prep10 minCook30 minServes42 large leeks(330g)6 tbsp neutral oil, plus a little extra if need be400g tempeh, cut into 1cm cubes â€“ I like theTofooandTibabrands4 garlic cloves, peeled and finely sliced6cm x 2cm piece fresh ginger, peeled and finely grated4 tbsp sambal oelek3 fresh or frozen makrut lime leaves, deveined and finely shredded1Â½ tbsp palm sugar, or light brown soft sugar1 tbsp kecap manis,plus extra for drizzlingFine sea salt60g roasted peanuts, finely choppedSteamed jasmine rice, to serveTop and tail the leeks, cut them in half lengthways, then finely slice the whites and greens. Put the shredded leeks in a colander, wash them well in cold water, then sit the colander in a bowl of fresh cold water and leave for five minutes, swishing them from time to time with your hands. Drain the leeks and set aside.Put two tablespoons of the oil in a wide pan over a medium-high heat. When hot, add the tempeh and fry for eight to 10 minutes, turning until the cubes are golden and crisp on all sides, then transfer to a plate.Pat the leeks dry. Pour three tablespoons of oil into the same pan and tip in half the sliced leeks. Cook on a medium-high heat for about eight minutes in all, leaving them undisturbed for a couple of minutes at a time before stirring, so they crisp up. Once the leeks are crisp, transfer them to a second plate. Repeat with the remaining leeks, adding more oil if need be.In the same pan, add the remaining tablespoon of oil and the garlic and ginger, and fry, stirring, for two minutes. Add the sambal oelek, shredded lime leaves, palm sugar, kecap manis, half a teaspoon of salt and two tablespoons of water, then mix in all the browned tempeh, three-quarters of the crisp leeks and all but a sprinkle of the peanuts until well combined.Put the tempeh and leek mixture on a platter, drizzle with a little extra kecap manis, then top first with the remaining leeks followed by the remaining peanuts. Serve with hot jasmine rice.Explore more on these topicsIndonesian food and drinkThe new veganVegetablesFoodVegan food and drinkrecipesShareReuse this content

title: The ADHD grey zone: why patients are stuck between private diagnosis and NHS care | Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder | The Guardian
description: NHS England pays for private assessments under â€˜right to chooseâ€™, but can reject diagnoses and is struggling to cope with demand
Author: Sarah Marsh
Headline: NHS England pays for private assessments under â€˜right to chooseâ€™, but can reject diagnoses and is struggling to cope with demand
Content: In England, patients with a GP referral can select a private provider for assessment and initial treatment funded by the NHS â€“ but there are long waiting lists.Photograph: RayArt Graphics/AlamyView image in fullscreenIn England, patients with a GP referral can select a private provider for assessment and initial treatment funded by the NHS â€“ but there are long waiting lists.Photograph: RayArt Graphics/AlamyAttention deficit hyperactivity disorderThe ADHD grey zone: why patients are stuck between private diagnosis and NHS careNHS England pays for private assessments under â€˜right to chooseâ€™, but can reject diagnoses and is struggling to cope with demandSarah MarshSat 24 Jan 2026 02.00 ESTShareSameer Modha knows the ADHD system all too well. He has been diagnosed himself, as have his two children, giving him a clear view of how the system works â€“ and where it breaks down.While his own diagnosis was relatively straightforward, the experience with his daughter was very different. The diagnosis he obtained for his eldest child, after an assessment carried out privately by a â€œvery senior ex-Camhs [child and adolescent mental health service] director, someone who knows the system and has seen a huge amount of thisâ€, was later rejected by the NHS. He was told it was not compliant with guidelines from theNational Institute for Health and Care Excellence(Nice), which sets healthcare standards nationally.It is a common experience. TheNHSis increasingly referring patients to private providers, which the health service pays for, only for those assessments to be rejected. The result is an inefficient system that wastes public money and leaves patients without care and mental health trusts struggling to cope.One NHS trust has said this churn is clogging its ability to treat patients as people cycle back into services after private assessments stall. The NHS is overspending an estimated Â£164m a year on ADHD services.Modha had to have the diagnosis reconfirmed through the NHS â€“ something that only happened after â€œconstant hasslingâ€ â€“ and even after that, he has struggled to get different parts of the system to work together. He describes being â€œcaught between the private and state systemsâ€, with GPs reluctant to engage in shared care.The ADHD system in the UK has broken down. Speaking to BBC Radio Oxford this week, Wes Streeting, the health secretary, was asked whether referrals for autism and ADHD amounted to an epidemic that the government was failing to manage. â€œWell, in a nutshell, yes,â€ he replied.Part of the problem is the way the private system and the NHS are working together, something Modha experienced first hand. Under â€œright to chooseâ€, an NHS policy inEngland, patients with a GP referral can select a private provider for assessment and initial treatment funded by the NHS, rather than waiting for a local NHS service. In theory, care is then handed back to the NHS through shared-care arrangements, but often this does not happen.Although Modhaâ€™s daughter was diagnosed not through right to choose but independently via a private provider, the same structural problems emerged when care needed to be integrated back into the NHS.Trusts say patients assessed through private providers are being sent back into NHS services in growing numbers. In a lettershared with the Guardian, the Midlands partnership university NHS foundation trust acknowledged it was struggling to cope and the trend was contributing to long waiting lists and â€œreduced capacity for new and complex casesâ€.ADHD waiting lists â€˜clogged by patients returning from private care to NHSâ€™Read moreThe trust highlighted the structural weaknesses of right to choose itself. â€œThere is limited regulation surrounding private ADHD providers,â€ it wrote, noting that providers could establish services and request to diagnose ADHD, but that â€œat times their assessments do not comply with Nice guidelinesâ€.Rather than relieving pressure on NHS services, the scheme appears to be recycling it. The trust said the current model â€œhighlights the challenges and limitationsâ€ of a system that can diagnose quickly but cannot always find â€œappropriately skilled staff to support prescribing.â€Regulatory action has underlined the risks of the approach. ADHDNet, also known as Holistic ADHD Solutions, a private ADHD provider operating under right to choose, has been suspended from NHS work. The provider was registered with Norfolk and Waveney integrated care board (ICB), allowing patients across England to use its services. The ICB said the suspension was a precaution triggered by concerns about â€œservice management, safety oversight and continuity of care arrangementsâ€.In NHSGreater Manchester, adult ADHD services are under particularly severe strain. Referrals have risen by more than 400%, from about 2,700 in 2022 to more than 11,000 in 2024, with more than 25,000 adults now waiting for autism or ADHD assessments. Services were designed for far lower demand; without change, waiting times could exceed seven or in some cases 10 years.Demand continues to outpace capacity, worsened by workforce shortages. NHS Greater Manchester estimates it would cost at least Â£30m a year to fund current levels of right to choose diagnostic requests alone, without enough clinicians to deliver them. Waits already range from 18 months to more than seven years.A key problem identified is that diagnosis has become the gateway to support, even though many people need help that does not require a full specialist diagnostic assessment. In response, NHS Greater Manchester is introducing a central triage hub, with all adult ADHD referrals receiving an initial face-to-face assessment. Only those meeting agreed clinical thresholds will go on to full NHS-funded diagnosis.The model aims to reduce full diagnostic assessments by 70-80%, standardise decisions and reduce pressure on specialist services. Alongside this, NHS Greater Manchester says it will expand community-based and non-clinical support so people can access help earlier while waiting.Throughout all of this, it is patients who bear the cost. One father told the Guardian that after three years and without warning, his sonâ€™s GP practice announced it would stop working with a private provider. Although his son was referred back to NHS services, waiting times â€œexceed six months, guaranteeing a treatment gapâ€. His consultant warned of â€œpredictable harmsâ€ if treatment stopped.Modha says: â€œYouâ€™re damned if you do and damned if you donâ€™t â€“ try to get help privately and integrate later, or try to do it all through the NHS and wait two years, by which time your child may be dead.â€A spokesperson for the Independent Healthcare Providers Network (IHPN), said: â€œIndependent providers are playing an essential role in supporting the provision of NHS ADHD services â€¦ Shared care is a significant challenge and there are real risks to patients when care is not coordinated effectively between providers, and itâ€™s important that the government, NHS commissioners, relevant GP representative bodies and independent providers work collaboratively to find solutions.â€â€œWhile any concerns about safety, quality or consistency of care should always be taken seriously and addressed through robust regulation and commissioning, the overriding challenge facing ADHD services is a longstanding lack of capacity and unacceptably long waiting times for diagnosis.â€Explore more on these topicsAttention deficit hyperactivity disorderNHSPrivate healthcareHealthNational Institute for Health and Care ExcellenceEnglandGreater ManchesternewsShareReuse this content

title: Could a surfing retreat in Morocco conquer my fear of the sea? | Surfing holidays | The Guardian
description: The process of learning to catch a wave is an all-consuming activity that can prove to be a powerful therapeutic tool
Author: Annie Kelly
Headline: The process of learning to catch a wave is an all-consuming activity that can prove to be a powerful therapeutic tool
Content: The surf around Tamraght is often calm, which is ideal for beginners.Photograph: Chris WerretView image in fullscreenThe surf around Tamraght is often calm, which is ideal for beginners.Photograph: Chris WerretSurfing holidaysCould a surfing retreat in Morocco conquer my fear of the sea?The process of learning to catch a wave is an all-consuming activity that can prove to be a powerful therapeutic toolAnnie KellySat 24 Jan 2026 02.00 ESTShareIcanâ€™t remember when my terror of waves began in earnest. Maybe it was a singular incident that triggered it, like that monster wave in Biarritz, France, almost 20 years ago that body-slammed me on to the seabed, taking all the skin off my chin.More likely is that my transition from fearless to frightened had been more of a slow creep, and a perfectly rational one when you consider the danger of riptides, hidden rocks, sharks and concussion. But for me, IÂ feel it goes deeper. Almost inevitably my job will have had something to do with this. Nearly two decades of working as a journalist reporting on the very worst things that human beings can do to other human beings in a wide array of contexts has definitely eroded my sense that I can keep myself â€“ and others â€“ safe from harm in a dangerous world.View image in fullscreenIn recent years, I have found that any bit of sea with waves above waist-height makes it a no-go zone for me, even though Iâ€™m a good swimmer and love being in water. On holiday Iâ€™mÂ often left fretting on the shoreline, while my family joyfully rides the waves without me.This makes me very sad. So when I recently found myself about to change jobs for the first time in 14 years, I decided that I needed a circuit break and that this circuit break should be a week-long trauma surfing retreat in Morocco. Here, I figured, I could process some of the emotionally shredding content Iâ€™d exposed myself to while, hopefully, finally facing up toÂ my fear of waves.View image in fullscreenA post-surf meal at Riad dar Haven.Photograph: Chris WerretThe company behind the retreat IÂ signed up to is Resurface. Founded by psychologist Josh Dickson, who specialises in trauma, recovery and personal growth, the idea is to provide a holistic experience by combining morning yoga and surf lessons with afternoon group therapyÂ work.In a call before the retreat, Josh said his intention is to create a â€œflowâ€ state, where the body and the mind are able to work together towards healing and renewal, bolstered by the sunshine, cold water and a disconnection from the rigours of our everyday lives.Surfing is not just excellent physical exercise, it requires the surfer to be immersed in nature, concentrating fully on what theyâ€™re doing moment to moment. It also triggers an array ofÂ helpful hormones â€“endorphins, dopamine and serotonin for mood boosts, andadrenalineand norepinephrine for thrills and focus. All of these help to create the perfect set up for therapeutic work.We travelled to beautiful beaches around Tamraght, where the waves were so tiny it was difficult for even me to be frightenedI had initially booked on to one of Resurfaceâ€™s first Reset retreats, designed to promote resilience and prevent burnout. Yet for various complicated reasons, I instead ended up on its first EMDR (eye movement, desensitisation and reprocessing) group retreat.Developed in the 1980s by US psychologist Francine Shapiro, the basic aim of EMDR is to help reduce distressing emotions connected to particular memories or past traumas that the body might be holding on to.The theory is that traumatic events are not neurologically processed in theÂ same way as healthy memories, and so they can resurface and intrude. EMDR therapy uses bilateral stimulation â€“ for example, rapidly moving your eyes from one point to another or tapping your body left then right at the same time as concentrating on a traumatic event. This, the theory goes, allows the brain to process and store the memory normally.View image in fullscreenThe writer enjoyed the chilled atmosphere of Tamraght.Photograph: Mauritius Images/AlamyObviously doing this in a group setting, among strangers, feels pretty intimate and exposing, so it was with some trepidation that I arrived in the small surf town of Tamraght, just north of Agadir, one sunny October afternoon to begin the retreat.Tamraght is lovely. The quieter, more chilled sister of the flashier surf tourism hotspot Taghazout, a couple of miles to the north, its dusty streets are full of busy restaurants, ceramics and surf shops, and with a lovely seafront where you can hang out with the beach camels.Learning to catch a wave, nearly always failing and then paddling straight back out to try again, was a meditation in itselfThat night, at Riad dar Haven, our beautiful and welcoming home for the six days of the retreat, our cohort â€“ an eclectic, multi-generational bunch â€“ met for a dinner of chicken with green olives and lemons cooked by theÂ resident chef.The next morning, after a short introductory session with Josh featuring some fairly excruciating but fun ice-breaking exercises, we piled into the mini van and headed down to the beach where we struggled into wetsuits and divided into groups. Some of us had never surfed (myself included), others were more experienced.Our teachers, led by local surf instructor Youness Arhbi, were excellent â€“ patient, funny and obviously experienced at convincing first-timers with cement hips that we had a chance of standing up on our huge foam learner boards.Every morning we travelled to different, beautiful beaches around Tamraght, where the waves were so tiny it was difficult for even me to be frightened. I found the experience of being in the cold, salt water for three or four hours at a stretch exhausting yet exhilarating. And, although I was definitely not a natural, the process of learning to catch a wave, nearly always failing and then paddling straight back out to try again, was a meditation in itself.After the lessons, our group of 12Â would all sit together on the beach, the sun on our faces, eating lunch and sharing the triumphs and frustrations of our surfing exploits. Then we would pile in the bus and head back to the riad where we would begin the afternoonâ€™s therapy session.At the beginning of the week, this part of the day felt pretty exposing, but Josh was thoughtful, confident and knowledgable in leading us through the process.View image in fullscreenAnnie Kelly in Tamraght, MoroccoAt first, I didnâ€™t find EMDR particularly transformational, although it was interesting that what came up during the sessions was oftenÂ not the memory or event I had decided to focus on at the beginning. However, as the week progressed, IÂ was surprised to discover that theseÂ sessions became the most transformational thing about the retreat for me.As for the surfing, I ended the weekÂ being almost as rubbish as when I started, but it didnâ€™t really matterAfter years of slowly and corrosively losing faith in the world, I found real hope and connection in sharing with aÂ group of people willing to face up to their own personal heartbreaks, traumas and pain. It was a balm that did more to restore my faith and hope in people than any amount of self-reflection could offer.As for the surfing, I ended the weekÂ being almost as rubbish as when I started, but it didnâ€™t really matter. On my last day, the waves had changed, and although they could not credibly be described as big, they were big enough for me to feel scared. Yet withÂ our instructorâ€™s encouragement â€“ and a bit of cathartic sobbing on theÂ beach when it all got too much â€“ IÂ persevered.And just once, in the last half-hour of the lesson, I managed to clamber awkwardly to my feet and stand up. As I raised my arms in the air in triumph, I heard cheering from the beach and watched as the group rose to their feet and joined me in celebration.The trip was provided byResurface, which offers seven-night surf therapy retreats fromÂ£2,500pp, including accommodation, transfers, all meals, surf lessons, therapy sessions and activities; the nextÂ trips starts on11 AprilExplore more on these topicsSurfing holidaysMorocco holidaysHealth and fitness holidaysAfrica holidaysHealth & wellbeingfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Tim Dowling: the dung men are here. The tortoise is out. Surely itâ€™s not spring already â€¦ | Family | The Guardian
description: I see the manure men as part of some lost and deeply English tradition, which is why I prefer my wife to deal with them
Author: Tim Dowling
Headline: I see the manure men as part of some lost and deeply English tradition, which is why I prefer my wife to deal with them
Content: Illustration: Selman Hosgor/The GuardianView image in fullscreenIllustration: Selman Hosgor/The GuardianThe Tim Dowling columnFamilyTim Dowling: the dung men are here. The tortoise is out. Surely itâ€™s not spring already â€¦I see the manure sellers as part of some lost and deeply English tradition, which is why I prefer my wife to deal with themTim DowlingSat 24 Jan 2026 01.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 12.43 ESTShareIam in the kitchen watching the dog and the cat fight whenÂ the tortoise suddenly appears. Or to put it another way: I watched the dog and the cat fight for a while, until it became tiresome; the next time I looked up â€“ possibly 15 minutes later â€“ the tortoise was also there. Thatâ€™s what I mean by suddenly. In real terms, the tortoise doesnâ€™t do anything suddenly.â€œWhere have you been?â€ I say, even though I know the answer. I havenâ€™t seen the tortoise in six weeks, but Iâ€™mÂ certain heâ€™s been butted up against theÂ left rear leg of the sofa for that whole period.â€œAre you trying to get in on this?â€ IÂ say. Thatâ€™s what it looks like. The tortoise is poised at the edge of the fray, head up, waiting to bite an unguarded appendage. For a moment the dog has the cat pinned to the floor, and the catâ€™s tail is waving slowly back and forth in front of the tortoiseâ€™s face. But he misses his chance: the cat rears up, sinks its claws into the dogâ€™s neck and bites in the manner of a leopard trying to take down a wildebeest. The dog steps over the tortoise and drags the cat to the opposite corner of the room, where the fight continues.The tortoise angles its head so its eye meets mine.â€œLettuce?â€ I say.â€œLook whoâ€™s up,â€ my wife says, walking into the kitchen with two dirty mugs in each hand.â€œYeah,â€ I say, opening the fridge. â€œSpring is here.â€Spring is not here. A cold rain is falling outside and the mid-morning light is sepulchral. But a rapid overnight thaw has jarred the tortoise out of suspended animation. Heâ€™ll stomp around the kitchen in a fury for a few days before he finds a new place to hide â€“ under the dogâ€™s bed perhaps, orÂ in the gap between the dresser and the wall. Once heâ€™s settled heâ€™ll retract his legs and head and stay put for another month.There are two of them, dressed in flat caps, scarves and worn jackets, offering farmyard manure on spec off the back of a lorryBut his premature appearance isnâ€™t the only sign of spring. Later, while my wife is at the supermarket, the manure men ring the doorbell.There are two of them, dressed in flat caps, scarves and worn jackets, offering farmyard manure on spec off the back of a lorry. They come round twice a year, generally in autumn and spring. I think of these dung-sellers as part of some lost and deeply English tradition, which is why I prefer it when my wife is on hand to deal with them.One of them says almost nothing; the other talks non-stop. He also prefers to deal with my wife, who likes listening to the biannual updates on his many ailments. On the other hand, she drives a harder bargain than I do. IÂ ring her.â€œThe manure men are here,â€ I say.â€œOh God,â€ she says. â€œJust tell them we donâ€™t want any.â€â€œItâ€™s already gone beyond that,â€ IÂ say. â€œIâ€™m making them tea.â€â€œHow much did you agree to pay?â€ she says.â€œIâ€™m not ready to tell you that,â€ I say.When Iâ€™ve made the tea I take the two mugs out. The rain has stopped.â€œNo sugar, two sugars,â€ I say, raising the mugs in turn. The one who talks all the time takes the two sugars one.â€œLeave his there,â€ he says, pointing to a windowsill.â€œThis is early for you, isnâ€™t it?â€ I say, thinking of spring.â€œYeah,â€ says the one with two sugars. â€œWe was here six weeks ago, but your missus said to come back inÂ January.â€â€œDid she?â€ I say.While the quiet one does all the work, we chat for a while, about illness, about life, about the ups and downs of the door-to-door manure game. Finally, IÂ have to get back to work.Eventually they go, and my wife returns. Together we look out the window at the neatly mulched beds.â€œHow was he?â€ she says.â€œIn and out of hospital all summer,â€ I say. â€œStill having tests.â€â€œUh-huh,â€ she says.â€œAnd they got a new truck, exactly the same as the old one,â€ I say. â€œAnd his daughter converted to Islam.â€â€œReally?â€ she says.â€œShe lives in Dubai,â€ I say. â€œAnd IÂ guess she married a fella out there.â€â€œWhat else?â€ she says. â€œDid he go toÂ the wedding?â€â€œI think so,â€ I say. â€œI canâ€™t remember.â€â€œYouâ€™re useless,â€ she says.â€œYou should have been here,â€ IÂ say,Â shrugging. â€œAnyway, they didÂ aÂ good job.â€â€œHow much?â€ she says.â€œStill too soon,â€ I say.Explore more on these topicsFamilyThe Tim Dowling columnfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Trump threatens Canada with 100% tariff over possible deal with China | US foreign policy | The Guardian
description: President also claims US refineries will process seized Venezuelan oil, saying â€˜we take the oilâ€™
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: President also claims US refineries will process seized Venezuelan oil, saying â€˜we take the oilâ€™
Content: Canadaâ€™s prime minister, Mark Carney, and Donald Trump at the White House on 7 October 2025.Photograph: Evan Vucci/APView image in fullscreenCanadaâ€™s prime minister, Mark Carney, and Donald Trump at the White House on 7 October 2025.Photograph: Evan Vucci/APUS foreign policyTrump threatens Canada with 100% tariff over possible deal with ChinaPresident also claims US refineries will process seized Venezuelan oil, saying â€˜we take the oilâ€™Guardian staff and ReutersSat 24 Jan 2026 10.04 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 19.13 ESTShareDonald Trumpon Saturday said he would impose a 100% tariff on all Canadian imports if the North American country makes a trade deal withChina.Beside that tariff threat, another Trump foreign policy maneuver to make news on Saturday involved the president announcing the US had taken the oil that was on recently seizedVenezuelantankers.The US president wrote on social media that if the Canadian prime minister, Mark Carney, â€œthinks he is going to makeCanadaa â€˜Drop Off Portâ€™ for China to send goods and products into the United States, he is sorely mistakenâ€.Trump withdraws invitation for Canada to join his global â€˜board of peaceâ€™Read moreâ€œChina will eat Canada alive, completely devour it, including the destruction of their businesses, social fabric, and general way of life,â€ Trump wrote on his Truth Social platform. â€œIf Canada makes a deal withChina, it will immediately be hit with a 100% Tariff against all Canadian goods and products coming into the [US].â€Trump has repeatedly invoked tariffs in a bid to bend countries to his will â€“ with some success, though he also repeatedlybacked downfrom his most extreme tariff-related threats.Notably, days earlier, Trump walked back his threat to impose sweeping tariffs on several European countries in order to facilitate the USâ€™s acquisition of Greenland, the semiautonomous Danish Arctic island which the president has been fixated on. Trump claimed he had reached â€œthe framework of a future dealâ€ on Greenland.In a New York Post interviewpublishedon Saturday, Trump boasted that the US will gain sovereignty and take ownership over land in Greenland where American bases are located.â€œWeâ€™ll have everything we want,â€ Trump reportedly told the Post. â€œWe have some interesting talks going on.â€Meanwhile, in the same Post interview published on Saturday, TrumpsaidUS refineries will process the oil his administration had taken from seized Venezuelan tankers.â€œLetâ€™s put it this way â€“ they donâ€™t have any oil,â€ Trump told the Post. â€œWe take the oil.â€The oil is being refined in â€œvarious placesâ€ including Houston, he said.The US military hasseizedseven Venezuela-linked tankers since the start of Trumpâ€™s month-long campaign to control Venezuelaâ€™s oil flows. Trump said on Tuesday that his administration had taken 50m barrels of oil out of Venezuela and was selling some of it in the open market.The intercepted vessels either were under US sanctions or said to be part of a â€œshadow fleetâ€ ofships that disguisetheir origins to move oil from major sanctioned producers: Iran, Russia or Venezuela.Trumpâ€™s Latin American foreign policy has homed in on Venezuela, initially aiming to push the Venezuelan president,NicolÃ¡s Maduro, from power. After failing to accomplish that aim through diplomacy, Trump ordered US forces to fly into the country to grab Maduro and his wife in an overnight raid on 3 January, bringing them to New York to face criminal drug-related charges anddetaining themthere.In Saturdayâ€™s interview with the Post, Trump bragged that a new weapon he called â€œthe discombobulatorâ€ played a central role in that raid.Those remarks came after the White House press secretary, Karoline Leavitt,sharedon social media a purported eyewitness account of the US military using some sort of â€œvery intense sound waveâ€ to incapacitate Maduroâ€™s bodyguards.Trump has said the US plans to control Venezuelaâ€™s oil resources indefinitely as it seeks to rebuild the countryâ€™s dilapidated oil industry in a $100bn plan thatis promptingmany raised eyebrows, not least fromenvironmentalistsand the US oil giants.Explore more on these topicsUS foreign policyDonald TrumpCanadaChinaTrump tariffsTariffsOilnewsShareReuse this content

title: Pentagon to reduce its role in deterrence of North Korea | North Korea | The Guardian
description: US policy document suggests South Korea take primary responsibility, as Pentagon prioritises defending US homeland
Author: Raphael Rashid
Headline: US policy document suggests South Korea take primary responsibility, as Pentagon prioritises defending US homeland
Content: South Korean and US soldiers watch a joint live firing drill. The Pentagon says its ally is capable of taking most of the responsibility for deterring North Korea.Photograph: Jung Yeon-Je/AFP/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenSouth Korean and US soldiers watch a joint live firing drill. The Pentagon says its ally is capable of taking most of the responsibility for deterring North Korea.Photograph: Jung Yeon-Je/AFP/Getty ImagesNorth KoreaPentagon to reduce its role in deterrence of North KoreaUS policy document suggests South Korea take primary responsibility, as Pentagon prioritises defending US homelandRaphael Rashidand agenciesSat 24 Jan 2026 01.18 ESTFirst published on Fri 23 Jan 2026 23.17 ESTShareThe Pentagon foresees a â€œmore limitedâ€ role in deterring North Korea, withSouth Koreataking primary responsibility for the task, a Pentagon policy document released on Friday said, in a move likely to raise concern in Seoul.South Korea hosts about 28,500 US troops in combined defence against North Koreaâ€™s military threat and Seoul has raised its defence budget by 7.5% for this year.â€œSouth Korea is capable of taking primary responsibility for deterring North Korea with critical but more limited US support,â€ said the National Defense Strategy, a document that guides the Pentagonâ€™s policies.North Korea launches ballistic missiles towards sea before South Korean leaderâ€™s visit to ChinaRead moreâ€œThis shift in the balance of responsibility is consistent with Americaâ€™s interest in updating US force posture on the Korean Peninsula,â€ the document added. In recent years, some US officials have signalled a desire to make US forces in South Korea more flexible to operate outside the Korean peninsula in response to a broader range of threats, such asdefending Taiwanand checking Chinaâ€™s growing military reach.South Korea has resisted the idea of shifting the role of US troops, but has worked to grow its defence capabilities in the past 20 years, to take on a wartime command of the combined US-South Korean forces. South Korea has 450,000 troops.The shift is part of what Washington has called â€œalliance modernisationâ€ under the Trump administration. South Korean president Lee Jae Myung has himself pushed for greater defence autonomy, criticising in Septemberwhat he calledâ€œthe submissive mindset that self-reliant defence is impossible without foreign troopsâ€.In a statement on Saturday, South Koreaâ€™s defence ministry said US Forces in Korea remained central to the alliance and would continue to deter North Korean aggression.The Pentagon document makes no mention of denuclearising the Korean peninsula, the secondmajor strategy paperto omit the language. The Biden administration in 2022explicitly statedâ€œcomplete and verifiable denuclearisationâ€ as a goal, suggesting Washington may be shifting towards managing North Koreaâ€™s nuclear arsenal rather than seeking its elimination.The wide-ranging document, which each new administration publishes, said the Pentagonâ€™s priority was defending the homeland. In the Indo-Pacific region, the document said, the Pentagon was focused on ensuring China could not dominate the US or its allies.â€œThis does not require regime change or some other existential struggle. Rather, a decent peace, on terms favourable to Americans but that China can also accept and live under, is possible,â€ the document said, without mentioning Taiwan by name in the roughly 25-page document.China claims democratically governed Taiwan as its own territory and has not ruled out the use of force to take control of the island. Taiwan rejects Beijingâ€™s sovereignty claims and says only the people of Taiwan can decide their future.With ReutersExplore more on these topicsNorth KoreaUS militarySouth KoreaUS foreign policyAsia PacificnewsShareReuse this content

title: New Zealand landslide: rescue efforts called off for six people buried in disaster  | New Zealand | The Guardian
description: Rescue efforts at Mount Maunganui site switch to recovery operation that police say could take several days
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Rescue efforts at Mount Maunganui site switch to recovery operation that police say could take several days
Content: Heavy machinery has been deployed at the scene of a deadly landslide triggered by heavy rains in Mount Maunganui, New Zealand.Photograph: David Rowland/ReutersView image in fullscreenHeavy machinery has been deployed at the scene of a deadly landslide triggered by heavy rains in Mount Maunganui, New Zealand.Photograph: David Rowland/ReutersNew ZealandNew Zealand landslide: rescue efforts called off for six people buried in disasterRescue efforts at Mount Maunganui site switch to recovery operation that police say could take several daysGuardian staffFri 23 Jan 2026 21.23 ESTFirst published on Fri 23 Jan 2026 20.25 ESTShareEfforts to rescue six people buried by a landslide at aNew Zealandholiday park ended on Saturday, with police shifting into a recovery operation.Police Supt Tim Anderson said human remains had been uncovered on Friday night beneath themountains of dirt and debris that crashed into a campsite in Mount Maunganuion Thursday, adding that it could take several days to locate all of the victims due to the unstable ground.â€˜The sound of mayhemâ€™: witness to New Zealand landslide describes â€˜almighty crackingâ€™Read moreAnderson said it was â€œheartbreakingâ€ that six people remained unaccounted for, including a 15-year-old, after camper vans, caravans and a shower block were buried in a mudslide brought on by heavy rain.He said it was now â€œhighly unlikelyâ€ that more than six people had been caught under the landslide.â€œThereâ€™s still a lot of mud and other aspects [around the site] so my primary consideration today is actually the safety of the staff working on it,â€ he said on Saturday. â€œThere are really strict parameters around those that are working on site right now.â€The remains will be transported to a mortuary in Hamilton. Chief coroner Anna Tutton warned that the identification process could be â€œpainfulâ€ and â€œlengthyâ€.For the past two days, the holiday town in the northern part of the country has staged a series of vigils, holding out hope that the search and rescue personnel would be successful.Prime minister Christopher Luxon said on Saturday â€œevery New Zealander has been hoping for a miracleâ€ and that the switch to a recovery operation was â€œthe news we have all been dreadingâ€.â€œPolice have confirmed fatalities at the campground and the reality that no one would have been able to survive, therefore the rescue operation taking place there is now moving to a recovery.â€œTo the families who have lost loved ones â€“ every New Zealander is grieving with you.â€More poor weather is forecast for the area on Saturday with thunderstorms and hail possible, potentially hampering the recovery operation at the campsite.New Zealand authorities are facing questions over why people were not evacuated after reports of a landslip at the campsite and neighbouring areas earlier on Thursday.Two people died in a separate landslide on Thursday in the neighbouring harbourside city of Tauranga. One of the people killed was a Chinese national, officials said.Explore more on these topicsNew ZealandAsia PacificnewsShareReuse this content
