Author: Ben Smee
Headline: Teachers who attended â€˜compulsoryâ€™ creationist conference run by US-based fundamentalist group told radiometric dating techniques were flawed
Content: Queensland teachers who attended a Christian science conference hosted by Answers in Genesis were  encouraged to incorporate material that conformed to a biblical worldview into their humanities lessons.Composite: Getty Images/Guardian DesignView image in fullscreenQueensland teachers who attended a Christian science conference hosted by Answers in Genesis were  encouraged to incorporate material that conformed to a biblical worldview into their humanities lessons.Composite: Getty Images/Guardian DesignAustralian educationScience teachers from Queensland Open Brethren schools told to teach students about vegetarian dinosaurs on Noahâ€™s ArkTeachers who attended â€˜compulsoryâ€™ creationist conference run by US-based fundamentalist group told radiometric dating techniques were flawedFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet ourbreaking news email,free appordaily news podcastBen SmeeQueensland state correspondentSat 24 Jan 2026 14.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 18.38 ESTShareTeachers employed by a large group ofQueenslandChristian schools were told to teach creationism in science classes, including that vegetarian baby dinosaurs would have been taken aboard Noahâ€™s Ark.Last year, the Open Brethren organisation Christian Community Ministries (CCM) hosted a Christian science conference by the US-based fundamentalist group Answers in Genesis, which oncebuilt a replica of Noahâ€™s Ark â€“ with model dinosaurs included.Some Queensland science and humanities teachers working at CCM â€“ whichoperates 15 schools around Australiaâ€“ were told it was compulsory to attend the event.Sign up: AU Breaking News emailThe conference featured a presentation by the Answers in Genesisâ€™ director of research, Australian geologist Andrew Snelling.Those present say Snelling told them the radiometric dating techniques used by mainstream scientists to show fossils and rocks are millions of years old were flawed. He said the Himalayas were formed by the â€œgreat floodâ€, and that juvenile vegetarian dinosaurs had been on the ark.View image in fullscreenA visitor looks into a cage containing a model dinosaur inside a replica Noahâ€™s Ark built by Answers in Genesis in Kentucky in 2016.Photograph: John Minchillo/APTeachers say they were then encouraged to incorporate the material by Snelling into their science and humanities lessons.Those who raised concerns with Guardian Australia made clear they did not object to faith-based schools teaching religious doctrine; their concern was that schools had a responsibility to educate children based on the curriculum.Faith-based schools in Queensland are required to teach the approved syllabus.Prof David Geelan, the president of theScienceTeachersâ€™ Association of Queensland, said the science curriculum explicitly introduces the theory of evolution to students from year 10.â€œThe students need to understand evolution as an explanation for the diversity of life and talk about the scientific evidence that supports the theory.The Australian who ascended to the helm of a Republican-linked fundamentalist Christian groupRead moreâ€œA thoughtful and nuanced teacher [at a faith-based school] could say: â€˜In our church we believe X, but for your assessments you should demonstrate your understanding of the scientific theory as currently developed.â€™ But Iâ€™m not sure that always happens.â€A â€˜distrust of scienceâ€™Answers in Genesis is a â€œyoung earth creationistâ€ group which disputes significant strands of consensus science, and claims instead that scientific evidence supports the biblical creation story.Last year Guardian Australia revealed the US-based group, now fronted by former Australian Christian Lobby head Martyn Iles, hadflagged a push into Australia.But Geelan said that in order to sustain the theory of creationism â€œyou have to end up being sceptical about a whole heap of current scientific knowledgeâ€.â€œAnswers in Genesis say scientists are lying to you â€¦ [and] that very often then forms up with other forms of science denialism. That distrust of science is the main negative.â€Geelan said while schools are required to teach the syllabus there â€œisnâ€™t really a mechanism for checking thisâ€.â€œThey probably shouldnâ€™t be teaching things that directly contradict the syllabus.â€œBut there arenâ€™t school inspectors going around. Thereâ€™s less of that compliance, the school has some autonomy to teach as they wish.â€The Queensland Curriculum and Assessment Authority said in a statement the stateâ€™s science syllabuses and resources â€œsupport the teaching of scientific theories, including the theory of evolutionâ€.â€œQueensland schools develop courses of study and assessment based on the requirements in our syllabuses and other advice and guidelines.â€œWe have several checkpoints during the year to ensure these requirements are being met.â€œPrincipals are ultimately responsible for the quality and content of teaching and learning in their schools.â€The chief executive of Christian Community Ministries, John Lyndon, said the organisationâ€™s schools teach â€œthe full requirements of the Australian curriculumâ€, including the theory of evolution.â€œAt the same time, as a Christian school, we also welcome insights from scientists and scholars who work from a biblical worldview. This enables students to engage thoughtfully and objectively in determining their own beliefs and to develop a well-rounded understanding of life.â€Lyndon said Snelling was â€œa highly qualified and respected geologistâ€ and said Guardian Australia had been given â€œinaccurateâ€ and â€œabsurdâ€ information about the presentation.â€œCCM schools are highly respected by our parents and school communities, who have deliberately chosen us to educate their children, being fully aware that our schools offer a Christ-centred educational opportunity which is wholly compliant with the Australian Curriculum.â€Snelling did not respond to a request for comment.Answers in Genesis is hosting a series of events in Australia, beginning later this month, including at Mueller College in north Brisbane, a school run by CCM.Explore more on these topicsAustralian educationReligionCreationismQueenslandScienceChristianitynewsShareReuse this content

title: Australian journalism â€˜sidelinedâ€™ in AI-generated news summaries on Copilot, research shows | Australian media | The Guardian
description: Exclusive: Experts say AI is likely to create more news deserts, fewer independent voices and threaten the viability of Australian journalism
Author: Amanda Meade
Headline: Exclusive: Experts say AI is likely to create more news deserts, fewer independent voices and threaten the viability of Australian journalism
Content: The majority of Copilotâ€™s AI-generated answers linked to US websites, and in three of the seven news prompts studied, no Australian sources appeared, researchers found.Photograph: Sipa US/AlamyView image in fullscreenThe majority of Copilotâ€™s AI-generated answers linked to US websites, and in three of the seven news prompts studied, no Australian sources appeared, researchers found.Photograph: Sipa US/AlamyAustralian mediaAustralian journalism â€˜sidelinedâ€™ in AI-generated news summaries on Copilot, research showsExclusive:Experts say AI is likely to create more news deserts, fewer independent voices and threaten the viability of Australian journalismFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesSign up for Guardian Australiaâ€™s free weekly media newsletter hereAmanda MeadeMedia correspondentSat 24 Jan 2026 14.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 20.37 ESTShareAustralian journalism is largely â€œinvisibleâ€ in AI-generated news summaries fromMicrosoftCopilot, which overwhelmingly favour US or European media, research by the University of Sydney has found.Roughly one-fifth of responses to Copilot news prompts feature links to Australian media sources, according to researcher Dr Timothy Koskie from the universityâ€™sCentre for AI, Trust and Governance.Inhis paper, Invisible journalists and dominant algorithms, Koskie warns the increasing use of these tools will almost certainly lead to more news deserts, fewer independent voices and a weakened democracy. He urges the development of policy mechanisms, such as thenews media bargaining code, to help journalism thrive.â€˜Not regulatedâ€™: launch of ChatGPT Health in Australia causes concern among expertsRead moreSearching for information, including news, is now one of AIâ€™s most widely used functions, according toReuters Institute surveys.When users receive AI summaries without clicking through to the original news website, they starve news outlets of web traffic and revenue, posing a threat toAustralian mediaoutletsâ€™ financial viability.Koskieâ€™s analysis of 434 AI-generated news summaries revealed non-Australian sources CNN, BBC and ABC America were introduced despite the user being located in Australia.Sign up to get Guardian Australiaâ€™s weekly media diary as a free newsletterThe technology â€œbasically sidelined Australian newsâ€, he said, and when Australian sources were used they were usually big players like Nine and the ABC and not smaller, independent media. No [local] journalist was ever mentioned,â€ Koskie told Guardian Australia.The technology is â€œjust reproducing crises that we didnâ€™t properly attend to beforeâ€, he said. â€œThe Australian media ecosystem is already struggling with concentrated ownership, declining independent outlets, and news deserts in regional areas.â€Koskie became interested in the impact of Copilot when it installed itself on his system without permission in 2023 and invited him to use seven globally focused prompts to get his news.Prompts included: â€œwhat are the major health or medical news updates for this weekâ€ and â€œwhat are the top global news stories todayâ€.He decided to follow the prompts to see where it would take him.The majority of Copilotâ€™s answers linked to US websites, and in three of the seven news prompts studied, no Australian sources appeared at all.â€œEven when Australia was mentioned, it was very often just Australia, rather than Ballarat or the Kimberley,â€ he said.â€œAustralians are invisible in this. In international studies, what people trust is the local news. And so we have this issue of declining trust in media, and the media that theyâ€™re being exposed to through these new platforms is not the one that people trust, which is local.â€œTrust is also in people, and the people are invisible.â€According to the Reuters Instituteâ€™spredictions for media, journalism and technology in 2026, generative AI â€œthreatens to upend the news industry by offering more efficient ways of accessing and distilling information at scaleâ€.â€œMeanwhile search engines are turning into AI-driven answer engines, where content is surfaced in chat windows, raising fears that referral traffic for publishers could dry up, undermining existing and future business models.â€Koskie, a postdoctoral research associate in digital communication, suggests extending the news media bargaining incentive remit to consider AI tools and incentivising AI companies to embed geographical location in their coding design.â€œWhile Copilot may offer a sleek, automated gateway to news, this study highlights its tendencies to reinforce dominant international sources, sideline independent and regional media, and erase the human labour behind journalism itself,â€ the academic paper warns. â€œIf left unchecked, such tools risk compounding Australiaâ€™s existing media pluralism challenges rather than alleviating them.â€Explore more on these topicsAustralian mediaAI (artificial intelligence)MicrosoftnewsShareReuse this content

title: Russia launches â€˜brutalâ€™ attack on Ukraine as peace talks continue  | Ukraine | The Guardian
description: Kyiv says Moscow used 396 drones and missiles in â€˜another night of Russian terrorâ€™ on second day of talks in UAE
Author: Peter Beaumont
Headline: Kyiv says Moscow used 396 drones and missiles in â€˜another night of Russian terrorâ€™ on second day of talks in UAE
Content: Fires broke out in several buildings hit by drone debris while heat and water services in parts of the capital were interrupted, Kyivâ€™s mayor said.Photograph: Ukrainian emergency services/AFP/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenFires broke out in several buildings hit by drone debris while heat and water services in parts of the capital were interrupted, Kyivâ€™s mayor said.Photograph: Ukrainian emergency services/AFP/Getty ImagesUkraineRussia launches â€˜brutalâ€™ attack on Ukraine as peace talks continueKyiv says Moscow used 396 drones and missiles in â€˜another night of Russian terrorâ€™ on second day of talks in UAEPeter Beaumontin KyivSat 24 Jan 2026 10.01 ESTFirst published on Sat 24 Jan 2026 02.14 ESTShareRussia launched a major drone and missile attack targeting Ukraineâ€™s two largest cities, Kyiv and Kharkiv, early on Saturday, as US, Ukrainian and Russian negotiators met in the United Arab Emirates for a second day oftripartite peace talks.â€œPeace efforts? Trilateral meeting in the UAE? Diplomacy? For Ukrainians, this was another night of Russian terror,â€ the countryâ€™s foreign minister, Andrii Sybiha, said after the latest Russian assault on critical infrastructure.â€œCynically, Putin ordered a brutal massive missile strike againstUkraineright while delegations are meeting in Abu Dhabi to advance the America-led peace process. His missiles hit not only our people, but also the negotiation table.LiveRussia launches â€˜brutalâ€™ attack on Ukraineâ€™s two largest cities â€“ videoâ€œThis barbaric attack once again proves that Putinâ€™s place is not at (US President Donald Trumpâ€™s) Board of Peace, but in the dock of the special tribunal,â€ Sybiha wrote on X.Despite the the latest wave of attacks, the talks in Abu Dhabi resumed on Saturday morning.When talks broke up later in the day, both sides suggested they were open to more dialogue, with Zelenskyy describing the talks as constructive, suggesting another round of talks could be held perhaps as early as next week.With Kyiv and other cities in the midst of widespread outages of heat, water and power after Russian attacks on energy infrastructure, officials in the capital said one person had been killed and at least 15 injured in strikes that continued until morning.Engineers in Kyiv face the huge task of reconnecting apartment buildings to heating. They said 6,000 of the cityâ€™s apartment blocks were without heat on Saturday morning, 4,000 more than in previous days, including many that had recently been reconnected.View image in fullscreenVehicles destroyed during Russiaâ€™s overnight drone and missile strikes on Kyiv.Photograph: Valentyn Ogirenko/ReutersInitial estimates suggested that at least 1.2 million consumers were without power across the country, including 800,000 in Kyiv.The Ukrainian air force said Russia had used 396 drones and missiles in the attacks, and officials warned that up to 80% of the country faced emergency power cuts in the immediate aftermath of the attack.The Russian strikes, which took place in the middle of the first tripartite talks of the war, come in tandem with Moscow continuing to insist it must control the eastern Donbas region of Ukraine, underlining doubts that it is serious about peace.Speaking in the aftermath of the strikes, the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, said agreements on air defence made with Trump in Davos this week must be â€œfully implementedâ€.Zelenskyy and Trump met at the World Economic Forum on Thursday and discussed air defence support for Ukraine, but neither leader specified afterwards what had been agreed.A distraction, a threat: how Ukrainians have viewed the Greenland crisisRead moreKyivâ€™s mayor, Vitali Klitschko, said: â€œCurrently, one person is known to have died and four to have been wounded,â€ he wrote in a social media post, adding that three of the injured had been admitted to hospital.Fires broke out in several buildings hit by drone debris while heat and water services in parts of the capital were interrupted, he said.View image in fullscreenA car workshop and garage in Kyiv that was hit overnight.Photograph: Valentyn Ogirenko/ReutersThe strikes come amid aworsening mid-winter energy crisisfocused on the capital, where many have been left without heat and power for a prolonged period.Klitschko said on Friday about 1,940 residential buildings in Kyiv were without heating after renewed attacks, adding â€œand this may not be the most difficult moment yetâ€.His office said about 600,000 residents had fled the city temporarily during the January power crisis that has left entire blocks across the city in darkness.The head of Kyivâ€™s military administration, Tymur Tkachenko, reported strikes in at least four districts. A medical facility was among the buildings damaged.Kyiv has already endured two mass overnight attacks this year that have knocked out power and heating to hundreds of residential buildings. Emergency workers were still engaged in restoring services to residents, with overnight temperatures dropping to -13C (9F).In Kharkiv, a frequent target 30km (18 miles) from the Russian border, the cityâ€™s mayor, Ihor Terekhov, said 25 drones had hit several districts over two and a half hours, with at least 14 people injured.Writing on Telegram, Terekhov said the drones had struck a dormitory for displaced people, a hospital and a maternity hospital.View image in fullscreenA Ukrainian emergency personnel works to extinguish a fire.Photograph: Oleksandr Magula/AFP/Getty ImagesThe first known direct contact between Ukrainian and Russian officials on the US-backed proposal also began on Friday.Ukraineâ€™s chief negotiator, Rustem Umerov, said the discussions had focused â€œon the parameters for ending Russiaâ€™s war and the further logic of the negotiation processâ€.An initial US draft drew heavy criticism in Kyiv and westernEuropefor sticking too closely to Moscowâ€™s line, while later iterations prompted pushback from Russia for floating the idea of European peacekeepers.Both sides say the fate of territory in the eastern Donbas region is one of the main sticking points in the search for a settlement to a war that has killed tens of thousands, displaced millions and decimated parts of Ukraine.Explore more on these topicsUkraineRussiaEuropenewsShareReuse this content

title: â€˜A lot of fearâ€™: the families bearing brunt of Swedenâ€™s immigration crackdown | Sweden | The Guardian
description: Many of those moved into an asylum return centre have held jobs for years and can speak the language
Author: Miranda Bryant
Headline: Many of those moved into an asylum return centre have held jobs for years and can speak the language
Content: Thamer and Faten, originally from Iraq, are facing deportation despite their third child being born in Sweden.Photograph: Josefine Stenersen/The GuardianView image in fullscreenThamer and Faten, originally from Iraq, are facing deportation despite their third child being born in Sweden.Photograph: Josefine Stenersen/The GuardianSwedenâ€˜A lot of fearâ€™: the families bearing brunt of Swedenâ€™s immigration crackdownMany of those moved into an asylum return centre have held jobs for years and can speak the languageMiranda Bryantin StockholmSat 24 Jan 2026 09.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 10.44 ESTShareâ€œSweden didthisfor us,â€ said Sofiye*, making a supportive scooping up gesture with her hands. â€œAnd then, bam.â€ She dropped them to the ground.Sofiye, who has three children, arrived in Sweden from Uzbekistan as an asylum seeker in 2008, and for much of that time she was able to build a life in the Scandinavian country. The family lived in a flat in a Stockholm suburb and Sofiye worked for the municipality in the home help department. She learned Swedish and her children went through the Swedish school system. Her youngest son was born in Sweden and her 18-year-old son, Hamza, who is studying in college to be a technician, doesnâ€™t know life anywhere else.Three years ago, however, after unsuccessfully seeking refugee status four times, Sofiye lost her right to work and is now living under the threat of a deportation order. For the last two years she and two of her children have been living in limbo in an asylum return centre in an industrial area near Stockholmâ€™s Arlanda airportThe situation is causing her so much anxiety that for the last two months she has lost her appetite and been vomiting with stress. As she spoke to the Guardian she held a plastic bag into which she regularly retched.View image in fullscreenThe asylum return centre near Stockholmâ€™s Arlanda airport. The Swedish migration agency said it had made efforts to ensure the centres were appropriate for children.Photograph: Josefine Stenersen/The Guardianâ€œI cannot sleep. I sleep just one or two hours. I throw up. I am so stressed. I donâ€™t want to speak to the children because here,â€ she said, pointing to her head, â€œis occupied. I donâ€™t know physically, mentally what I should do.â€The centre, one of a growing number of reception and return facilities aimed at housing an estimated 11,000 asylum seekers in the coming years, is part of Swedenâ€™s increasingly hostileasylum and immigration policy. The centre-right government, which depends on the support of the far-right Sweden Democrats, says it wants to â€œredirect focusâ€ away from receiving asylum seekers to instead becoming a â€œcountry for labour immigrationâ€.The government recently celebrated data showing that Sweden had its lowest level of asylum seekers since 1985, claiming that lower numbers â€œcreate better conditions for successful integrationâ€. Thousands of people like Sofiye â€“ who have lived in Sweden for years and are well-established in society and the job market, with children who were born in Sweden â€“ face deportation.Among the recent policy changes include asylum seekers being placed in reception centres instead of being provided with individual accommodation who are then offered â€œrepatriation grantsâ€ to leave the country voluntarily.The government has also introduced stricter conditions for gaining citizenship and tightened family reunification rules. Applicants must prove their identity through an in-person visit and provide more documentation than was previously the case.Committing a crime can now result in losing the right to live in Sweden for anyone who is not a Swedish citizen. In 2025 a total of 440 people were subjected to criminal deportations, according to government figures.â€œIf you do not want to become part of this community, you should not come to Sweden,â€ the government has stated.View image in fullscreenA â€˜refugees welcomeâ€™ demonstration in Gothenburg in 2015. The attitude towards immigration in Sweden has hardened in the years since.Photograph: Scanpix Sweden/ReutersThe hostile environment is a far cry from Swedenâ€™s immigration policies of the past. In 2014, at the start of a period when the number of people arriving to Europe from countries in the Middle East rose sharply, the then prime minister, Fredrik Reinfeldt, made a speech urging Swedes toâ€œopen your heartsâ€to newcomers.The direction of travel is unlikely to change even with a general election next year, say observers, as the main political parties, including the opposition centre-left Social Democrats, have embraced similar hardline policies.â€œMany people that we meet say to us: â€˜We came to Sweden believing this was a country that respected human rights: where are they?â€™â€ said Nannie SkÃ¶ld, a counsellor at Stockholm Stadsmissionâ€™s Who Am I Tomorrow? project, which provides legal and psychosocial support to individuals and families with deportation orders.The latest government figures show that 8,312 people returned to their home countries in 2025, the highest number in a decade, while the number of asylum seekers decreased by 30% on the previous year.â€œWe meet people who came to Sweden for work or to study, and people who donâ€™t have grounds for asylum,â€ said SkÃ¶ld. â€œWe also meet people who are fleeing from the Taliban or they are LGBTQ from Uganda, and who then see that their request for international protection is denied.â€One of the changes that was having a particularly damaging impact is the decision to abolish â€œtrack changesâ€, she said. The new rule, which came into force at short notice last April, prevents people who have had their asylum applications rejected from applying for a residence permit, even if they have worked in Sweden. It also prevents those who had already obtained a work permit from extending it.The decision is estimated to have put 4,700 people who were established in Swedish society at risk of deportation.SkÃ¶ld added: â€œPeople [who] are well integrated and established in Sweden â€¦ are asking: â€˜What else could I have done? â€¦ How could I possibly prove my worth if even doing everything that is supposedly correct isnâ€™t enough and will never be enough?â€™â€Life in the return centres is tough. The facility near Arlanda, which also houses new arrivals, is an â€œopenâ€ centre, meaning people can come and go. But getting around from there is logistically difficult and many people are getting by on a few kronor a day. It was a difficult place to be in for children, said SkÃ¶ld, who said her team heard from LGBTQ asylum seekers that the shared spaces could feel unsafe. Many there suffer from poor mental health as a result of their precarious circumstances.â€œThere is a lot of fear, a lot of anxiety,â€ she said. â€œPeople who have received a deportation order fear being deported any day.â€View image in fullscreenThamer says his sons are willing and able to work.Photograph: Josefine Stenersen/The GuardianThamer and Faten are a married couple who came to Sweden from Iraq on work visas with their two sons, who are now 20 and 16. Their third son was born in Sweden in 2021. But they now face deportation after their asylum applications were denied and work visas expired. Thamer said that a criminal organisation has threatened to harm their children if they return to Iraq.â€œThere are people who have lived in Sweden for 30 years but they donâ€™t talk Swedish like me,â€ said Thamer, 52. â€œI write as well, not just speak. What do they want more than that? I am not a criminal.â€Thamer said he was offered a job as a car mechanic but was unable to take it because his work visa had expired. â€œSweden wants men and I have three. Can they not make use of them?â€The Swedish migration agency said it was unable to comment on individual cases. It was â€œworking to ensure that the [reception and return centres] are safe for everyone staying there, with particular consideration given to children and other vulnerable groups, such as LGBTQ personsâ€, a spokesperson said.*Those interviewed requested their surnames not be published as their cases arein processExplore more on these topicsSwedenEuropeMigrationnewsShareReuse this content

title: â€˜Repatriate the goldâ€™: German economists advise withdrawal from US vaults | Germany | The Guardian
description: Shift in relations and unpredictability of Donald Trump make it â€˜risky to store so much gold in the USâ€™, say experts
Author: Kate Connolly
Headline: Shift in relations and unpredictability of Donald Trump make it â€˜risky to store so much gold in the USâ€™, say experts
Content: Michael JÃ¤ger, head of the European Taxpayers Association, said Donald Trump was â€˜unpredictableâ€™, and that this meant â€˜our gold is no longer safe in the Fedâ€™s vaultsâ€™.Photograph: Michael Dalder/ReutersView image in fullscreenMichael JÃ¤ger, head of the European Taxpayers Association, said Donald Trump was â€˜unpredictableâ€™, and that this meant â€˜our gold is no longer safe in the Fedâ€™s vaultsâ€™.Photograph: Michael Dalder/ReutersGermanyâ€˜Repatriate the goldâ€™: German economists advise withdrawal from US vaultsShift in relations and unpredictability of Donald Trump make it â€˜risky to store so much gold in the USâ€™, say expertsKate Connollyin BerlinSat 24 Jan 2026 03.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 03.02 ESTShareGermany is facing calls to withdraw its billions of eurosâ€™ worth of gold from US vaults, spurred on by the shift in transatlantic relations and the unpredictability ofDonald Trump.Germany holds the worldâ€™s second biggest national gold reserves after the US, of which approximately â‚¬164bn (Â£122bn) worth â€“ 1,236 tonnes â€“ is stored in New York.Emanuel MÃ¶nch, a leading economist and former head of research at Germanyâ€™s federal bank, the Bundesbank, called for the gold to be brought home, saying it was too â€œriskyâ€ for it to be kept in the US under the current administration.â€œGiven the current geopolitical situation, it seems risky to store so much gold in the US,â€ he told the financial newspaperHandelsblatt. â€œIn the interest of greater strategic independence from the US, the Bundesbank would therefore be well advised to consider repatriating the gold.â€World stock markets brace for turbulence after Trumpâ€™s latest tariff shockRead moreStefan Kornelius, the spokesperson for Friedrich Merzâ€™s coalition government, said recently that withdrawal of the gold reserves was not currently under consideration.But MÃ¶nch is only the latest in a string of economists and financial experts to argue that such a move would be in keeping with the greater strategic independence that Europeâ€™s largest economy has been seeking from the US in recent months.Michael JÃ¤ger, the head of the European Taxpayers Association (TAE) as well as the Association of German Taxpayers, has also said Berlin should make its move, arguing that the USâ€™s stated desire to seize Greenland should concentrate minds.â€œTrump is unpredictable and he does everything to generate revenue. Thatâ€™s why our gold is no longer safe in the Fedâ€™s vaults,â€ JÃ¤ger told theRheinische Post. â€œWhat happens if the Greenland provocation continues? â€¦ The risk is increasing that the German Bundesbank will no longer be able to access its gold. Therefore, it should repatriate its reserves.â€JÃ¤ger said he had written last year to the Bundesbank and the finance ministry, urging them to â€œbring our gold homeâ€.Until recently the gold issue has been the preserve mainly of the far-right Alternative fÃ¼r Deutschland (AfD), which has repeatedly urged the return of the gold for patriotic reasons. But it has increasingly crept into the mainstream discourse.Katharina Beck, the finance spokesperson for the opposition Greens in the Bundestag, has also spoken out in favour of relocating the gold bars, calling them an â€œimportant anchor of stability and trustâ€, which â€œmust not become pawns in geopolitical disputesâ€.However, Clemens Fuest, the president of the Institute for Economic Research (Ifo) and one of the countryâ€™s most prominent economists, warned against such a move, saying it could lead to unintended consequences and would â€œonly pour oil on the fire of the current situationâ€, he told the Rheinische Post.Germanyâ€™s total gold reserves are worth almost â‚¬450bn.Just over half are held at the Bundesbank in Frankfurt am Main, 37% in the vaults of the US Federal Reserve in New York and 12% at the Bank of England in London, the global centre of gold trading. The Bundesbank says it regularly undertakes an audit of the supplies of gold it holds in storage.Speaking last October at the International Monetary Fundâ€™s (IMF) autumn meetings in Washington DC, the Bundesbank president, Joachim Nagel, assured attenders there was â€œno cause for concernâ€ over the German gold held at the US Federal Reserve.World is entering time of â€˜great power politicsâ€™, warns German chancellorRead moreFrauke Heiligenstadt, the parliamentary group spokesperson on financial policy for the Social Democrats, junior partners in the government, said that while she understood concerns about the gold reserves, there was no need for panic.â€œGermanyâ€™s gold reserves are well diversified,â€ she said. Because half of them are located in Frankfurt, â€œour ability to act is guaranteedâ€. Having gold in New York made sense, she added, because â€œGermany, Europe and the US are closely linked in terms of financial policyâ€.But, amid Trumpâ€™s hardening rhetoric towards his western partners, an increasing number of Merzâ€™s Christian Democrats have been speaking out in favour of relocation.â€œDue to the Trump administration, the US is no longer a reliable partner,â€ Ulrike Neyer, a professor of economics at the University of DÃ¼sseldorf, told the Rheinische Post.Explore more on these topicsGermanyEconomicsGoldDonald TrumpUS politicsEuropeCommoditiesnewsShareReuse this content

title: Syrian and Kurdish forces agree to extend ceasefire as threat of war looms | Syria | The Guardian
description: Ceasefire to be extended for one month to allow transfer of suspected Islamic State members from Syria to Iraq
Author: William Christou
Headline: Ceasefire to be extended for one month to allow transfer of suspected Islamic State members from Syria to Iraq
Content: Members of Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) arrive at the Kurdish-held city of Kobane after withdrawing from the Al-Aqtan prison in the Raqa province of Syria.Photograph: AFP/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenMembers of Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) arrive at the Kurdish-held city of Kobane after withdrawing from the Al-Aqtan prison in the Raqa province of Syria.Photograph: AFP/Getty ImagesSyriaSyrian and Kurdish forces agree to extend ceasefire as threat of war loomsCeasefire to be extended for one month to allow transfer of suspected Islamic State members from Syria to IraqWilliam Christouin Deir el-ZourSat 24 Jan 2026 07.47 ESTShareThe Syrian government and Kurdish forces agreed to extend a ceasefire on Saturday, according to Syrian diplomatic sources, temporarily staving off a looming war between the two sides in the north-east of the country.Sources told Agence France-Presse the ceasefire would be extended for â€œa period of up to one month at mostâ€, citing the need to facilitate the transfer of suspected members ofIslamic Statefrom Syria to Iraq.Kurdish forces withdraw from IS detention camp in north-east SyriaRead moreThe two sides had announced a temporary ceasefire earlier in the week, halting an offensive by the Syrian government which brought its army to the door of the Kurdish Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF). The announcement quelled concerns the offensive would restart on Saturday and gave more space for diplomacy, but did not solve the root cause of the conflict between the two sides.Fighting over three contested neighbourhoods inAleppoin early January led to a sweeping government offensive in which the SDF lost the majority of its territory in the country in a matter of days.The ceasefire was meant to give time for the SDF to implement a 14-point plan with the Syrian government under which the Kurdish militia would disband and its soldiers integrate into the Syrian army.If the SDF did not implement the agreement, Damascus would resume its offensive and push toward the last strongholds of the SDF in Hasakeh, and the Kurdish-majority areas of Qamishli and Kobane.The two sides spent the ceasefire preparing for the eventuality of a full-scale war.SDF forces built up in Kurdish-majority areas while its leaders called for a general mobilisation among residents there, distributing weapons to those willing to take up arms.View image in fullscreenA protester at a demonstration in the northern Iraqi Kurdish city of Sulaimaniyah to oppose the deployment of Syrian government forces in formerly Kurdish-led areas in Syria.Photograph: Shwan Mohammed/AFP/Getty ImagesSyrian government soldiers and tanks streamed towards the frontline, hoping to bring the north-east under the control of Damascus. â€œSoon we will be in Hasakeh and then Qamishli, God willing,â€ a soldier said on Thursday while standing guard as logistics convoys moved towards the Hasakeh front.As soldiers waited on the battlefield, Syrian officials and regional powers were engaged in a bout of diplomacy to avoid resuming the war. The SDF leader, Mazloum Abdi, went to Iraqi Kurdistan for the second time, where he met the US envoy for Syria, Tom Barrack, who has been mediating talks between the SDF and Damascus.Abdi also spoke on the phone to the Syrian foreign minister, Asaad al-Shaibani, which was followed by an agreement allowing the safe transfer of SDF fighters from a besieged prison in Syrian government-controlled territory.â€œIdeally, the transfer of Daesh [Islamic State] prisoners from Syria should take place. While this is happening, the existing non-conflict environment needs to be maintained,â€ the Turkish foreign minister, Hakan Fidan, said on Friday, referring to the US-facilitated transfer of more than 7,000 suspected IS members and fighters from Syria to Iraq.Disputes between the two sides remain even with the ceasefire extension. The 14-point plan would bring an end to the autonomous Syrian Kurdish project, and Kurdish leaders seemed to struggle to come to terms with their losses over the last two weeks, which has left them with little leverage.The SDF went from controlling nearly a third of the country, including its oil fields, breadbasket and key infrastructure, to just a few cities. The deal on the table would turn the Kurdish force, which not so long ago boasted of being 100,000 strong, into essentially a municipality overseeing a local police force running a few Kurdish cities in the north-east of the country.Abdi, long known as a pragmatic figure among the SDF, has signalled he would be willing to implement the deal.He is struggling, however, to gain consensus within the SDF.If he is unable to unify the SDF and implement the agreement with the government, then the alternative would be war. Damascus has made it clear it would no longer tolerate non-state armed groups and is determined to unify the country under its flag, either through negotiations or force.The US, which has backed the Kurdish force for the past decade, has made its support for Damascus clear, with Barrack saying the SDFâ€™s role as the anti-IS force in Syria had now been filled by the Syrian government.View image in fullscreenThe president of Iraqi Kurdistan, Nechirvan Barzani (right), meets the head of the SDF), Mazloum Abdi, in Erbil.Photograph: Iraqi Kurdistan Presidency/AFP/Getty ImagesThe US military has already began transferring IS prisoners from Kurdish territories to prevent any escapes ahead of a renewed war with Damascus. Once IS prisoners are secured, there will be little strategic interests left for a US military presence in north-east Syria.Even if Damascus has the military advantage and regional backing, it is still hoping to prevent a war. Its offensive so far has led to relatively few casualties, as the SDF has opted to withdraw from Arab-majority areas such as Raqqa and Deir el-Zour rather than confront the Syrian government.Fighting in Kurdish-majority areas is likely to be more bloody.There is fear among Kurdish civilians of the Syrian government fighters, after government-backedmassacres in Druze-majority Suweida province and in the Alawite-majority Syrian coastlast year.Many residents in Kurdish-majority areas have armed themselves. Kurdish forces have dug in, having prepared for this fight for years, creating a vast subterranean tunnel network to facilitate guerrilla fighting against a better armed force.Damascus is aware that even if it wins the war, it could drive away the Kurds, push the SDF underground and create a insurgency similar to that of the Kurdistan Workersâ€™ Party (PKK) in Turkey for years to come.Explore more on these topicsSyriaMiddle East and north AfricaIslamic StateAlepponewsShareReuse this content

title: Trump says US â€˜armadaâ€™ heading to Middle East as Iran death toll put above 5,000 | Iran | The Guardian
description: US president says â€˜we have a lot of shipsâ€™ going in that direction and that Washington is watching Iran closely
Author: Patrick Wintour
Headline: US president says â€˜we have a lot of shipsâ€™ going in that direction and that Washington is watching Iran closely
Content: The aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln (pictured) and several guided-missile destroyers will arrive in the Middle East in the coming days.Photograph: Eric S Powell/APView image in fullscreenThe aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln (pictured) and several guided-missile destroyers will arrive in the Middle East in the coming days.Photograph: Eric S Powell/APIranTrump says US â€˜armadaâ€™ heading to Middle East as Iran death toll put above 5,000US president says â€˜we have a lot of shipsâ€™ going in that direction and that Washington is watching Iran closelyPatrick WintourDiplomatic editorFri 23 Jan 2026 20.47 ESTFirst published on Fri 23 Jan 2026 08.07 ESTShareDonald Trump has said an American â€œarmadaâ€ is heading towards the Middle East and that the US is monitoring Iran closely, as activists put the death toll from Tehranâ€™s crackdown on protesters at 5,002.Speaking on Air Force One as he returned from theWorld Economic Forumin Davos overnight, he said: â€œWe have a lot of ships going that direction, just in case. Iâ€™d rather not see anything happen, but weâ€™re watching them very closely â€¦ we have an armada â€¦ heading in that direction, and maybe we wonâ€™t have to use it.â€The aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln and several guided-missile destroyers are due to arrive in the Middle East in the coming days. Additional air defence systems are being deployed, most likely around US and Israeli airbases. The UK said it would send RAF Eurofighter Typhoon jets from 12 Squadron to Qatar, at Dohaâ€™s request.Iran will treat any attack â€œas an all-out war against us, and we will respond in the hardest way possibleâ€ a senior Iranian official, speaking on condition of anonymity, told Reuters on Friday ahead of the arrival of the US aircraft carrier strike group.The US president pulled back from attacking Iran two weeks ago, despitepromising â€œhelp is on its wayâ€, largely because he felt he had been given no military option that would prove decisive in securing regime change in Tehran. He was also urged to hold back by the Gulf states.A map showing the location of USS Abraham LincolnIn an update on Friday, the US-based Human Rights Activists News Agency (HRANA) said the death toll from the Iranian crackdown on protesters had reached 5,002 â€“ comprising 4,716 demonstrators, 203 government-affiliated people, 43 children and 40 civilians not taking part in the protests.â€˜He hoped Trumpâ€™s help would arriveâ€™: why protesters in Iran feel betrayedRead moreThe agencyâ€™s numbers have been accurate in previous unrest in Iran and rely on a network of activists there to verify deaths. HRANA said at least 26,541 people had been arrested.The protests started on 28 December when traders took to the streets in Tehran in response to a sudden dip in the value of the rial. As they spread, demands expanded to include calls for an end to the countryâ€™s government, creating the most serious and deadliest unrest in the country since the 1979 revolution.View image in fullscreenTrump speaks with reporters onboard Air Force One after leaving the World Economic Forum in Davos.Photograph: Evan Vucci/APSpeaking at an emergency session of the UN Human Rights Council in Geneva, Volker TÃ¼rk, the UN commissioner for human rights, said thousands of people, including children, had been killed on the streets and in residential areas. He said video evidence showed there were hundreds in morgues with fatal injuries to their heads and chests, while hundreds of security personnel had also been killed.He urged Iran to â€œend their brutal repressionâ€, including summary trials, and urged a complete moratorium on the use of the death penalty.TÃ¼rk decried Iranâ€™s judiciary chief this week saying there would be no leniency for the thousands detained, saying it was a â€œchilling developmentâ€. â€œI am deeply concerned by contradictory statements from the Iranian authorities about whether those detained in connection with the protests may be executed,â€ he said, pointing out that Iran â€œremains among the top executioner states in the worldâ€, with at least 1,500 people reportedly put to death there last year.The Iranian authorities have sought to delegitimise the protests by claiming rioters infiltrated peaceful protests. â€œNone of this would justify resorting to disproportionate use of force or coercing families,â€ TÃ¼rk said. He claimed there had been 100 forced confessions and a lack of transparency about proceedings, with those arrested including lawyers, human rights activists, cafe owners, athletes and actors.The internet shutdown was the longest recorded in Iran and had severely restricted communications making it difficult for families to check on the welfare of their loved ones, he said.Mai Sato, the UN special rapporteur on human rights in Iran, demanded to be able to visit Iran for a thorough investigation. â€œThe Iranian people have shown enormous courage by talking truth to power,â€ she said, and urged the international community to reciprocate.â€œLethal force can only be used as a last resort to protect life and must be lawful, necessary and proportionate. Iâ€™ve received countless videos showing security forces using lethal force against unarmed protesters.â€The protest movement has largely petered out in the face of the crackdown, which was accompanied by anunprecedented internet blackout, though chants of â€œdeath to the dictatorâ€ are taking place at bitter and often well-attended funerals.View image in fullscreenA burnt-out bus depot damaged during recent anti-government protests in Tehran.Photograph: Abedin Taherkenareh/EPAVideos are still trickling out from inside Iran showing how security forces were given licence to shoot to kill protesters, especially from 5-8 January.One of the main reformist newspapers, Ham-Mihan, has been shut down for printing two stories: one on the pursuit of protesters in a hospital and the other detailing the severity and brutality of the suppression more widely.Many leading reformists have not been able to express their views on the crackdown, and the few that have been allowed to address wider audiences seem to be blaming both sides for a collapse in social solidarity brought on by a crash in the exchange rate. The extent to which these problems are caused by sanctions or internal inefficiency is debated.Map showing location of US troops in the middle eastIn his longest reflection to date on the violence, the Iranian president, Masoud Pezeshkian, a reformist elected 18 months ago, claimed â€œthe civil and just protest of the people was turned into a bloody and violent battle due to a conspiracy by those who wish Iran ill willâ€.Scott Bessent, the US treasury secretary, took credit while in Davos for the protests, saying US sanctions had led to the unrest and that maximum economic sanctions â€œworked because in December, their economy collapsedâ€.He added: â€œWe saw a major bank go under. The central bank has started to print money. There is a dollar shortage. They are not able to get imports, and this is why the people took to the streets. This is economic statecraft, no shots fired, and things are moving in a very positive way here.â€Trump has repeatedly left open the option of new military action against Iran after Washington backed and joined Israelâ€™s12-day war in Juneaimed at degrading Iranian nuclear and ballistic missile programmes. But the prospect of immediate American action seemed to have receded in recent days, with both sides insisting on giving diplomacy a chance.Ali Abdollahi Aliabadi, who heads Iranâ€™s Khatam-al Anbiya Central Headquarters, which coordinates the army and the Revolutionary Guards, warned the US on Thursday that any military strike on Iran would turn all US bases in the region into â€œlegitimate targetsâ€.Explore more on these topicsIranDonald TrumpUS militaryUS foreign policyProtestMiddle East and north AfricanewsShareReuse this content

title: Protesters supporting Palestine Action hunger striker arrested outside prison | London | The Guardian

Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Police said group breached HMP Wormwood Scrubs ground where Umar Khalid is being held
Content: A group of protesters have been arrested on suspicion of aggravated trespass at HMP Wormwood Scrubs.Photograph: Andrew Matthews/PAView image in fullscreenA group of protesters have been arrested on suspicion of aggravated trespass at HMP Wormwood Scrubs.Photograph: Andrew Matthews/PALondonProtesters supporting Palestine Action hunger striker arrested outside prisonPolice said group breached HMP Wormwood Scrubs grounds where Umer Khalid is being heldPA MediaSat 24 Jan 2026 18.58 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 19.07 ESTShareA group of protesters supporting a Palestine Action prisoner on hunger strike have been arrested after they breached prison grounds, the Metropolitan police has said.The force said on Saturday evening that it had detained a group of protesters outside HMP Wormwood Scrubs, in westLondon, and was in the process of making a number of arrests.According to the force, the group refused to leave the grounds when ordered to do so, allegedly blocked prison staff from entering and leaving, and threatened police officers.The Met said a number of them also managed to get inside a staff entrance area of a prison building.The group were arrested on suspicion of aggravated trespass, the force said.Footage shared on social media showed a group chanting outside the prison, with some holding signs.At one point, the group can be seen moving towards a building â€“ and one clip appears to show some demonstrators inside.It is understood they were holding the demonstration in support of Umer Khalid.He is the last remaining participant in the Prisoners for Palestine hunger strike campaign, according to the group.Explore more on these topicsLondonnewsShareReuse this content

title: Home Office to launch â€˜British FBIâ€™ to deal with serious crime UK-wide  | Police | The Guardian
description: National Police Service will investigate organised crime, terrorism, fraud and online child abuse
Author: Donna Ferguson
Headline: National Police Service will investigate organised crime, terrorism, fraud and online child abuse
Content: The home secretary, Shabana Mahmood, says creating the National Police Service will enable local forces to spend more time fighting crime in their communities.Photograph: James Manning/PAView image in fullscreenThe home secretary, Shabana Mahmood, says creating the National Police Service will enable local forces to spend more time fighting crime in their communities.Photograph: James Manning/PAPoliceHome Office to launch â€˜British FBIâ€™ to deal with serious crime UK-wideNational Police Service will investigate organised crime, terrorism, fraud and online child abuseDonna FergusonandMorgan OforiSat 24 Jan 2026 17.30 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 17.53 ESTShareThe government is setting up a NationalPoliceService â€“ dubbed the â€œBritish FBIâ€ â€“ to deal with organised crime, terrorism, fraud and online child abuse in a major change to policing in England and Wales.The new organisation, which will be announced by the Home Office in a white paper on Monday, means fraud, criminal gang and UK-wide counter terror investigations will no longer be carried out by a combination of existing agencies such as the National Crime Agency and regional organised crime units run by local police forces.The National Police Service (NPS) will instead deploy â€œworld-class talentâ€ and â€œstate-of-the-art technologyâ€ to carry out these investigations nationally, enabling local police officers to use more of their resources to crack down on less serious and complex local crimes, such as shoplifting or antisocial behaviour.Under the plans, the work of the counter-terror policing unit led by the Metropolitan police, the National Police Air Service run by West Yorkshire police and national roads policing operations will all be carried out by the new NPS, which will share technology, intelligence and resources across borders.Police Federation criticises plans for mandatory â€˜licence to practiseâ€™ for officersRead moreâ€œThe current policing model was built for a different century,â€ said the home secretary,Shabana Mahmood.â€œSome local forces lack the skills or resources they need to fight complex modern crime such as fraud, online child abuse or organised criminal gangs,â€ she added.â€œWe will create a new National Police Service â€“ dubbed â€˜the British FBIâ€™ â€“ deploying world-class talent and state-of-the-art technology to track down and catch dangerous criminals.â€œIn doing so, local forces will be able to spend more time fighting crime in their communities.â€The NPS will be run by a national police commissioner who will become the most senior police chief in the country. It will set standards and training for police forces and acquire new technology such as facial recognition cameras â€“ acontroversial movethat has provokedfierce criticismover its impact on privacy and human rights â€“ on behalf of all police forces.A joint statement from the Met, counter-terrorism policing and the National Police Chiefsâ€™ Council said: â€œModern crime requires a modern policing response. We support and have been calling for this ambitious step to bring together some of the most capable policing teams in the country into a single National Police Service.â€œThis builds on the high international regard that already exists among partners for counter-terrorism policing, whose capabilities and professionalism are recognised globally.â€œThis transformation, however, must be delivered with care. Its success depends on maintaining strong connections with local policing and the communities we serve.â€œNeighbourhood officers remain indispensable in disrupting organised crime and countering terrorism. Their relationships, insights and presence on the ground are foundational to public safety.â€œAs we implement this reform programme, protecting those vital local links will be essential to ensuring the new National Police Service strengthens â€“ not separates â€“ the bond between policing and the public.â€The NPS will be created in stages, working alongside existing agencies and regional organised crime units for the transition.Backing the plans, Neil Basu, former head of counter-terrorism policing, said NPS will be â€œfar more capable as one national security system dealing more effectively with major crime, organised crime and terrorism in all its formsâ€.Graeme Biggar, director general of the National Crime Agency, which would be merged into the new organisation, is also supporting the proposals.â€œI am proud of the brilliant work NCA officers do to protect the public from serious and organised crime and new and emerging threats,â€ he said. â€œBut the overall policing system is out of date. Crime has changed, technology has changed, and how we respond needs to change.â€œAs part of reform, we need a single, stronger national law enforcement body, building on the NCA and others, to more coherently tackle organised crime, fraud, terrorism and the new international and online threats we face.â€Biggar added: â€œThese are threats that affect us all locally, but need a national and international response. Such a body would enable us to improve how we protect the public, our communities and the country.â€Sir Mark Rowley, the head of the Metropolitan police, has also previously supported the idea of the national responsibility for counter-terrorism being removed from his force.But the plans were met with concern on the part of Graham Wettone, a policing analyst.Wettone is a former frontline operational officer of 30 yearsâ€™ experience who specialised in public order, policing protests and demonstrations.Poorly performing police forces to be named and shamed under new plansRead moreHe said: â€œHopefully they have consulted with those people actually doing the job: operational frontline officers and frontline detectives, the detectives actually going out investigating crime, police officers in uniform answering calls.â€œI donâ€™t believe they have. From what Iâ€™m hearing, it seems to me itâ€™s largely come from the Home Office, from people that have advised or guided the Home Office as to what policing needs, having never actually done the job at all â€“ possibly from police leaders who havenâ€™t actually done the job for some period of time.â€But, he added: â€œFraud investigations are complex, so probably do need a national overview. Because thereâ€™s now a huge amount of online fraud, it covers many areas of the country, so having one force managing it is very, very difficult when your offenders and your victims can be in Lancashire, Yorkshire and Devon and Cornwall.â€œSo it makes sense. It makes sense to nationalise some aspects as organised crime groups donâ€™t stick to county boundaries. They literally work across the country, and will move people across the country from force to force area.â€Explore more on these topicsPoliceShabana MahmoodPolice and crime commissionersnewsShareReuse this content

title: Starmer allies urge him to block Andy Burnham from running in byelection | Andy Burnham | The Guardian
description: Greater Manchester mayor has applied to stand for Labour in Gorton and Denton, setting up potential fight for PMâ€™s political future
Author: Harry Taylor
Headline: Greater Manchester mayor has applied to stand for Labour in Gorton and Denton, setting up potential fight for PMâ€™s political future
Content: Andy Burnham is considered one of the favourites to replace Keir Starmer were the prime minister to be toppled.Photograph: Phil Noble/ReutersView image in fullscreenAndy Burnham is considered one of the favourites to replace Keir Starmer were the prime minister to be toppled.Photograph: Phil Noble/ReutersAndy BurnhamStarmer allies urge him to block Andy Burnham from running in byelectionGreater Manchester mayor has applied to stand for Labour in Gorton and Denton, setting up potential fight for PMâ€™s political futureKiran Stacey,Geraldine McKelvieandHarry TaylorSat 24 Jan 2026 16.33 ESTFirst published on Sat 24 Jan 2026 12.03 ESTShareKeir Starmerâ€™s allies are urging him to block Andy Burnham from running in the Gorton and Denton byelection, after theGreater Manchestermayor declared his intention to stand, setting up a potential fight for the prime ministerâ€™s political future.Burnham said on Saturday he wanted to contest the seat after the sitting MP, Andrew Gwynne, said he intended to stand down.Burnhamâ€™s allies â€“ including ministers, MPs and trade union chiefs â€“ say that as one of the countryâ€™s most high-profile and popularLabourpoliticians, he must be allowed to fight the seat and attempt a return to parliament.But with theManchestermayor having made no secret about his leadership ambitions, those close to the prime minister were on Friday night urging him to take steps to prevent Burnham standing.â€œIf Keir doesnâ€™t make the call [to block Burnham], itâ€™s game over,â€ said one.Another added: â€œAndyâ€™s candidacy is not going anywhere. It will cost too much to fight the Manchester mayoralty and there is no guarantee we would win it.â€The fight over Labourâ€™s future crystallised on Saturday evening, when Burnham submitted his application to run in the seat alongside a letter to the partyâ€™s ruling national executive committee (NEC).He wrote in the letter: â€œI see this byelection as the frontline of that fight for the Manchester Way and I feel I owe it to a city which has given me so much to lead it from the front, despite the risks involved.â€He said he wanted to run a â€œhopeful and unifyingâ€ campaign. If selected, he would face strong challenges from Reform UK and the Green party.The NEC could meet as soon as Sunday morning to decide whether to let Burnham resign from the mayoralty and to put himself forward to the local party for selection as their candidate.While NEC members are free to cast their votes however they wish, the prime ministerâ€™s allies have a majority on the committee and are expected to vote against Burnham should those around Downing Street make it clear thatâ€™s what they want.One person with knowledge of the committeeâ€™s processes said: â€œThere are significant cost implications to having a mayoral selection and byelection, itâ€™s reasonable to expect mayors to serve their term.â€Starmer faces pressure not to block Andy Burnhamâ€™s return to parliamentRead moreThe byelection was called this week afterthe resignation of the former minister Gwynne, who announced he was standing down because of ill health. Gwynne sat as an independent after being suspended from Labour over offensive WhatsApp messages.It has long been rumoured that Burnham would mount a bid to replace Gwynne. Days before the partyâ€™s conference in Liverpool last year, Burnham told the Telegraph that Labour MPshad contacted him over the summer, asking him to stand, after becoming concerned at Starmerâ€™s growing unpopularity.Polling suggests Starmer is one of the least popular Labour prime ministers ever and Labour MPs are increasingly concerned about how his leadership will impact Mayâ€™s local elections.View image in fullscreenBurnhamâ€™s application could still be blocked by Labourâ€™s national executive committee, the partyâ€™s ruling body which is dominated by Starmer allies.Photograph: Bloomberg/Getty ImagesIn his letter, Burnham said Greater Manchester faced a â€œdirect threatâ€ to â€œeverything [it] has always been about from a brand of politics which seeks to pit people against each otherâ€, perceived as a reference to the growth of the populist right.Some polling has suggested Burnham is the only Labour candidate who could see off a challenge from Nigel Farageâ€™s party.Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, and Labourâ€™s deputy leader, Lucy Powell, both told the Fabian Societyâ€™s conference on Saturday that Burnham should be allowed to stand.Khan told the event in central London: â€œIâ€™m a firm believer in the best team having all the talent playing for them, and if Andy wants to return to parliament, I will try and make some time between now and the byelection to knock on some doors for him.â€Meanwhile Powell, who represents the neighbouring Manchester Central constituency, said the NEC should be wary of blocking Burnham from standing.She said it should be up to Burnham and party members in the constituency whether he is allowed to be the Labour candidate. She praised Burnham as â€œincredibly popularâ€ and as having changed Manchester â€œfor the betterâ€.She said: â€œIt should be up to Andy and the local members who will select their candidate, and our members are very discerning.â€Powell also acknowledged Labour could easily lose to either Reform or the Green party if the wrong candidate was selected.â€œIn that context, I always want to see the very best candidate, the person who can most help Labour win in that very difficult byelection,â€ she said. â€œI want to see the best candidates come forward and be able to come forward and help us win.â€Can Andy Burnham calm the anger in a Manchester seat Labour fears losing?Read moreHealth secretary Wes Streeting, perceived as Burnhamâ€™s biggest rival for the leadership should Starmer be deposed, refused to say whether he would support Burnhamâ€™s candidacy.â€œThis is a decision for the party, not for the cabinet,â€ he said. â€œI have been told in no uncertain terms that is my answer to the question. This is a really critical byelection. We have to work hard to earn peopleâ€™s trust and to earn every vote. We want the best possible candidate for that byelection.â€However, he added: â€œIn the last day or so, without having indicated whether he wants to run, Iâ€™ve seen some pretty unkind things said about Andy, as usual from people who donâ€™t put their names on this sort of briefing.â€œI think that is a disgraceful way to treat someone who is a Labour mayor, part of our team and part of our movement.â€Two members of the government have now said they think Burnham should be allowed to run. Energy secretary Ed Miliband, who led the party between 2010 and 2015, said: â€œI very much hope the local party will have the option of selectingAndy Burnhamas the candidate.â€Miatta Fahnbulleh, parliamentary undersecretary of state in the housing, communities and local government, said: â€œWeâ€™ve got the fight of our lives on our hands to beat Reform, which we have a moral duty to the country to do, and we need our best team on the pitch.â€œSo if he wants to put his hat in the ring and if he can persuade his members and persuade the electorate to bring him in then I think he would be an asset.â€View image in fullscreenMiatta Fahnbulleh MP speaks during the Co-operative party conference last year. She said Burnham â€˜would be an assetâ€™ if he could persuade members and the electorate to vote him in.Photograph: Jeff Moore/PAOther ministers believe it would be a mistake to allow Burnham to run.â€œI know No 10 is inept but surely they are not inept enough to allow a man to enter parliament for the sole purpose of challenging the prime minister,â€ one said.Another said that it would be a â€œbig decisionâ€ for the national executive committee, who will have to consider the prospect of a costly mayoral byelection.â€œIf he stands, it will be to go on the backbenches until the prime minister decides to give him a role,â€ one Starmer ally added.â€œThese are the facts he needs to consider. There is no vacancy for leader if that is where his ambition lies. Very few in the PLP [parliamentary Labour party] would welcome the distraction of any talk of a leadership challenge.â€Another backbench MP added: â€œWe are gearing up for crucial elections across the country. We really donâ€™t need a Burnham circus taking resources away â€“ he needs to put the party before personal ambition for a change.â€œBesides, a mayoral byelection would cost around Â£5m. It simply wouldnâ€™t be right to cut short his term in this way.â€Explore more on these topicsAndy BurnhamLabourKeir StarmerGreater ManchesterManchesterByelectionsLabour party leadershipnewsShareReuse this content

title: Storm Ingrid washes away part of Teignmouthâ€™s historic pier | UK weather | The Guardian
description: Yellow warnings for heavy rain remain in place across parts of Northern Ireland, Scotland and south-west England and Wales
Author: Morgan Ofori
Headline: Yellow warnings for heavy rain remain in place across parts of Northern Ireland, Scotland and south-west England and Wales
Content: The force of the waves stirred up by Storm Ingrid caused part of Teignmouthâ€™s Victorian pier to collapse into the sea on SaturdayPhotograph: Teignmouth Town Council/PAView image in
