title: Will Andy Burnham return to parliament â€“ and what would it mean for Keir Starmer? | Andy Burnham | The Guardian
description: Starmer loyalists argue Burnhamâ€™s return to Westminster would undermine the government â€“ but he has the support of powerful party figures
Author: Pippa Crerar
Headline: Starmer loyalists argue Burnhamâ€™s return to Westminster would undermine the government â€“ but he has the support of powerful party figures
Content: Many interpret Andy Burnhamâ€™s bid to return to parliament as the first step towards a challenge of Keir Starmerâ€™s leadership.Photograph: Ian Vogler/Daily Mirror/PAView image in fullscreenMany interpret Andy Burnhamâ€™s bid to return to parliament as the first step towards a challenge of Keir Starmerâ€™s leadership.Photograph: Ian Vogler/Daily Mirror/PAAndy BurnhamAnalysisWill Andy Burnham return to parliament â€“ and what would it mean for Keir Starmer?Pippa CrerarPolitical editorStarmer loyalists argue Burnhamâ€™s return to Westminster would undermine the government, but he has the support of powerful party figuresSat 24 Jan 2026 14.28 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 17.38 ESTShareWhen Lucy Powell, Labourâ€™s deputy leader and a close ally ofAndy Burnham, took to the stage at the Fabian conference in London on Saturday, she had a blunt message for her party.â€œI want to make sure that weâ€™re putting out the best team on the pitch, week after week, so we can win those important matches,â€ she told the audience.â€œI donâ€™t want to see [footballer Erling]Haaland on the bench because thereâ€™s been some falling out,â€ the lifelong Manchester City fan said.â€œBut Iâ€™m also going to get behind Pep Guardiola as our manager and make sure that we win matches, win those crucial matches, and go on to win the league. I think we can do that.â€With Labour flagging in the polls,Keir Starmerunder pressure and unpopular domestically, and dozens of MPs worried about hanging on to their seats at the next election, the view that the party should have its best players on the pitch is one widely shared.But the question pondered by many insideLabouron Saturday, as they whiled away the long hours until the 5pm deadline for Gorton and Denton byelection applications, was whether Andy Burnham sees himself as the star striker on the team, or its captain.â€˜The best interests of our partyâ€™: Andy Burnhamâ€™s letter to Labour NEC in fullRead moreBurnham is fully aware that many will see his return as just the first step in his plan to take over from Keir Starmer as leader. In his letter to Labourâ€™s ruling national executive committee (NEC), posted on social media at 5pm on the dot, Burnham confronted that head on.â€œI would be there to support the work of the government, not undermine it, and I have passed on this assurance to the prime minister,â€ he wrote.But does anybody believe him? Within moments of the byelection being confirmed last Thursday, Starmerâ€™s allies had alreadylaunched a â€œStop Andyâ€ campaignto prevent the Labour mayor from returning to parliament.With the party machinery tightly controlled by Morgan McSweeney, Starmerâ€™s chief of staff, it may look as though it would be an all but impossible task for Burnham to make it past the NEC to run.Party insiders point to the cost of a mayoral byelection campaign in Greater Manchester, which would mean that about Â£500,000 of party funding was diverted from other races across Britain. â€œThat alone should be enough to say no,â€ said one NEC source.Burnhamâ€™s insistence that he would be a team player has, unsurprisingly, been meet with scepticism in some quarters.â€œIf anyone believes heâ€™s doing it to support rather than undermine the government, I have a bridge to sell them. The NEC should just make the argument that we all know what Andy is up to and they wonâ€™t stand for it,â€ one minister said.Several Labour MPs drew parallels to Boris Johnson, who re-entered parliament in a byelection while still London mayor, whiledenying it was the start of a campaignto get into Downing Street. Once elected, he spent years undermining subsequent prime ministers before he achieved his aim.Yet there is a powerful lineup of party figures on Burnhamâ€™s side. They include Lucy Powell, her predecessor Angela Rayner, the former leader Ed Miliband, the London mayor Sadiq Khan, the two biggest unions, numerous MPs and party members. There would be significant disquiet if he was blocked.The NEC is not, of course, his only hurdle. He would actually have to win the seat â€“ potentially facing Reform UK and pro Gaza independents. Even the Green party leader, Zack Polanski, is considering running.Burnhamâ€™s regional approval ratings are high. He is not known as the King of the North for nothing. According to Ipsos, heâ€™s on +25 among voters in the north-west â€“ the only politician with a positive rating â€“ while Nigel Farage is on -29 and Starmer is on -40.Andy Burnham applies to stand for Labour in Gorton and Denton byelectionRead moreBut even if he makes it back to Westminster, a leadership contest is by no means automatic. While many MPs are despairing of Starmer, fearing that he will be unable to turn things round, the No 10 operation has been trying to woo them since the autumn.Starmerites argue that trying to remove their man during a period of such global instability would be deeply unwise. They add that the experience of running a city region is a world away from that of running a country.But nobody denies the May elections present the next moment of great peril for the prime minister. And if Burnham were back in parliament, he would be in position to strike.Another concern among MPs that could yet save Starmer: that a coup less than two years after winning a huge majority would cast Labour in the same light as the Tories, with their five prime ministers in less than 10 years.Powell, one of Burnhamâ€™s closest allies, touched on this in her speech, perhaps inadvertently. Notably, it was the line that got the loudest applause from the audience.â€œIâ€™ve been saying openly and publicly over the last few weeks that people have got to get behind Keir Starmer,â€ she told them. â€œWe are one Labour team, and I donâ€™t want to see this byelection â€¦ emerge into more infighting and talking about ourselves.â€ It may already be too late.Explore more on these topicsAndy BurnhamKeir StarmerLabouranalysisShareReuse this content

title: Is the supreme court ready to stand up to Trump over Federal Reserve attack? | Federal Reserve | The Guardian
description: Conservative majority appears eager to hand president greater power â€“ with one exception: the US central bank
Author: Lauren Aratani
Headline: Conservative majority appears eager to hand president greater power â€“ with one exception: the US central bank
Content: Donald Trump and Jerome Powell at the Federal Reserve in Washington in July last year.Photograph: Kent Nishimura/ReutersView image in fullscreenDonald Trump and Jerome Powell at the Federal Reserve in Washington in July last year.Photograph: Kent Nishimura/ReutersFederal ReserveIs the supreme court ready to stand up to Trump over Federal Reserve attack?Conservative majority appears eager to hand president greater power â€“ with one exception: the US central bankLauren Arataniin New YorkSat 24 Jan 2026 07.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 07.02 ESTShareDonald Trump has tried his usual tactics when it comes to getting the USFederal Reserveto lower interest rates: bully when persuasion doesnâ€™t work, and then fire when bullying doesnâ€™t work.In an unprecedented assault on the central bank, the president has called the Fed chair, Jerome Powell, â€œstupidâ€ and threatened to fire him for not cutting interest rates as quickly as Trump would like. Most recently, the justice department instigated acriminal investigationagainst Powell for testimony he gave about renovations at the Fedâ€™s headquarters. Even so, the Fed has not budged.Tactically, Trumpâ€™s assault on the Fed appears to be no different than his overhaul of the entire federal government. The president has learned if he pushes hard enough, he can get his way. And he has mostly been successful.But with the Fed, it seems that Trump may have met his match. At least as far as the supreme court is concerned. On Wednesday, the courtâ€™s justices, in oral arguments, appearedresoundingly skepticalof Trumpâ€™s firing of the Fed governor Lisa Cook.But while the justicesâ€™ skepticism could be interpreted as a sign that the court is checking executive authority, legal experts warn that any ruling against him may not be a harsh check on Trumpâ€™s power.Instead, the court appears to be carving out a special exception for the Fed at a time when the independence of other government agencies is still under threat.â€œThe consequences are potentially very harmful,â€ said Michael Dorf, a law professor at Cornell University. â€œThe supreme court is making war on independent agencies at the worst possible moment â€“ which is to say at a moment when you have a president who wants to centralize power in himself and wants to appoint people who are there because of their loyalty to him and [who] have no particular expertise.â€Trump fired Cook in August, alleging that she committed mortgage fraud by listing more than one property as her primary home, a move that would give her a better mortgage rate. The accusations were first posted on social media, and a few days later, Trump removed Cook. The White House made an appeal to the highest court after a lower federal courttemporarily reinstatedCook into her role.Because Cookâ€™s firing was haphazard, with no investigation or formal hearing about the alleged mortgage fraud, Trumpâ€™s case against Cook has opened up a host of questions the court could answer in a ruling. Were Cookâ€™s due-process rights violated because she didnâ€™t receive a hearing? Even if the mortgage allegations are true (Cookâ€™s lawyerssaythey have evidence it was an â€œinadvertent mistakeâ€), does mortgage fraud that took place before she was appointed a Fed governor constitute grounds for her removal? Should the case have been decided on by a lower court before reaching the supreme court?Making matters even more complicated is the nature of the Fed. The US central bank was created to be a quasi-private, independent government agency that is supposed to be protected from politics. Fed officials can only be fired by the president â€œfor causeâ€, though the law doesnâ€™t specify what â€œcauseâ€ is.Running in the background of the case is a big question, one that could have repercussions for the global economy: how much power will the supreme court allow a president to have over the Fed?Typically, constitutional experts look to see how the supreme court has decided similar cases, and Cookâ€™s firing was far from the first test of Trumpâ€™s executive powers.Last year, Trump fired independent officials, including two Democratic-appointed members of the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB), which oversees unions, and Rebecca Slaughter, the commissioner of the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), which regulates telecommunications and media.The supreme court allowed Trumpâ€™s firing of the officials to stand, and in Slaughterâ€™s case, constitutional experts anticipate a landmark ruling that will strengthen executive power for decades to come.Some within the US conservative legal movement have beenadvocatingfor the â€œunitary executiveâ€ theory â€“ the idea that the president should be able to fire any executive branch officers at will. At the heart of this belief is the idea that the votes of the American people should be the only check on the president.For conservative justices on the supreme court who support that theory, Trumpâ€™s second term has given them the perfect opportunity. Constitutional analysts say that Slaughterâ€™s FTC firing, which is still pending, will allow the court to narrow or even overturn Humphreyâ€™s Executor v United States, a landmark case from 1935 that limited the presidentâ€™s power to fire executive officials of independent agencies.But while conservative justices appear keen to hand the president even more power, there seems to be a single exception: the Fed.The supreme court even mentioned the central bank when it allowed Trumpâ€™s NLRB firings to go through, a notable event given that the Fed had nothing to do with the case.â€œThe Federal Reserve is a uniquely structured, quasi-private entity that follows in the distinct historical tradition of the First and Second Banks of the United States,â€ the courtâ€™s majority wrote at the time.Many took this as a signal from the court that, should Trump try to fire an executive within the Fed, the court would resist.Legal experts point out that, by law, the Fedâ€™s structure within the federal government is no different than the other quasi-private, independent agencies.â€œThe elephant in the room in this oral argument is how come, when it comes to Lisa Cook, suddenly the judges are interested in enforcing the statute [of independence]. Whereas with Rebecca Slaughter â€¦ and all these other people he improperly removed, they just conclude the status doesnâ€™t matter. His constitutional authority allows him to remove anybody for any reason. Like, whatâ€™s going on here?â€ said Lev Menand, a professor at Columbia Law School.The justicesâ€™ rationale seems to be as much economic as legal. Amy Coney Barrett, a member of the 6-3 conservative majority on the court, brought up the fact that â€œwe have amicus briefs from economists who tell us that if Governor Cook is [fired], that it could trigger a recessionâ€.â€œHow should we think about the public interest in a case like this?â€ she asked.Brett Kavanaugh, another conservative, asked Trumpâ€™s justice department direct questions about the â€œreal-worldâ€ importance of Fed independence.â€œLetâ€™s talk about the real-world downstream effects of this, because if this were set as a precedent, it just seems to me â€“ just thinking big picture â€“ what goes around comes around,â€ Kavanaugh said. â€œAll of the current presidentâ€™s appointees would likely be removed for cause on January 20, 2029 if thereâ€™s Democratic president â€¦ so what are we doing here?â€The power of the Fed comes largely from its ability to set interest rates. High interest rates make borrowing more expensive. It can slow inflation at the risk of increasing unemployment. That Trump wants lower interest rates is not surprising: lower interest rates can give the economy a short-term boost, but at the risk of rising prices later.Itâ€™s a balancing act that requires looking at the economic data and thinking about whatâ€™s best for the long-term stability of the economy, not the political fortunes of whoever is in power. Mess with that independence, and economic shocks such as a recession could be triggered.With Trumpâ€™s case against Cook, â€œan unstoppable force has met an immovable objectâ€, Menand said. While a majority of the justices may be fine with cutting down, for example, the FTCâ€™s independence, â€œitâ€™s a totally different game when it comes to the Federal Reserveâ€.â€œLarge business interests donâ€™t want to see the Federal Reserveâ€™s capacity degraded. They donâ€™t want to see the Federal Reserve politicized,â€ Menand said.To many legal scholars, the supreme court has been very lenient with Trumpâ€™s executive power, even beyond the issue of independent agencies. Over the last year, the court has allowed the administration tocontinueaggressive immigration enforcement tactics and has blocked lower courts from issuing nationwide injunctions that, as in his first term, could block some of his executive actions.â€œOne thing that concerns me a little bit is that if the court rules against Trump in the tariffs case, and in Cook, it will have gotten unearned prestige for being unbiased and standing up to Trump,â€ Dorf said. â€œYou stand up to him at the most extreme edge of what he does, [but] youâ€™re still allowing him to do all sorts of things that, in prior circumstances, we would have said the court ought to stand up to. But theyâ€™re not.â€Itâ€™s unclear when the court will release its decision on Cookâ€™s case, though it will probably issue a ruling by June.Explore more on these topicsFederal ReserveUS economyEconomicsDonald TrumpUS politicsfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Trump threatens Canada with 100% tariff over possible deal with China | US foreign policy | The Guardian
description: President also claims US refineries will process seized Venezuelan oil, saying â€˜we take the oilâ€™
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: President also claims US refineries will process seized Venezuelan oil, saying â€˜we take the oilâ€™
Content: Canadaâ€™s prime minister, Mark Carney, and Donald Trump at the White House on 7 October 2025.Photograph: Evan Vucci/APView image in fullscreenCanadaâ€™s prime minister, Mark Carney, and Donald Trump at the White House on 7 October 2025.Photograph: Evan Vucci/APUS foreign policyTrump threatens Canada with 100% tariff over possible deal with ChinaPresident also claims US refineries will process seized Venezuelan oil, saying â€˜we take the oilâ€™Guardian staff and ReutersSat 24 Jan 2026 10.04 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 19.13 ESTShareDonald Trumpon Saturday said he would impose a 100% tariff on all Canadian imports if the North American country makes a trade deal withChina.Beside that tariff threat, another Trump foreign policy maneuver to make news on Saturday involved the president announcing the US had taken the oil that was on recently seizedVenezuelantankers.The US president wrote on social media that if the Canadian prime minister, Mark Carney, â€œthinks he is going to makeCanadaa â€˜Drop Off Portâ€™ for China to send goods and products into the United States, he is sorely mistakenâ€.Trump withdraws invitation for Canada to join his global â€˜board of peaceâ€™Read moreâ€œChina will eat Canada alive, completely devour it, including the destruction of their businesses, social fabric, and general way of life,â€ Trump wrote on his Truth Social platform. â€œIf Canada makes a deal withChina, it will immediately be hit with a 100% Tariff against all Canadian goods and products coming into the [US].â€Trump has repeatedly invoked tariffs in a bid to bend countries to his will â€“ with some success, though he also repeatedlybacked downfrom his most extreme tariff-related threats.Notably, days earlier, Trump walked back his threat to impose sweeping tariffs on several European countries in order to facilitate the USâ€™s acquisition of Greenland, the semiautonomous Danish Arctic island which the president has been fixated on. Trump claimed he had reached â€œthe framework of a future dealâ€ on Greenland.In a New York Post interviewpublishedon Saturday, Trump boasted that the US will gain sovereignty and take ownership over land in Greenland where American bases are located.â€œWeâ€™ll have everything we want,â€ Trump reportedly told the Post. â€œWe have some interesting talks going on.â€Meanwhile, in the same Post interview published on Saturday, TrumpsaidUS refineries will process the oil his administration had taken from seized Venezuelan tankers.â€œLetâ€™s put it this way â€“ they donâ€™t have any oil,â€ Trump told the Post. â€œWe take the oil.â€The oil is being refined in â€œvarious placesâ€ including Houston, he said.The US military hasseizedseven Venezuela-linked tankers since the start of Trumpâ€™s month-long campaign to control Venezuelaâ€™s oil flows. Trump said on Tuesday that his administration had taken 50m barrels of oil out of Venezuela and was selling some of it in the open market.The intercepted vessels either were under US sanctions or said to be part of a â€œshadow fleetâ€ ofships that disguisetheir origins to move oil from major sanctioned producers: Iran, Russia or Venezuela.Trumpâ€™s Latin American foreign policy has homed in on Venezuela, initially aiming to push the Venezuelan president,NicolÃ¡s Maduro, from power. After failing to accomplish that aim through diplomacy, Trump ordered US forces to fly into the country to grab Maduro and his wife in an overnight raid on 3 January, bringing them to New York to face criminal drug-related charges anddetaining themthere.In Saturdayâ€™s interview with the Post, Trump bragged that a new weapon he called â€œthe discombobulatorâ€ played a central role in that raid.Those remarks came after the White House press secretary, Karoline Leavitt,sharedon social media a purported eyewitness account of the US military using some sort of â€œvery intense sound waveâ€ to incapacitate Maduroâ€™s bodyguards.Trump has said the US plans to control Venezuelaâ€™s oil resources indefinitely as it seeks to rebuild the countryâ€™s dilapidated oil industry in a $100bn plan thatis promptingmany raised eyebrows, not least fromenvironmentalistsand the US oil giants.Explore more on these topicsUS foreign policyDonald TrumpCanadaChinaTrump tariffsTariffsOilnewsShareReuse this content

title: â€˜Repatriate the goldâ€™: German economists advise withdrawal from US vaults | Germany | The Guardian
description: Shift in relations and unpredictability of Donald Trump make it â€˜risky to store so much gold in the USâ€™, say experts
Author: Kate Connolly
Headline: Shift in relations and unpredictability of Donald Trump make it â€˜risky to store so much gold in the USâ€™, say experts
Content: Michael JÃ¤ger, head of the European Taxpayers Association, said Donald Trump was â€˜unpredictableâ€™, and that this meant â€˜our gold is no longer safe in the Fedâ€™s vaultsâ€™.Photograph: Michael Dalder/ReutersView image in fullscreenMichael JÃ¤ger, head of the European Taxpayers Association, said Donald Trump was â€˜unpredictableâ€™, and that this meant â€˜our gold is no longer safe in the Fedâ€™s vaultsâ€™.Photograph: Michael Dalder/ReutersGermanyâ€˜Repatriate the goldâ€™: German economists advise withdrawal from US vaultsShift in relations and unpredictability of Donald Trump make it â€˜risky to store so much gold in the USâ€™, say expertsKate Connollyin BerlinSat 24 Jan 2026 03.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 03.02 ESTShareGermany is facing calls to withdraw its billions of eurosâ€™ worth of gold from US vaults, spurred on by the shift in transatlantic relations and the unpredictability ofDonald Trump.Germany holds the worldâ€™s second biggest national gold reserves after the US, of which approximately â‚¬164bn (Â£122bn) worth â€“ 1,236 tonnes â€“ is stored in New York.Emanuel MÃ¶nch, a leading economist and former head of research at Germanyâ€™s federal bank, the Bundesbank, called for the gold to be brought home, saying it was too â€œriskyâ€ for it to be kept in the US under the current administration.â€œGiven the current geopolitical situation, it seems risky to store so much gold in the US,â€ he told the financial newspaperHandelsblatt. â€œIn the interest of greater strategic independence from the US, the Bundesbank would therefore be well advised to consider repatriating the gold.â€World stock markets brace for turbulence after Trumpâ€™s latest tariff shockRead moreStefan Kornelius, the spokesperson for Friedrich Merzâ€™s coalition government, said recently that withdrawal of the gold reserves was not currently under consideration.But MÃ¶nch is only the latest in a string of economists and financial experts to argue that such a move would be in keeping with the greater strategic independence that Europeâ€™s largest economy has been seeking from the US in recent months.Michael JÃ¤ger, the head of the European Taxpayers Association (TAE) as well as the Association of German Taxpayers, has also said Berlin should make its move, arguing that the USâ€™s stated desire to seize Greenland should concentrate minds.â€œTrump is unpredictable and he does everything to generate revenue. Thatâ€™s why our gold is no longer safe in the Fedâ€™s vaults,â€ JÃ¤ger told theRheinische Post. â€œWhat happens if the Greenland provocation continues? â€¦ The risk is increasing that the German Bundesbank will no longer be able to access its gold. Therefore, it should repatriate its reserves.â€JÃ¤ger said he had written last year to the Bundesbank and the finance ministry, urging them to â€œbring our gold homeâ€.Until recently the gold issue has been the preserve mainly of the far-right Alternative fÃ¼r Deutschland (AfD), which has repeatedly urged the return of the gold for patriotic reasons. But it has increasingly crept into the mainstream discourse.Katharina Beck, the finance spokesperson for the opposition Greens in the Bundestag, has also spoken out in favour of relocating the gold bars, calling them an â€œimportant anchor of stability and trustâ€, which â€œmust not become pawns in geopolitical disputesâ€.However, Clemens Fuest, the president of the Institute for Economic Research (Ifo) and one of the countryâ€™s most prominent economists, warned against such a move, saying it could lead to unintended consequences and would â€œonly pour oil on the fire of the current situationâ€, he told the Rheinische Post.Germanyâ€™s total gold reserves are worth almost â‚¬450bn.Just over half are held at the Bundesbank in Frankfurt am Main, 37% in the vaults of the US Federal Reserve in New York and 12% at the Bank of England in London, the global centre of gold trading. The Bundesbank says it regularly undertakes an audit of the supplies of gold it holds in storage.Speaking last October at the International Monetary Fundâ€™s (IMF) autumn meetings in Washington DC, the Bundesbank president, Joachim Nagel, assured attenders there was â€œno cause for concernâ€ over the German gold held at the US Federal Reserve.World is entering time of â€˜great power politicsâ€™, warns German chancellorRead moreFrauke Heiligenstadt, the parliamentary group spokesperson on financial policy for the Social Democrats, junior partners in the government, said that while she understood concerns about the gold reserves, there was no need for panic.â€œGermanyâ€™s gold reserves are well diversified,â€ she said. Because half of them are located in Frankfurt, â€œour ability to act is guaranteedâ€. Having gold in New York made sense, she added, because â€œGermany, Europe and the US are closely linked in terms of financial policyâ€.But, amid Trumpâ€™s hardening rhetoric towards his western partners, an increasing number of Merzâ€™s Christian Democrats have been speaking out in favour of relocation.â€œDue to the Trump administration, the US is no longer a reliable partner,â€ Ulrike Neyer, a professor of economics at the University of DÃ¼sseldorf, told the Rheinische Post.Explore more on these topicsGermanyEconomicsGoldDonald TrumpUS politicsEuropeCommoditiesnewsShareReuse this content

title: Pittsburgh Steelers line up Mike McCarthy as next head coach | Pittsburgh Steelers | The Guardian
description: Pittsburgh are set to appoint Super Bowl-winning coach Mike McCarthy after Mike Tomlinâ€™s departure, according to a report by ESPNâ€™s Adam Schefter
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Pittsburgh are set to appoint Super Bowl-winning coach Mike McCarthy after Mike Tomlinâ€™s departure, according to a report by ESPNâ€™s Adam Schefter
Content: Dallas Cowboys head coach Mike McCarthy looks on during a January game against the Washington Commanders.Photograph: Gareth Patterson/APView image in fullscreenDallas Cowboys head coach Mike McCarthy looks on during a January game against the Washington Commanders.Photograph: Gareth Patterson/APPittsburgh SteelersPittsburgh Steelers line up Mike McCarthy as next head coachSteelers to turn to McCarthy after Tomlin exits roleMcCarthy won Super Bowl with Packers in 2010Hire rekindles link with former QB Aaron RodgersSat 24 Jan 2026 14.07 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 15.24 ESTShareMike McCarthyâ€™s next job is set to bring him back to where it all began.The Pittsburgh Steelers intend to hire the Super Bowl-winning coach as their next head coach, according to multiple reports, with ESPNfirst breaking the news. A person familiar with the discussions told the Associated Press the sides are moving toward an agreement, though a deal has not yet been finalized.For McCarthy, the move would represent a homecoming. The 62-year-old grew up in the Greenfield neighborhood, only a short drive from the Steelersâ€™ South Side practice facility, and now stands poised to take over one of the NFLâ€™s most tradition-bound franchises.He is expected to replace Mike Tomlin, whostepped away earlier this monthafter 19 seasons in charge. Tomlin leaves behind a rÃ©sumÃ© defined by consistency â€“ 193 regular-season wins, a Super Bowl title and no losing seasons â€“ but also lingering frustration over postseason stagnation. Pittsburgh have exited the playoffs at the first hurdle in each of their last six appearances, all by double-digit margins, including this seasonâ€™s home defeat by the Houston Texans.McCarthy arrives with a profile unlike the men who preceded him. Since 1969, the Steelers have employed just three head coaches: Hall of Famers Chuck Noll and Bill Cowher, followed by Tomlin. All were relatively untested assistants when hired. McCarthy, by contrast, brings 18 seasons of head-coaching experience and a career record of 185â€“123â€“2, including playoff games.Thirteen of those seasons came in Green Bay, where he guided the Packers to a Super Bowl victory after the 2010 season â€“ a win that came at the expense of Tomlin and the Steelers â€“ before spending five years leading the Dallas Cowboys. His tenure in Dallas ended after the 2024 season when the sides failed to agree on a contract extension.The Steelers conducted a wide-ranging search after Tomlinâ€™s departure, interviewing close to a dozen candidates across the league. That group included Minnesota Vikings defensive coordinator Brian Flores and Los Angeles Chargers defensive coordinator Jesse Minter, whowas hired this week by the Baltimore Ravensto replace John Harbaugh. Ultimately, Pittsburgh landed on experience, entrusting McCarthy with a roster that has hovered in competitive but unspectacular territory for much of the past decade.In many ways, the Steelersâ€™ struggles have centered on quarterback instability. Drafting consistently in the high teens or low 20s has made landing a long-term answer difficult, a problem compounded by the decision not to identify Ben Roethlisbergerâ€™s successor early and the failed gamble on first-round pick Kenny Pickett in 2022.IfAaron Rodgersdoes not return for another season, Pittsburgh would open the 2026 campaign with their sixth different Week 1 starting quarterback in six years. Rodgers, who will be a free agent in March, spent last season with the Steelers and won a Super Bowl under McCarthy in Green Bay, a connection that adds intrigue to the hire. The Steelers currently hold the 21st pick in a draft widely viewed as thin at quarterback.Pittsburgh could again prioritize other needs â€“ including wide receiver and cornerback â€“ rather than forcing a quarterback solution. Still, team president Art Rooney II has rejected the idea of a reset.â€œI donâ€™t like that word that much,â€ Rooney said recently. â€œWeâ€™ll try to compete day one if we can.â€McCarthyâ€™s impending arrival suggests the Steelers intend to do exactly that.Explore more on these topicsPittsburgh SteelersNFLAaron RodgersUS sportsShareReuse this content

Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: The NBA postponed Timberwolves-Warriors after a fatal federal shooting near Target Center, citing safety concerns and rescheduling the game for Sunday
Content: Demonstrators against the Ice deployment carry signs while marching past the Target Center in downtown Minneapolis on Friday.Photograph: Bloomberg/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenDemonstrators against the Ice deployment carry signs while marching past the Target Center in downtown Minneapolis on Friday.Photograph: Bloomberg/Getty ImagesNBANBA game in Minneapolis between Warriors and Timberwolves postponed after shootingNBA postpones Wolves-Warriors game after shootingAlex Pretti, 37, killed by border control near arenaGame rescheduled for Sunday amid safety concernsAgenciesSat 24 Jan 2026 16.11 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 20.04 ESTShareThe NBA game between the Minnesota Timberwolves and Golden State Warriors was postponed on Saturday afternoon followinganother fatal shooting by a federal officerin Minneapolis.The game was rescheduled for Sunday afternoon. The Timberwolves and Warriors are also scheduled to play on Monday night.The league announced the decision was made to â€œprioritize the safety and security of the Minneapolis communityâ€ after37-year-old Alex Pretti was killedin a confrontation with officers on a street in a commercial district less than two miles from Target Center, the downtown arena where the Timberwolves play. With the crowd of protesters growing around the shooting site on Saturday, the Minnesota National Guard was assisting local police to try to keep the peace.The Minnesota Twins were holding their annual winter fan festival at Target Field, across the street from Target Center, and ended the event an hour early for the â€œexpedited departureâ€ of all guests.Thousands of people marched through downtown on Friday with the air temperature well below zero in protest of the presence and tactics of the federal force that swelled to about 3,000 officers in the Twin Cities area this month as part of the Trump administrationâ€™s immigration crackdown.Two weeks ago, 37-year-old Renee Good was fatally shot in her car as she drove away from a group of officers following a confrontation. title: Arne Slot says Liverpool â€˜ran out of energyâ€™ in defeat at Bournemouth | Liverpool | The Guardian
description: Arne Slot conceded his Liverpool side ran out of steam in defeat at Bournemouth, after Amine Adliâ€™s 95th-minute winner condemned his side to a first loss since November
Author: Ben Fisher
Headline: Arne Slot conceded his Liverpool side ran out of steam in defeat at Bournemouth, after Amine Adliâ€™s 95th-minute winner condemned his side to a first loss since November
Content: Arne Slot said he could not criticise his players for lacking energy due to the rigours of the fixture list.Photograph: Robin Jones/AFC Bournemouth/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenArne Slot said he could not criticise his players for lacking energy due to the rigours of the fixture list.Photograph: Robin Jones/AFC Bournemouth/Getty ImagesLiverpoolArne Slot says Liverpool â€˜ran out of energyâ€™ in defeat at BournemouthHead coach highlights away game in Champions LeagueSlot questions fixture list after difficult away tripBen Fisherat the Vitality StadiumSat 24 Jan 2026 16.42 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 19.28 ESTShareArne Slot conceded his side ran out of steamin defeat at Bournemouth, after Amine Adliâ€™s 95th-minute winner condemned Liverpool to a first loss since November. Liverpool pulled level from 2-0 down late on courtesy of Dominik Szoboszlaiâ€™s sensational free-kick, but Bournemouth responded impressively and Adli struck a winner from a long throw with almost the last kick.The Liverpool head coach felt the referee, Michael Salisbury, should have played more second-half stoppage time taking in substitutions and video assistant referee checks but admitted he feared aBournemouthwinner. â€œI think it is safe to say they could have scored 3-2 a little bit earlier,â€ Slot said, alluding to chances for the Bournemouth pair Evanilson and Ryan Christie. â€œA few of our players ran out of energy and I cannot even criticise them for that because two days ago [three] we had to play an away game. Weâ€™re the only team that played in the Champions League that has two games in between.Adli scrambles last-gasp winner as Bournemouth take down LiverpoolRead moreâ€œThis time after an away game [a3-0 win in Marseille], another away game against one of the most intense teams in the league and I mainly played the same players because of the players we have available. Conceding a goal is always frustrating, but especially if there is no time left to come back into the game.â€At full time Slot told the officials he was unhappy that only four minutes of stoppage time were allocated. â€œFor me, four minutes of added time was not enough but in the end that didnâ€™t matter because they scored,â€ he said. â€œAlthough then we couldâ€™ve maybe had two or three [more] minutes but this game shouldnâ€™t have had four minutes of extra time. There was a free-kick that took two or three minutes, there were VAR moments, there were substitutions. Thatâ€™s what I said to them.â€Slot refused to criticise his captain, Virgil van Dijk, for his defensive error in the buildup to Evanilsonâ€™s opener and would not be drawn when asked whether Andy Robertson would remain at the club. Tottenhamare pursuing a dealto sign the Scotland captain, who replaced Milos Kerkez at half-time. The left-back, a Â£40m buy from Bournemouth last summer, was at fault for the hostsâ€™ second goal, scored while Liverpool had only 10 men on the pitch after Joe Gomez was forced off injured.Bournemouthâ€™s head coach, Andoni Iraola, expressed his delight that his side were rewarded for shifting their mentality and gameplan. â€œNormally we go full gas from the beginning, we keep our energy until the end,â€ he said. â€œBut now, probably because we donâ€™t have the numbers and need to adapt a little bit, we are choosing our moments a little bit more and knowing we might need to save a little bit of energy.â€Explore more on these topicsLiverpoolBournemouthArne SlotnewsShareReuse this content

title: Shiffrin returns to giant slalom podium as US stack top eight in Czechia | Mikaela Shiffrin | The Guardian
description: Mikaela Shiffrin finished third for her first GS podium in two years as Sara Hector won in Czechia, three weeks before the Milano Cortina Olympics
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Mikaela Shiffrin finished third for her first GS podium in two years as Sara Hector won in Czechia, three weeks before the Milano Cortina Olympics
Content: Paula Moltzan, Sara Hector and Mikaela Shiffrin, from left to right, celebrate after Saturdayâ€™s giant slalom race in Spindleruv Mlyn, Czechia.Photograph: Millo Moravski/Agence Zoom/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenPaula Moltzan, Sara Hector and Mikaela Shiffrin, from left to right, celebrate after Saturdayâ€™s giant slalom race in Spindleruv Mlyn, Czechia.Photograph: Millo Moravski/Agence Zoom/Getty ImagesMikaela ShiffrinShiffrin returns to giant slalom podium as US stack top eight in CzechiaShiffrin returns to GS podium weeks before CortinaHector wins first giant slalom since January 2025Moltzan second, Oâ€™Brien fifth and Hurt eighth for USAgenciesSat 24 Jan 2026 09.50 ESTShareMikaela Shiffrin earned a place on the podium of a World Cup giant slalom for the first time in two years Saturday, finishing third in the last GS before the Milan Cortina Olympics.The race was won by defending Olympic champion Sara Hector, who held on to her opening run lead for her first victory since January 2025.â€œYou always have to keep working, itâ€™s so many strong girls as you can see today,â€ the Swedish winner said in a course-side interview. â€œI am super happy that in the end I crossed the finish line first. Thatâ€™s a really cool feeling.â€Shiffrin, the 2018 Olympic GS gold medalist, trailed Hector by 0.23 seconds and the American shared the podium with second-placed teammate Paula Moltzan, who was 0.18 off the pace.Shiffrin holds the womenâ€™s record for most career World Cup GS wins with 22 but hadnâ€™t had a top-three result in the discipline in 11 events since coming runner-up at a race in Slovakia in January 2024.Six days later, she crashed in a downhill on the course that will be used for the Olympics next month and then didnâ€™t compete in GS again until the start of the 2024-25 season.In November 2024, she sustained a puncture wound to the right side of her abdomen and severe damage to her oblique abdominal muscles in a crash at her home GS in Killington, Vermont, and subsequently suffered from lingering post-traumatic stress disorder.This season, Shiffrin racked up three fourth places before ultimately returning to the podium Saturday, three weeks before the Olympic race in Cortina dâ€™Ampezzo.Moltzan, whoâ€™s chasing her maiden career win, got her third podium of the season, leading a strong showing by the US team, with Nina Oâ€™Brien in fifth and AJ Hurt in eighth.In the opening run, Hector edged out Camille Rast of Switzerland by 0.02 seconds, with GS rankings leader Julia Scheib of Austria 0.26 back in third.Rast dropped to fourth, while Scheib skied out in the final run.Overall World Cup champion Federica Brignone, who made a strong return to racing from a nine-month injury layoff on Tuesday, and her Italian teammate Sofia Goggia, the 2018 Olympic downhill champion, sat out the event in Czechia, with a weekend of speed racing coming up in Switzerland next week ahead of their home Olympics.A slalom on the same hill is scheduled for Sunday.Explore more on these topicsMikaela ShiffrinSkiingUS sportsShareReuse this content

title: â€˜A long time comingâ€™: table tennis world hails Marty Supreme-fueled boom | Table tennis | The Guardian
description: An Oscar-tipped cult biopic, sold-out matches and fresh faces at clubs suggest table tennis may finally be breaking free of its basement reputation in the US
Author: Mattha Busby
Headline: An Oscar-tipped cult biopic, sold-out matches and fresh faces at clubs suggest table tennis may finally be breaking free of its basement reputation in the US
Content: This image released by A24 shows TimothÃ©e Chalamet in a scene from Marty Supreme.Photograph: APView image in fullscreenThis image released by A24 shows TimothÃ©e Chalamet in a scene from Marty Supreme.Photograph: APTable tennisâ€˜A long time comingâ€™: table tennis world hails Marty Supreme-fueled boomOnce dismissed as a basement game, table tennis is enjoying an unlikely US revival as the Oscar-tipped biopic Marty Supreme collides with a wave of new playersMattha BusbySat 24 Jan 2026 03.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 03.02 ESTShareFor decades in the US, table tennis has lived a double life: one of the most widely played sports in the country, yet still dismissed by many as a basement pursuit. Now, unexpectedly, it is having a cultural moment.The release ofMarty Supreme, a film steeped in obsession and myth, and loosely based on postwar American table tennis champion Marty Reisman, has pushed ping-pong into the pop-culture mainstream â€“ just as US Major League Table Tennis sells out matches, clubs report growing interest, and younger players pick up paddles for the first time.â€œThe movie has been a catalyst,â€ says David Silberman, cofounder ofPingPod, which operates table tennis venues across the US northeast. â€œWeâ€™re starting to see it in the data of our business.â€In 2022, Silberman started playing table tennis regularly withMarty Supremedirector Josh Safdie â€“ whom he describes as â€œa solid beginner playerâ€ by competitive standards â€“ at Pingpodâ€™s Midtown, New York location. â€œHeâ€™s fascinated by the sport â€¦ and how itâ€™s always been considered a second-rate sport,â€ says Silberman.â€œWhen Christmas Day came along and the movie premiered we pretty much immediately saw a 20-40% spike in year-on-year new customer reservations, and existing customer utilisation went up 10-15%. Clearly a wave of new people are picking up the paddle.â€Major League Table Tennis (MLTT), the first professional table tennis league in the US, established in 2023, just set an all-time regular season ticket sales record, according to founder Flint Lane. â€œNo doubt some of that is Marty related.â€View image in fullscreenLily Zhang is a six-time US national champion and four-time Olympian.Photograph: Jung Yeon-Je/AFP/Getty ImagesThe sport already had momentum, adds MLTT senior vice-president for marketing, Matt Parker, â€œbut the film has helped reintroduce it to a younger, culture-driven audience thatâ€™s now showing up at matches and engaging with our content.â€MLTTâ€™s first event since the release of Marty Supreme sold out in Portland, Oregon, at the beginning of the month â€“ markingthe first selloutand the highest regular-season attendance weekend in league history, with more than 2,000 tickets sold.â€œTable tennis is definitely having a moment right now, and I love to see it,â€ says Lily Zhang, a six-time US national champion in womenâ€™s singles who in Novemberbecame the first womanto rank No 1 on MLTTâ€™s power rankings list. â€œItâ€™s been a long time coming.Marty Supremehas definitely launched table tennis into the pop culture mainstream, but I would love to see more of that interest translate over to the professional side and in supporting current professional players, because we could really use it.â€A 2024 Wall Street Journal profile on Zhang, a four-time Olympian who reached the round of 16 at the Paris Olympics,highlightedhow difficult it is for even the best table tennis players to make a living in the sport in the US. Estimateshave longplaced US participation in table tennis at about 16 million Americans per year, though it is a casual pursuit for most.â€œPeople are often surprised when they hear that Iâ€™m a professional player â€“ â€˜ping pong is an Olympic sport?â€™ â€“ and a lot of them like to tell me they could â€˜probably beatâ€™ me in a match just because theyâ€™ve played a lot in their basement,â€ adds Zhang. â€œI laugh it off, but itâ€™s really because there is such a lack of understanding of how intense, technical and challenging the professional game is.â€The lack of appreciation of the skills of table tennis Olympians was perhaps on show in a recent BBC interview with TimothÃ©e Chalamet, who played the titular Marty in Marty Supreme,winning the Golden Globefor best actor ahead of the Oscars in March. The interviewerasked himif he may be able to make the team for the LA Olympics in 2028. Chalamet humbly responded there was less than a one-a-million chance despite having begun training for the role in 2018.View image in fullscreenFans look on as the Chicago Wind take on the Texas Smash during the Major League Tennis Championship last year in Philadelphia.Photograph: Isaiah Vazquez/Getty ImagesOn Instagram,a series of clipsfrom professional table tennis matches feature surreal replays of intense rallies of such a velocity which almost defy belief. It appears to be a matter of time before the American public gets hooked on the drama, and the MLTT says that â€œwagering is set to launch in the coming months, further expanding fan engagement opportunities.â€But while the film has helped spark curiosity, it has also exposed a deeper tension between the chaotic fantasy on screen and the quieter reality of a sport that, for millions of players, is less about rage and lone-wolf genius than focus, discipline, longevity and mental health.â€œThe film has created a cultural ripple,â€ says Luba Sadovska, co-owner of North Shore Table Tennis Club in Vancouver, Canada, and a former Czechoslovakian national representative player. â€œWeâ€™re seeing new people coming forward who want to join the club as members. A lot of them played years ago, so it really feels like theyâ€™re reconnecting with their younger selves.â€Her club hosted ahardbat paddle doublestournament after the movieâ€™s release, since part of the Marty Supreme tale is his frustration at being beaten by a Japanese player who was an early adopter of the spongier bat that helped foster the modern game. â€œIt was an absolute blast â€“ great energy, lots of laughter, and a really strong sense of community,â€ says Sadovska.But inside the sport, â€œitâ€™s also prompted a kind of reckoning â€“ about what gets mythologized, what gets left out, and what table tennis actually offers in real life.â€ Anger doesnâ€™t have a place in real table tennis, she says, since it is considered a weakness â€œand professional players donâ€™t show their weaknesses that easily.â€At Vitality Pong Neuro Active Clinic, which Sadovska co-founded, table tennis is played as a neuroactive training tool for people with Parkinsonâ€™s, Alzheimerâ€™s, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and following strokes. â€œTheyâ€™re looking [to attune their] focus and resilience, without burning out or breaking down.â€The rapidity of table tennis, with the required quick reflexes, the spin of the ball and the instantaneous processing and coordination demanded of even amateur players, underpins its â€œprofoundâ€ set of mental health benefits, adds Silberman, whose company hit a $50m valuationin 2024. â€œIt staves off neurodegenerative diseases,â€ he says. â€œItâ€™s just unequivocally a good thing in our society.â€Explore more on these topicsTable tennisMarty SupremeUS sportsfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Brenden Aaronson enters peak form at the right time for Leeds and the US | USA | The Guardian
description: The Philadelphia Union product has added end product to his trademark hustle â€“ the trick now is keeping the good form going.
Author: James Nalton
Headline: The Philadelphia Union product has added end product to his trademark hustle â€“ the trick now is keeping the good form going.
Content: Brenden Aaronson earned a standing ovation for his performance against Fulham.Photograph: Richard Sellers/PAView image in fullscreenBrenden Aaronson earned a standing ovation for his performance against Fulham.Photograph: Richard Sellers/PAUSABrenden Aaronson enters peak form at the right time for Leeds and the USThe Philadelphia Union product has added end product to his trademark hustle â€“ can he keep the good form going?James NaltonSat 24 Jan 2026 05.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 05.02 ESTShareTiming is everything in a World Cup year, and Brenden Aaronsonâ€™s has been pretty much perfect.Scoring a goal and putting in a top performanceagainst your teamâ€™s biggest rivalis something all players dream of. To do so when your family is watching in the stands and a reporter from your home town newspaper, the Philadelphia Inquirer, is in the press box makes it all the better. Aaronson did all of the above at Elland Road for Leeds United against Manchester United earlier this month.The 2026 World Cup may transform US soccer. The 2030 World Cup could be even betterRead moreBeyond this isolated, personal moment, there is the bigger picture of a player hopinh to catch the eye of the USMNT head coach, Mauricio Pochettino. Such a high-profile goal is certainly one way to do it, as is continuing that good form into subsequent weeks. Once again, Aaronson has done it all.Aaronson scored twice in a subsequent 4-3 defeat at Newcastle United, emerging as one of the best and most prominent players in one of the most dramatic games in the English league so far this season. (Though it should be noted he also conceded a penalty late on from a handball).â€œI turned off for a minute and I know I canâ€™t lift my hand like this around the box,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™sfootball at the end of the day.â€The scoring run took the former Philadelphia Union player to four league goals for the season, level with suchPremier Leagueluminaries as Mohamed Salah and Bukayo Saka. Regardless of performance levels, achieving any kind of regular attacking output in the goals and assists columns in the Premier League isnâ€™t easy. Just ask some of the leagueâ€™s biggest summer signings Benjamin Å eÅ¡ko, Florian Wirtz, Viktor GyÃ¶keres and Xavi Simons, none of whom have more goal contributions than Aaronson, who has three assists to go with his four goals.Being left out of the lineup for Leedsâ€™ subsequent visit to Championship side Derby County in what was ahistoric weekend in the English FA Cupwas less a case of being dropped, more an indication of the Americanâ€™s importance to his club. Premier League teams will often use the early rounds of cup competitions to rest players considered key to their league campaign. Leedsâ€™ primary aim this year is to avoid relegation, so manager Daniel Farke clearly sees Aaronsonâ€™s availability in the league as crucial to achieving that aim. He returned for the clubâ€™s next Premier League match, earning a standing ovation at home for his performance against Fulham before being subbed off.Things have not always been this rosy for Aaronson at Leeds. His relationship with the club and its supporters has had its ups and downs, especially when, after Leeds was relegated in 2023, he left on loan for Bundesliga side Union Berlin. Itâ€™s the kind of move that can be seen as showing a lack of loyalty, abandoning a team when it needs you the most, but itâ€™s also a fairly common occurrence and can be as much about a club balancing its wage bill as it is a playerâ€™s decision.Aaronson returned for the 2024-25 Championship season after an unspectacular spell in Berlin, and went on to be part of the Leeds team that topped the second tier with 100 points to secure a return to the Premier League. Plenty of minutes were logged in that Championship-winning campaign, and plenty of yards covered. Itâ€™s a built-in work rate that you get with Aaronson that can soon start to win fans over again, but the addition of goals, assists, and quality in key moments to complement the toil completes the job.Then and now: what has changed since the opening Premier League games?Read moreHis nine goals in the 2024-25 campaign were a career best, and the flurry of goals to begin 2026 has put him on track to better that number in 2025-26 and reach double figures. Christian Pulisic never reached double figures for goals in the Premier League, despite doing so in each of his seasons in Serie A for Milan.In some ways, it has been an unusual Premier League season so far, with the champions Liverpool dropping off despite a record summer transfer spend, Chelsea sacking their Club World Cup-winning manager Enzo Maresca, and Aston Villa and Sunderland making impressive starts.Leeds are in the bottom half of the table, but still eight points above the relegation places. Falling off rather than moving further up will always be the prediction for a newly promoted team, but in a strong and competitive Premier League, Leeds are holding their own, just four points off a congested mid-table gathering and 10 points from a European spot.Aaronson will be key to any further progress. His finishing and decision-making in the final third will need to remain at the new and improved 2026 level, especially since Facundo Buonanotte has just arrived on loan from Brighton as potential competition for his place in the lineup. It will also need to remain at this level to ensure he returns home for the World Cup this summer as a participant rather than an onlooker.â€œThat one felt really good, to be honest with you,â€Aaronson toldthe Philadelphia Inquirerâ€™s Jonathan Tannenwald of his goal against Manchester United. â€œTo score against your rival is huge, and Iâ€™m really proud of it. And keep going from here.â€Keeping going is something Aaronson does better than most. The combination of work rate and quality he possesses can be an asset to any team, and is something Pochettino values. The quality aspect of this dynamic can be fleeting, but the 25-year-old has entered a good run of form at exactly the right time, both for his clubâ€™s hopes of remaining in the Premier League and for his USMNT chances in a World Cup year.Explore more on these topicsUSAUS sportsLeeds UnitedPremier LeaguefeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Rory McIlroy backs Muirfield for Open return despite â€˜lowest pointâ€™ in 2013 | Rory McIlroy | The Guardian
description: Rory McIlroy has endorsed Muirfieldâ€™s case for an Open revival despite reaching his golfing nadir at the Scottish links in 2013
Author: Ewan Murray
Headline: Rory McIlroy has endorsed Muirfieldâ€™s case for an Open revival despite reaching his golfing nadir at the Scottish links in 2013
Content: Rory McIlroy  on his way to a round of 71 for a three under par at the Dubai Desert Classic.Photograph: Ali Haider/EPAView image in fullscreenRory McIlroy  on his way to a round of 71 for a three under par at the Dubai Desert Classic.Photograph: Ali Haider/EPARory McIlroyRory McIlroy backs Muirfield for Open return despite â€˜lowest pointâ€™ in 2013Scottish links last staged championship 13 years agoâ€˜Itâ€™s one of the best courses on the rota and in the UKâ€™Ewan Murrayat Emirates Golf ClubSat 24 Jan 2026 07.04 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 08.54 ESTShareRory McIlroy has endorsed Muirfieldâ€™s case for an Open revival despite reachinga golfing nadirthere when the major was last staged at the Scottish links in 2013. McIlroy declared he felt â€œunconsciousâ€ and â€œbrain deadâ€ while en route to a missed cut in East Lothian 13 years ago.The refusal of the Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers to admit women â€“ a scenariothat changed in 2017â€“ and thelow attendance at Muirfieldon that last visit played a part in the absence of the Open. Yet the venue is still rightly regarded as one of the finest in the world.Patrick Reed unfazed by fines as he hits the front in Dubai Desert ClassicRead moreThe R&A has yet to announce Open sites beyond St Andrews in 2027. Muirfield is at least part of that discussion and rightly so, according to McIlroy. â€œIt would be wonderful if it was,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™m not privy to those conversations, but Muirfield deserves to be back on the Open rota.â€œThey rectified the issues they had. Itâ€™s a wonderful course. Itâ€™s one of the best courses on the rota and in the UK. As well, it has to commercially make sense. I think Mark Darbon [the chief executive] has been brought in to [the R&A] make the Open Championship commercially viable. I would say Muirfield, that area, North Berwick, that would probably be one of the more commercially viable opens.â€Portmarnock in Dublin is expected to stage the first Open outside the United Kingdom in the near future. A further and logistical complication with Muirfield is the staging of the Scottish Open at the Renaissance Club, which is essentially next door, on the previous week.View image in fullscreenRory McIlroy suffered in the Open at Muirfield in 2013. Rounds of 79 and 75 meant he missed the cut.Photograph: Toby Melville/ReutersMcIlroy laughed when contemplating 2013. Rounds of 79 and 75 meant he exited at 12 over par. â€œCould have been my lowest point in my professional career,â€ said the Masters champion. â€œIâ€™ve won an Open since then, Iâ€™ve played well in the Open. Yeah, 2013 feels like a lifetime ago.â€Royal Lytham & St Annes has endured an even longer wait than Muirfield. The Lancashire links last staged the Open in 2012, when Ernie Els prevailed over Adam Scott in dramatic style. The 2029 Open will mark 50 years since Seve Ballesteros triumphed at Lytham.â€œWith Birkdale this year, it would be very early to bring an Open back to that region in 2028,â€ McIlroy said. â€œThe Womenâ€™s Open is at Lytham this year. Usually when the womenâ€™s is somewhere, then the menâ€™s seems to follow pretty soon after. That could be the case.â€McIlroy was in fine fettle despite missing a short par putt on the 18th hole of his third round at the Dubai Desert Classic. His 71 for a three under par aggregate almost certainly leaves too much to do going into round four. â€œItâ€™s January,â€ he said when asked to assess the state of his game.â€œI am sort of working my way back into form a little bit. It is OK. Itâ€™s not exactly where I want it to be, but it is early. I just want to go out and play a good round tomorrow and end the week on a positive note.â€Patrick Reedâ€™s 67 means he will take a four-shot lead into the final day at the Emirates Club. Spainâ€™s David Puig is the closest to Reedâ€™s 14 under par aggregate. Andy Sullivan and Viktor Hovland are at minus nine.Explore more on these topicsRory McIlroyThe OpenEuropean TourGolfnewsShareReuse this content

title: Thomas Frank calls for â€˜calm headsâ€™ as Tottenham fans renew calls for his exit | Tottenham Hotspur | The Guardian
description: Thomas Frank has called for â€˜calm headsâ€™ after Tottenhamâ€™s draw at relegation-threatened Burnley despite fans again urging the club to dismiss him
Author: Will Unwin
Headline: Thomas Frank has called for â€˜calm headsâ€™ after Tottenhamâ€™s draw at relegation-threatened Burnley despite fans again urging the club to dismiss him
Content: Thomas Frank (left) talks to Micky van de Ven after the draw at Burnley.Photograph: Richard Sellers/PAView image in fullscreenThomas Frank (left) talks to Micky van de Ven after the draw at Burnley.Photograph: Richard Sellers/PATottenham HotspurThomas Frank calls for â€˜calm headsâ€™ as Tottenham fans renew calls for his exitHead coach targeted in draw at BurnleyFrank: â€˜You canâ€™t say we didnâ€™t do everything to winâ€™Will Unwinat Turf MoorSat 24 Jan 2026 13.32 ESTLast modified on Sat 24 Jan 2026 13.58 ESTShareThomas Frank has called for â€œcalm headsâ€ after Tottenham fans urged the club to dismiss him during their draw at relegation-threatened Burnley. The away end sang â€œYouâ€™re getting sacked in the morningâ€ at full time, making their views clear to the hierarchy and head coach.Cristian Romero salvaged a late point for Tottenhamafter Axel Tuanzebe and Lyle Foster had turned things around to counter Micky van de Venâ€™s opening goal. The draw leaves Tottenham with two wins in 14 and mired in mid-table.Romeroâ€™s late strike rescues point for troubled Tottenham at BurnleyRead moreâ€œYou canâ€™t say we didnâ€™t do everything to win,â€ Frank said. â€œWe just need to keep improving. The only way it can be is calm heads, carry on and keep doing what we think is the right thing.â€œWe do more than enough to win the game, we just need to defend better in two situations. And, of course, score another goal that could make the difference at 1-0.â€Poor defending assisted Burnleyâ€™s comeback. â€œWe can never, ever, ever concede that goal, because it just changes the momentum going into half-time,â€ Frank said of Tuanzebeâ€™s header.â€œIn the second half we are coming out, we are not as dominant, but I still think we are OK on top. We got a big chance to Dominic Solanke, 2-1 up. And then we concede another goal that we can never, ever, ever concede.â€The Tottenham supporters chanted regularly for Frankâ€™s exit during the match. Talks were held last weekend over the head coachâ€™s position, but no definitive action was taken.View image in fullscreenMicky van de Ven put Tottenham in front at Turf Moor but the visitors fell behind before Cristian Romeroâ€™s late leveller.Photograph: Peter Powell/Reutersâ€œThe message to the fans, as I said the whole time, is that weâ€™re working very hard on making sure everything is going in the right direction and that weâ€™ll keep doing that,â€ Frank said.â€œFirst and foremost, I want to thank them for travelling and supporting the team throughout the game. We could, should have been out of sight. But also they acknowledge the willpower and character of the team that keep running, keep fighting to the end. We just need to keep going.â€A point away to Eintracht Frankfurt on Wednesday should guarantee a top-eight spot in the Champions League and progression to the round of 16, which would help Frankâ€™s cause. The club are also in negotiations with Liverpool overthe signing of the defender Andy Robertson, who would become the second new arrival this month afterConor Gallagher.There were more points dropped late on by Burnley, which has become a regular occurrence this season. â€œIt was only four or five weeks ago I was hugely critical of this team in terms of usat Brighton away, weâ€™ve reacted in an incredible way,â€ Scott Parker said.â€œThereâ€™s no denying that we need to now turn draws into wins and today, for being so close, youâ€™d hope that would have been the case.
